description: Those looking to complete the Apple Certified Support Professional (ACSP) certification will find in this course an overview of the process involved in achieving the certification and details about the exam required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is designed for technicians working in business environments supporting Apple computers and confirms one understands OS X's core functionality. Viewers will learn in this course tactics like basic installation and configuration of OS X Yosemite, managing user accounts, file systems used by Mac OS, enforcing policy across a network, data management, applications and processes, network configurations, and system management and security.
name: Certified Support Professional 10.10
subtitle: OS X Support Essentials 10.10

episodes.description: The ACSP certification is for businesses when they deploy Macs for the use of basic installation, security, policy enforcement and for the purpose of getting Macs to interact with non-Apple operating systems. Viewers will hear an overview about the knowledge one needs to attain the ACSP certification, about the OS X Support Essentials Exam and the exam objectives of topics one should know for the exam.

00:33:50,910 --> 00:33:52,920
on the next screen you'll be
able to choose the time zone.

697
00:33:52,920 --> 00:33:55,080
I'm just going to leave it checked and
continue.

698
00:33:55,080 --> 00:33:57,400
And now we should be good to go.

00:33:57,400 --> 00:34:00,790
All right, our diagnostic and
usage screen there,

we just say whether we want
to report that back to Apple.

701
00:34:03,110 --> 00:34:05,986
My computer is gonna get wiped here before
too long so I'm gonna turn those off.

00:34:08,400 --> 00:34:12,219
And there it goes for the initial setup,
it's creating your user profile for

703
00:34:12,219 --> 00:34:15,979
that account we just made, we'll probably
need to follow this up though and

704
00:34:15,979 --> 00:34:17,630
create other accounts.

00:34:17,630 --> 00:34:19,880
But now that it's done,
here it is, it's fired up,

706

I still have my installation media sitting
right there that I installed from,

00:34:23,184 --> 00:34:26,561
I can get rid of that now, I'm done with

00:34:28,331 --> 00:34:32,433
All right, and now I've got a fresh clean
installation of Yosemite and I can go in

709
00:34:32,433 --> 00:34:36,320

710
00:34:36,320 --> 00:34:38,140
I am still logged in as that
administrator account though.

711
00:34:38,140 --> 00:34:42,140
So, one of the first steps that I would do
is to jump into my system preferences and

712
00:34:42,140 --> 00:34:46,200
go down to users and groups, and
in here you'll see that account we made.

00:34:46,200 --> 00:34:48,100

We probably want to add a new account.

715
00:34:49,700 --> 00:34:54,860
So I'm just gonna hit the unlock

716
00:34:54,860 --> 00:34:58,540
And I'll add in a new account for
myself, right, Don Pezet and

717
00:34:58,540 --> 00:35:02,220
I'll just make myself a standard user,

718
00:35:02,220 --> 00:35:05,040
And I'm not gonna use iCloud for this one.

719
00:35:06,170 --> 00:35:09,220

I'll get that account created.

721

And now the computer is ready
to turn over to the end user.

722
00:35:13,130 --> 00:35:15,610
And I can tell the end user,
hey, log in as Don Pezette.

723

Here's your password.

724
00:35:16,710 --> 00:35:20,310
And now you've got access to your system.

725
00:35:20,310 --> 00:35:24,050
Not too terribly a painful process
to get it set up and installed.

726
00:35:24,050 --> 00:35:28,070
Now for those of you that are interested,
back in the ACA shows and

727
00:35:28,070 --> 00:35:30,340
we're gonna see this in the ACTC show.

728

We can do automated employments of
Mac OS where it's preconfigured,

729

it's already got user accounts created or

730

731

You can do some really cool
automated deployments.

732

We're not going to cover that here,

733
00:35:45,900 --> 00:35:49,480
Or if you're in a hurry, we already

00:35:49,480 --> 00:35:50,610
you can jump over and catch it there.

735
00:35:52,022 --> 00:35:55,980
All right, but as far as the install and

736

Pretty straight forward process and

I don't think we did anything in here that

738
00:36:00,530 --> 00:36:03,690
For the most part it was clicking next a
bunch of times and off you go, all right.

739
00:36:04,830 --> 00:36:07,910
For the exam and

That was covered in the first show.

742

The second thing, remember that having

743
00:36:16,010 --> 00:36:20,550
really handy for doing clean installs,

744

manual upgrades like that, having that

745
00:36:24,290 --> 00:36:26,710
And we showed how to make
that in the first episode.

746
00:36:26,710 --> 00:36:30,310
For doing an upgrade though, most people

747
00:36:30,310 --> 00:36:33,100
Do an in place upgrade, you don't

748
00:36:33,100 --> 00:36:35,380
You just use the download
link in the App Store.

749
00:36:35,380 --> 00:36:37,230
Off you go pretty straight forward there.

750
00:36:37,230 --> 00:36:40,640
I also talked about
the migration assistant, right.

00:36:40,640 --> 00:36:45,000
We got a chance to see that where we could
bring our data over from other Macs or

752
00:36:45,000 --> 00:36:48,840
we could bring it over from a Windows PC,
right now functionality is there and

753
00:36:48,840 --> 00:36:49,580
works pretty well.

754
00:36:49,580 --> 00:36:52,940
It will help you get your data on
the new machine and get up and running.

755
00:36:52,940 --> 00:36:56,500
Now Apple's trying to remove that
apprehension people have like how am I

756
00:36:56,500 --> 00:36:59,780
going to buy a new computer cuz this
computers built exactly the way I want it

757
00:36:59,780 --> 00:37:02,770
well, here's your chance to move
those settings over, and get running.

758
00:37:03,770 --> 00:37:04,490
All right.

759
00:37:04,490 --> 00:37:07,570
Well, that's a pretty good spot for

764
00:37:15,550 --> 00:37:16,990
But you gotta start somewhere.

Installation upgrades

766
00:37:19,530 --> 00:37:22,650
All right, let me remind you guys if

episodes.description: When something goes wrong with the Mac OS, one will need to look into different recovery features. Viewers will hear discussions about the downloadable recovery disk assistant for older operating systems like OS X Lion, the built-in recovery partition that is included in most newer systems like Mavericks and Yosemite, the internet recovery feature, and using the recovery partition found in the USB installation media.
episodes.title: OS Recovery
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,678 --> 00:00:36,151
Alright, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:36,151 --> 00:00:38,490
Welcome back,
to another episode of IT pro tv.

4
00:00:38,490 --> 00:00:40,510
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:40,510 --> 00:00:43,848
Back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

6
00:00:43,848 --> 00:00:47,980
Today we're gonna be jumping
into operating system recovery,

7
00:00:47,980 --> 00:00:51,510
which is one of those topics that we need
to be aware of if we're supporting Macs,

8
00:00:51,510 --> 00:00:54,510
but hopefully we never have to use, right.

9
00:00:54,510 --> 00:00:58,740
OS recovery, that means something
is going wrong with Mac OS.

10
00:00:58,740 --> 00:01:01,640
Things are not working the way
they're supposed to work, and

11
00:01:01,640 --> 00:01:03,520
we've got to find some way to recover it.

12
00:01:03,520 --> 00:01:07,750
Well, to better understand this let's talk
about some of the symptoms that might be

13
00:01:07,750 --> 00:01:09,920
leading to this type of needing, right.

14
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:15,410
Maybe you have a computer that's been
running Yosemite for months or years.

15
00:01:15,410 --> 00:01:16,540
Things have been running fine.

16
00:01:16,540 --> 00:01:18,040
In for a long time, and

17
00:01:18,040 --> 00:01:21,090
all of a sudden you're starting to
see some erratic behavior, right.

18
00:01:21,090 --> 00:01:25,220
Maybe certain files are missing
from your hard drive that you

19
00:01:25,220 --> 00:01:26,760
know were there yesterday.

20
00:01:26,760 --> 00:01:30,970
Or maybe the files there, but when you try
and open them they're corrupted, right.

21
00:01:30,970 --> 00:01:35,680
Maybe you're seeing that spinning color
wheel a lot more than you used to.

22
00:01:35,680 --> 00:01:39,742
Just throughout the day this constantly
spinning color wheel really slow system,

23
00:01:39,742 --> 00:01:40,780
all right.

24
00:01:40,780 --> 00:01:43,790
Maybe your computer's
occasionally freezing.

25
00:01:43,790 --> 00:01:46,150
You're working and all of a sudden
it just stops responding and

26
00:01:46,150 --> 00:01:47,950
you have to re-boot, all right.

27
00:01:47,950 --> 00:01:52,180
These are all symptoms that could
indicate a problem with MacOS.

28
00:01:52,180 --> 00:01:56,190
An actual operating system
issue on your computer.

29
00:01:56,190 --> 00:01:57,780
Right.
Now those are the symptoms,

30
00:01:57,780 --> 00:01:58,840
what are some of the causes?

31
00:01:58,840 --> 00:02:00,950
Well, there's any number of
things that can cause this.

32
00:02:00,950 --> 00:02:02,800
It could be failing memory, right.

33
00:02:02,800 --> 00:02:06,190
The RAM sticks inside of your
computer can go bad over time.

34
00:02:06,190 --> 00:02:08,420
More commonly though
it's failing hard drive.

35
00:02:08,420 --> 00:02:12,304
As your hard drive starts to fail,
you'll lose one sector and

36
00:02:12,304 --> 00:02:14,780
then another sector and then another.

37
00:02:14,780 --> 00:02:16,780
A hard drive never loses just one sector.

38
00:02:16,780 --> 00:02:18,810
It always starts to spread,
and it gets worse and

39
00:02:18,810 --> 00:02:22,150
worse and worse until the hard drive
becomes completely unreliable, all right.

40
00:02:23,430 --> 00:02:26,410
What happens is, when Yosemite runs,

41
00:02:26,410 --> 00:02:28,720
it tries to load its files
off of the hard drive.

42
00:02:28,720 --> 00:02:31,690
If the files are bad on the hard drive,
as soon as it reads them,

43
00:02:31,690 --> 00:02:34,010
they're already bad and
it's not gonna work right.

44
00:02:34,010 --> 00:02:37,880
If it's the memory that's bad,
when Yosemite reads a file off of the hard

45
00:02:37,880 --> 00:02:40,270
drive it copies it into
RAM to work with it.

46
00:02:40,270 --> 00:02:42,890
And so when it first copies it in
there it thinks everything's fine and

47
00:02:42,890 --> 00:02:46,960
then when it goes back to re-read the file
from RAM, now the file is damaged in RAM.

48
00:02:46,960 --> 00:02:47,740
Right.

49
00:02:47,740 --> 00:02:50,940
That's even harder to track down cuz
the error will usually be different every

50
00:02:50,940 --> 00:02:51,570
single time.

51
00:02:51,570 --> 00:02:53,630
It's really difficult to track those down.

52
00:02:53,630 --> 00:02:56,790
But at the end of the day they really end

53
00:02:56,790 --> 00:02:59,630
up causing a problem with
the operating system.

54
00:02:59,630 --> 00:03:02,880
So even if I go back and
I fix the RAM chip, I replace it.

55
00:03:02,880 --> 00:03:05,420
Or I replace the hard drive and
I clone the drive over.

56
00:03:05,420 --> 00:03:09,510
When I do that I may still have
corrupted files on the drive.

57
00:03:09,510 --> 00:03:13,220
And so we need to be able to fix that,
and that's where OS recovery comes in.

58
00:03:13,220 --> 00:03:14,647
Right.

59
00:03:14,647 --> 00:03:17,322
Apple has a collection of utilities
that are available for us to try and

60
00:03:17,322 --> 00:03:19,787
recover systems that are experiencing
these kind of problems.

61
00:03:19,787 --> 00:03:21,714
If you can't boot your computer up.

62
00:03:21,714 --> 00:03:24,135
If you do boot up but it freezes a lot.

63
00:03:24,135 --> 00:03:24,953
Or it locks up.

64
00:03:24,953 --> 00:03:26,102
Or your files are missing.

65
00:03:26,102 --> 00:03:30,560
We need some way to be able to access
our system to fix the problem.

66
00:03:30,560 --> 00:03:33,820
That doesn't require us using
the operating system that is the problem.

67
00:03:33,820 --> 00:03:34,460
Right.

68
00:03:34,460 --> 00:03:37,860
So, we have a few mechanisms for
it, and it's changed a good bit

69
00:03:37,860 --> 00:03:41,400
over the years to try and become
a lot more simple than it used to be.

70
00:03:42,660 --> 00:03:47,010
Well, inside of Yosemite the options are
actually a little different than what we

71
00:03:47,010 --> 00:03:47,540
had before.

72
00:03:47,540 --> 00:03:49,340
Let's cover the old way first.

73
00:03:49,340 --> 00:03:52,421
[COUGH] In the olden days, right,
under lion, so it was really just two,

74
00:03:52,421 --> 00:03:53,970
three years ago.

75
00:03:53,970 --> 00:03:59,910
Under Mac OS X Lion, you actually have
what was called the Recovery Assistant.

76
00:03:59,910 --> 00:04:03,065
And if you never heard of this,
let me bring up the webpage for it here.

77
00:04:03,065 --> 00:04:05,100
[COUGH] I've got Apple's page pulled up.

78
00:04:05,100 --> 00:04:08,630
Here's their
OS X: About Recovery Disk Assistant.

79
00:04:08,630 --> 00:04:12,290
So the Recovery Disk Assistant was
a little disk that you could make and you

80
00:04:12,290 --> 00:04:15,680
could burn it to a DVD, but more commonly
you used a USB thumb drive, right.

81
00:04:15,680 --> 00:04:18,555
So you take a little thumb
drive you format it,

82
00:04:18,555 --> 00:04:21,590
you throw the recovery
disk assistant on there.

83
00:04:23,222 --> 00:04:25,566
And you boot the computer up, and
it would boot this recovery menu.

84
00:04:25,566 --> 00:04:27,429
And the recovery menu would let
you get to the disk utility.

85
00:04:27,429 --> 00:04:29,467
It would let you get to
the startup program.

86
00:04:29,467 --> 00:04:32,056
You will be able to modify what
disc was booting, things like that.

87
00:04:32,056 --> 00:04:34,285
Basic tools you needed to recover system.

88
00:04:34,285 --> 00:04:35,927
Doesn't really need all right.

89
00:04:35,927 --> 00:04:40,021
But if you go to build
a recovery disk assistant today,

90
00:04:40,021 --> 00:04:45,272
one of the things you'll notice is
that it sure does talk about Lion and

91
00:04:45,272 --> 00:04:48,800
Mountain Lion quite a bit, all right.

92
00:04:48,800 --> 00:04:51,770
And it doesn't really mention Yosemite.

93
00:04:51,770 --> 00:04:56,270
The reason is, all of the utilities
that were present in the disk assistant

94
00:04:56,270 --> 00:05:00,380
are now part of just the regular
installation media for Yosemite.

95
00:05:00,380 --> 00:05:05,710
So if you've created an external
installation media for

96
00:05:05,710 --> 00:05:08,140
Yosemite, you can boot off of that, and

97
00:05:08,140 --> 00:05:11,100
you have access to everything
the Recovery Disk Assistant did, too.

98
00:05:11,100 --> 00:05:16,010
So we don't really need a dedicated
recovery disk assistant for

99
00:05:16,010 --> 00:05:18,510
Yosemite or even Mavericks for
that matter.

100
00:05:18,510 --> 00:05:21,900
So if you read this article, and I'll post
the links for this in the show notes, but

101
00:05:21,900 --> 00:05:24,820
if you read it and you get down to
the bottom, and you go to download

102
00:05:24,820 --> 00:05:29,960
the recovery assistant, you'll notice
that it's branded for Lion, all right.

103
00:05:29,960 --> 00:05:34,300
And if you search Apple site, there is no,

104
00:05:35,590 --> 00:05:38,330
Yosemite or Mavericks download for
it, all right.

105
00:05:38,330 --> 00:05:41,935
So you might ask yourself, well wait a
minute Don, it was really nice having that

106
00:05:41,935 --> 00:05:45,730
little media, that key that I could
punch into a computer and boot from it.

107
00:05:45,730 --> 00:05:46,940
Now I don't have that.

108
00:05:46,940 --> 00:05:49,010
Well, you do right,
it's just the install media.

109
00:05:49,010 --> 00:05:51,990
You make that installation media like
we showed in the very first episode of

110
00:05:51,990 --> 00:05:52,860
this series.

111
00:05:52,860 --> 00:05:54,879
You boot off of that and
you'll have access to the same utilities.

112
00:05:56,040 --> 00:05:57,970
All right.
Let's go worst case scenario.

113
00:05:57,970 --> 00:06:00,080
What if you didn't make
the installation media?

114
00:06:00,080 --> 00:06:03,820
Well, that's the part where we're
actually covered really well.

115
00:06:03,820 --> 00:06:07,000
If your mac is running Mavericks or
Yosemite,

116
00:06:07,000 --> 00:06:11,510
right if you're in 10.9 or 10.10,
when you bought that computer from Apple,

117
00:06:11,510 --> 00:06:16,070
they did two things to make it where
you shouldn't need that key, all right.

118
00:06:16,070 --> 00:06:20,370
The first thing is the recovery
utility in that installation media

119
00:06:20,370 --> 00:06:24,410
is actually a hidden partition on
the hard drive of your computer already.

120
00:06:24,410 --> 00:06:25,030
RIght.

121
00:06:25,030 --> 00:06:29,210
So, it's already stored,
just hidden on your computer.

122
00:06:29,210 --> 00:06:32,640
And if you need to access recovery,
you don't need a USB key for it.

123
00:06:32,640 --> 00:06:33,940
It's right there on the drive.

124
00:06:33,940 --> 00:06:37,180
So if you had some memory that was going
bad, and you've replaced the memory.

125
00:06:37,180 --> 00:06:40,540
They've fixed that, and now there's
some file corruption on your system, or

126
00:06:40,540 --> 00:06:42,620
your operating system files
are a little corrupted.

127
00:06:42,620 --> 00:06:46,090
Well you can just reboot your mac and
boot your recovery.

128
00:06:46,090 --> 00:06:50,140
The way you do it by holding
command R while you boot.

129
00:06:50,140 --> 00:06:54,340
You basically hit power on your keyboard
while youre holding command R and

130
00:06:54,340 --> 00:06:57,620
you wait until the little gray apple
symbol appears when you see that apple

131
00:06:57,620 --> 00:07:01,260
logo you can let go, and at that
point its gonna boot your recovery.

132
00:07:01,260 --> 00:07:05,300
Itll look for that hidden partition on
the drive, and it will boot from that.

133
00:07:05,300 --> 00:07:11,190
All right, now in the official Apple
textbooks, in their information, they tell

134
00:07:11,190 --> 00:07:16,610
us that the recovery partition is hidden
and command R is the way you get to it.

135
00:07:16,610 --> 00:07:19,710
But I'll tell you in real life land,
if you boot up your system and

136
00:07:19,710 --> 00:07:22,060
you just hold the Alt or the option key.

137
00:07:22,060 --> 00:07:25,320
The option key that we used to pick
which partition we're gonna boot from,

138
00:07:25,320 --> 00:07:27,780
you'll find that on most computers

00:17:45,100 --> 00:17:48,920
I've got my operating system hard drive,
my user data hard drive, my installer,

375
00:17:48,920 --> 00:17:49,622
I don't want to go there.

376
00:17:49,622 --> 00:17:53,430
I'm gonna pick the operating system
hard drive and I'll hit continue, and

377
00:17:53,430 --> 00:17:56,890
on this next screen it's
going to start the install.

378
00:17:56,890 --> 00:18:01,590
Now, when I started that install,
am I about to lose all my data?

379
00:18:01,590 --> 00:18:04,180
Well no, what it's actually doing is

380
00:18:04,180 --> 00:18:06,800
replacing all of
the operating system files.

381
00:18:06,800 --> 00:18:09,670
If any of the operating
system files we damaged,

382
00:18:09,670 --> 00:18:14,530
it's gonna replace those with good clean
ones right out of our recovery partition.

383
00:18:14,530 --> 00:18:15,110
All right?

384
00:18:15,110 --> 00:18:18,230
Or from our reinstallation media
if that's where we're coming from.

385
00:18:18,230 --> 00:18:20,430
So it's gonna replace those and
get them in place.

386
00:18:21,540 --> 00:18:23,210
All right so
we'll leave that one churning along.

387
00:18:23,210 --> 00:18:25,460
And I do wanna show you
guys one more thing.

388
00:18:25,460 --> 00:18:28,230
Right there I did
the boot off of recovery.

389
00:18:28,230 --> 00:18:31,160
Let me show you what happens if you
boot up the installation media.

390
00:18:31,160 --> 00:18:34,480
When you boot off the installation
media it detects that you've

391
00:18:34,480 --> 00:18:38,480
already got an OS on the drive and
it changes the menu items a little bit.

392
00:18:38,480 --> 00:18:42,600
In the previous episode I showed doing
an install in a new machine, and

393
00:18:42,600 --> 00:18:45,500
we booted off the installation media and
did the whole install.

394
00:18:45,500 --> 00:18:48,100
But I didn't dive into all the different
menu items because we weren't

395
00:18:48,100 --> 00:18:49,610
talking about recovery then.

396
00:18:49,610 --> 00:18:53,400
When it comes to recovery for me, I almost
always boot off of the installation media

397
00:18:53,400 --> 00:18:55,150
because it's got some
neat utilities in there.

398
00:18:55,150 --> 00:18:57,250
So let me show you those
right here on this machine.

399
00:18:57,250 --> 00:18:59,890
So here's another machine that I
booted off my installation media.

400
00:18:59,890 --> 00:19:04,480
I popped my USB key in there I held
down my Alt key while I booted, and

401
00:19:04,480 --> 00:19:07,330
I chose this installation
media to boot from.

402
00:19:07,330 --> 00:19:10,140
And when it came up, I get this menu here.

403
00:19:10,140 --> 00:19:11,560
Actually, I'm lying.

404
00:19:11,560 --> 00:19:13,500
I did hold down Cmd+R
when I booted this one.

405
00:19:13,500 --> 00:19:17,030
So I held down Cmd+R and
it booted off that installation media.

406
00:19:17,030 --> 00:19:19,160
But what you'll see are some
slightly different menu items.

407
00:19:19,160 --> 00:19:22,390
Now Disk Utility, right, Get Help Online.

408
00:19:22,390 --> 00:19:24,570
Those are ones that we saw
before in earlier episodes, but

409
00:19:24,570 --> 00:19:29,770
here I've got restore from time machine,
and reinstall OS X.

410
00:19:29,770 --> 00:19:33,370
Restore from time machine, that's going
to basically allow to hook up an external

411
00:19:33,370 --> 00:19:37,190
hard drive and recover our date,
bringing in our system from that way.

412
00:19:37,190 --> 00:19:41,220
Reinstall OS X, that's going to copy
over our operating system files and

413
00:19:41,220 --> 00:19:43,560
put them in place so
we can boot our system.

414
00:19:43,560 --> 00:19:49,840
So we've got that option here and
it says, reinstall a new copy of OS X.

415
00:19:49,840 --> 00:19:53,430
But it is installing on top of your
existing copy, if you want to do a true

416
00:19:53,430 --> 00:19:57,010
reinstall you need to go to disk
utility and format your drive first.

417
00:19:57,010 --> 00:19:59,710
That way it doesn't
bring in your old data.

418
00:19:59,710 --> 00:20:01,760
Some of the other things that
are different is if I go up

419
00:20:01,760 --> 00:20:05,850
under the utilities menu, notice how
I've got my Firmware Password Utility,

420
00:20:05,850 --> 00:20:08,900
I've got Terminal, but
I've also got Network Utility.

421
00:20:08,900 --> 00:20:11,830
I didn't see the Network Utility a few
moments ago because I was booting to

422
00:20:11,830 --> 00:20:15,150
recover off a local hard drive so
it didn't need network access.

423
00:20:15,150 --> 00:20:16,430
Then here it's got the network utility.

424
00:20:16,430 --> 00:20:20,020
And I can go into that, and
it lets you do some simple tests.

425
00:20:20,020 --> 00:20:22,000
You can see if you're
getting an IP address,

426
00:20:22,000 --> 00:20:24,600
you can do pings, lookups, trace routes.

427
00:20:24,600 --> 00:20:28,490
So you've got a few options here to be
able to check your network connectivity,

428
00:20:28,490 --> 00:20:29,710
which can be pretty handy too.

429
00:20:29,710 --> 00:20:32,960
So there's a lot of neat
utilities that are built in here

430
00:20:32,960 --> 00:20:35,590
to help with recovery of the system.

431
00:20:35,590 --> 00:20:39,030
But for most of us, we're really
going to be doing one of two things.

432
00:20:39,030 --> 00:20:43,500
Either reinstalling OS X to repair
our operating system files, or

433
00:20:43,500 --> 00:20:46,900
restoring from Time Machine
to repair our files, right?

434
00:20:46,900 --> 00:20:51,290
If there is disk corruption, it probably
hasn't just affected the operating system.

435
00:20:51,290 --> 00:20:53,510
It's probably affected your
personal files too, so

436
00:20:53,510 --> 00:20:56,510
restoring from Time Machine
is one of the best options.

437
00:20:56,510 --> 00:20:59,430
And just a personal word of advice,
you never

438
00:20:59,430 --> 00:21:03,000
want to rely on a hard drive that's
tested with a failure at some point.

439
00:21:03,000 --> 00:21:07,580
If a hard drive had a single sector fail,
well Mac OS is smart it will flag it as

440
00:21:07,580 --> 00:21:10,430
bad sector and it won't write to it
anymore, it will write to other sectors.

441
00:21:10,430 --> 00:21:13,820
But you never have just one sector fail,
it will start to spread,

442
00:21:13,820 --> 00:21:17,020
it may not spread right away it may
take a few days, weeks, months.

443
00:21:17,020 --> 00:21:19,340
But it will spread and
that drive will fail.

444
00:21:19,340 --> 00:21:22,780
Better to replace it on your
schedule than to replace it

445
00:21:22,780 --> 00:21:26,020
whenever that hard drive chooses to fail
and you know you are busy at work and

446
00:21:26,020 --> 00:21:28,380
you're trying to get things done and
the hard drive is dead.

447
00:21:28,380 --> 00:21:31,860
All right, so better to replace
those things ahead of time.

448
00:21:31,860 --> 00:21:35,000
All right so recovering our systems,
pretty straight forward.

449
00:21:35,000 --> 00:21:36,430
A lot of good stuff is built in.

450
00:21:36,430 --> 00:21:38,350
So let me just recap these.

451
00:21:38,350 --> 00:21:42,680
For Mountain Lion and earlier we
have the recovery disk assistant.

452
00:21:42,680 --> 00:21:44,560
We download that utility from Apple.

453
00:21:44,560 --> 00:21:45,310
You run it.

454
00:21:45,310 --> 00:21:48,660
You point it at a USBP and
it will make your recovery disk assistant.

455
00:21:48,660 --> 00:21:50,050
That's good for Mountain Lion and earlier.

456
00:21:51,260 --> 00:21:55,050
For mavericks and
Yosemite boot with command R.

457
00:21:55,050 --> 00:21:58,120
The recovery partition is
already on the hard drive.

458
00:21:59,620 --> 00:22:02,420
If the hard drive is damaged
we have Internet recovery.

459
00:22:02,420 --> 00:22:06,020
You boot holding Cmd+R, it won't
find recovery on the hard drive and

460
00:22:06,020 --> 00:22:08,160
it'll go out to the Internet instead.

461
00:22:08,160 --> 00:22:09,220
And pull it right from Apple.

462
00:22:09,220 --> 00:22:10,490
All right.

463
00:22:10,490 --> 00:22:14,100
Then the other option was to boot from
the installation media which was the last

464
00:22:14,100 --> 00:22:15,010
thing that I did.

465
00:22:15,010 --> 00:22:17,270
I booted with Cmd+R with
the installation media in and

466
00:22:17,270 --> 00:22:19,480
it pulled the recovery
partition from there.

467
00:22:19,480 --> 00:22:21,650
And I've got the option
to reinstall DOS and

468
00:22:21,650 --> 00:22:23,410
all the various other things that we need.

469
00:22:23,410 --> 00:22:24,050
All right.

470
00:22:24,050 --> 00:22:27,480
Remember that if you're doing Internet
recovery and it's connecting to Apple and

471
00:22:27,480 --> 00:22:32,770
do reinstall DOS, it's over five gigs
of data that it's gotta download and

472
00:22:32,770 --> 00:22:33,680
that's gonna take a while.

473
00:22:33,680 --> 00:22:35,680
If you're doing it off of
your installation media,

474
00:22:35,680 --> 00:22:37,980
it's much faster and so
that's what I recommend.

475
00:22:37,980 --> 00:22:41,420
But for the exam, you need to be familiar
with each of the different options and

476
00:22:41,420 --> 00:22:42,500
those are what we've just seen.

477
00:22:43,780 --> 00:22:44,420
All right.
Also

478
00:22:44,420 --> 00:22:48,160
keep in mind that there's always that
menu bar up at the top of the screen.

479
00:22:48,160 --> 00:22:51,060
So if you don't see an option
in the utilities that are being

480
00:22:51,060 --> 00:22:54,220
displayed in the main part of the screen,
look up to the menu.

481
00:22:54,220 --> 00:22:55,750
Right?
Up in the menu you'll have that utilities

482
00:22:55,750 --> 00:22:58,460
drop down and there's more
stuff stashed away under there.

483
00:22:59,740 --> 00:23:00,690
All right.

484
00:23:00,690 --> 00:23:03,210
So that's basically it for OS recovery.

485
00:23:03,210 --> 00:23:04,510
Not a terribly difficult thing.

486
00:23:04,510 --> 00:23:07,720
In typical Apple style they try
to make it easy and painless.

487
00:23:07,720 --> 00:23:08,772
And in this case, it is.

488
00:23:08,772 --> 00:23:11,530
All right, well let me remind you guys,

489
00:23:11,530 --> 00:23:13,917
if you have any questions on this stuff,
feel free to ask.

490
00:23:13,917 --> 00:23:15,110
Right?
Live during the show,

491
00:23:15,110 --> 00:23:19,300
you can go to itpro.tv/live and you can
post your questions in the chat room,

492
00:23:19,300 --> 00:23:21,360
we monitor and answer during the show.

493
00:23:21,360 --> 00:23:23,100
If you have any questions after the show,

494
00:23:23,100 --> 00:23:24,810
well you can always go into our Q and
A forums.

495
00:23:24,810 --> 00:23:27,670
At the top of every page is
a link that says Q and A.

496
00:23:27,670 --> 00:23:31,260
Hop in there, post your questions,
we monitor and answer after the show.

497
00:23:31,260 --> 00:23:35,150
All right well that's about all we've got
for this episode so thanks for watching.

498
00:23:35,150 --> 00:23:38,708
Signing off for ITPROTV,
I'm Don Pezet and I'll see you next time.

499
00:23:38,708 --> 00:23:48,708
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Once a system is installed, initial configuration will need to be done. Viewers will see how to automate settings through the Profile Manager and move over data from an old console to a new one using the Migration Assistant tool. Viewers will also hear system preferences, network configurations, and the setup assistant be discussed.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,050 --> 00:00:10,050
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,220 --> 00:00:22,630
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,630 --> 00:00:32,630
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,720 --> 00:00:36,170
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

5
00:00:36,170 --> 00:00:38,800
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,800 --> 00:00:40,342
I'm your host, Don Pezet,

7
00:00:40,342 --> 00:00:44,470
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

8
00:00:44,470 --> 00:00:48,758
Now, in our previous episodes we've
been taking a look at getting Yosemite

9
00:00:48,758 --> 00:00:53,180
installed on a new Mac, or on an existing
Mac, and we took a look at upgrades and

10
00:00:53,180 --> 00:00:55,180
clean installs and so on.

11
00:00:55,180 --> 00:00:57,710
And what we want to take a look at now,

12
00:00:57,710 --> 00:01:01,640
is the initial configuration that we
perform once a system is installed.

13
00:01:01,640 --> 00:01:05,960
So, once we've installed Yosemite,
the default out of the box experience,

14
00:01:05,960 --> 00:01:09,720
it may be okay for us, but there might
be some things that we need to tweak.

15
00:01:09,720 --> 00:01:11,270
And so Apple, for the exam objectives,

16
00:01:11,270 --> 00:01:15,120
they call out a couple of specific
areas we need to address.

17
00:01:15,120 --> 00:01:17,620
The first area is migrating our user data.

18
00:01:17,620 --> 00:01:19,950
We might have an old computer
that we're replacing.

19
00:01:19,950 --> 00:01:21,960
We need to get our user data off of it,
right?

20
00:01:21,960 --> 00:01:27,080
If we did an upgrade, then we've already
got our user data here, we skip this step.

21
00:01:27,080 --> 00:01:30,101
But if our user data was an an old
computer or a separate system,

22
00:01:30,101 --> 00:01:33,010
we need to go and gather the data
from there and bring it over.

23
00:01:33,010 --> 00:01:36,720
So that's gonna require a little bit
of extra effort on our part, right?

24
00:01:36,720 --> 00:01:40,290
Now that's one part of the mix of
what we're going to see today.

25
00:01:40,290 --> 00:01:43,010
The other things that Apple calls
out are configuring networking.

26
00:01:43,010 --> 00:01:46,640
We need to get our Mac connected to the
network so we can do automatic updates and

27
00:01:46,640 --> 00:01:48,260
browse the Internet.

28
00:01:48,260 --> 00:01:50,400
We also need to create user accounts.

29
00:01:50,400 --> 00:01:54,130
If we had separate user accounts on our
system before we'll need them now, or

30
00:01:54,130 --> 00:01:57,690
if this is a new machine we may choose
to create those separate user accounts.

31
00:01:57,690 --> 00:02:00,340
I know in the installation episode
I created a generic account

32
00:02:00,340 --> 00:02:01,870
called Help Desk.

33
00:02:01,870 --> 00:02:04,140
So I probably need to come back and
create more user accounts for

34
00:02:04,140 --> 00:02:07,050
each of the users that
are gonna login to the system.

35
00:02:07,050 --> 00:02:10,240
Another thing we need to do is just
to adjust our general preferences, so

36
00:02:10,240 --> 00:02:13,327
we're gonna take a little tour of
the System Preferences screen, and

37
00:02:13,327 --> 00:02:15,130
what some of those general settings do.

38
00:02:15,130 --> 00:02:18,420
And then lastly we're gonna
talk about software updates.

39
00:02:18,420 --> 00:02:21,786
Apple is really good about pushing out
security fixes and software updates for

40
00:02:21,786 --> 00:02:25,407
their software, you need to make sure
that's enabled, that you're doing that and

41
00:02:25,407 --> 00:02:27,710
letting those automatic checks and
updates happen.

42
00:02:27,710 --> 00:02:30,660
They're all important pieces
of setting up a new computer.

43
00:02:31,850 --> 00:02:37,470
All right, well let's start off with
migrating our data from another system.

44
00:02:37,470 --> 00:02:40,104
If you had an old Mac, and
you just bought a new one,

45
00:02:40,104 --> 00:02:42,510
you need to be able to
get your data moved over.

46
00:02:42,510 --> 00:02:45,837
Or if you're coming from the Windows
world and you have a Windows 7 machine or

47
00:02:45,837 --> 00:02:46,810
something like that,

48
00:02:46,810 --> 00:02:49,910
and you want to bring your data over and
throw it onto the new one.

49
00:02:49,910 --> 00:02:53,370
Well, we've got a simple process that
enables us to do both of those and

50
00:02:53,370 --> 00:02:55,240
it's called the Migration Assistant.

51
00:02:55,240 --> 00:02:58,120
In the initial episodes that we
did where we were installing,

52
00:02:58,120 --> 00:02:59,630
you guys saw the Migration Assistant and

53
00:02:59,630 --> 00:03:02,300
I think I just skipped past it,
I think I said Don't Migrate Data.

54
00:03:02,300 --> 00:03:05,020
Well, the Migration Assistant does run

55
00:03:05,020 --> 00:03:08,370
the first time you boot
after doing an install.

56
00:03:08,370 --> 00:03:11,230
But that's not the only time you can run
it, you can run it whenever you want.

57
00:03:11,230 --> 00:03:13,990
It's actually tucked away inside
of your Applications folder

58
00:03:13,990 --> 00:03:15,480
in the Utilities folder.

59
00:03:15,480 --> 00:03:19,400
So the Migration Assistant is there,
we can call it up and fire it at any time.

60
00:03:19,400 --> 00:03:23,093
And you can run it more than once,
maybe you had more than one old Mac and

61
00:03:23,093 --> 00:03:26,425
you want to bring all of that data
into a single new one, right?

62
00:03:26,425 --> 00:03:28,710
So you can run the Migration Assistant
more than once and

63
00:03:28,710 --> 00:03:30,175
point to those different systems.

64
00:03:30,175 --> 00:03:32,005
It's a pretty neat little process.

65
00:03:32,005 --> 00:03:37,845
Now, when you run the Migration Assistant,
it will log you out of your Mac.

66
00:03:37,845 --> 00:03:40,824
So if you are in the middle of doing
something, you've got a bunch of documents

67
00:03:40,824 --> 00:03:42,922
open, make sure you save them
first before you run it.

68
00:03:42,922 --> 00:03:46,204
But otherwise you'll run it, and
it'll take you into this separate,

69
00:03:46,204 --> 00:03:49,543
it's like a special user space where
the Migration Assistant runs, and

70
00:03:49,543 --> 00:03:51,800
you'll be able to gather your data,
all right?

71
00:03:51,800 --> 00:03:53,550
So I want to show that to you guys.

72
00:03:53,550 --> 00:03:57,863
And to do that, what I've got is here
is a Yosemite install that I did this

73
00:03:57,863 --> 00:04:01,920
morning that is stock,
I haven't done anything to mess with this.

74
00:04:01,920 --> 00:04:05,470
I installed Yosemite and during the
install I created that Help Desk account,

75
00:04:05,470 --> 00:04:07,260
just like we did in that previous show.

76
00:04:07,260 --> 00:04:11,970
So here's a stock install that doesn't
have any of my settings, all right.

77
00:04:11,970 --> 00:04:14,680
Meanwhile, right here
I've got my old machine.

78
00:04:14,680 --> 00:04:18,240
And this is running Mavericks,
and it's got some customizations.

79
00:04:18,240 --> 00:04:21,540
I've got my autobiography
sitting here on the desktop,

80
00:04:21,540 --> 00:04:24,830
which is the shortest autobiography ever.

81
00:04:24,830 --> 00:04:27,380
We've got a couple of
custom apps installed.

82
00:04:27,380 --> 00:04:29,490
I've got my Write app installed down here.

83
00:04:29,490 --> 00:04:31,800
I've got my Space wallpaper set, right?

84
00:04:31,800 --> 00:04:34,330
So, a couple of different
things going on here.

85
00:04:34,330 --> 00:04:36,080
This system has been customized.

86
00:04:37,400 --> 00:04:40,180
Well, when I move to my new Mac,
I don't want to have to redo all

87
00:04:40,180 --> 00:04:44,700
the customizations that I did, so
I want to use the Migration Assistant.

88
00:04:44,700 --> 00:04:46,960
Now the Migration Assistant
has two pieces.

89
00:04:46,960 --> 00:04:51,090
There's the source machine,
that's the machine that has your data.

90
00:04:51,090 --> 00:04:53,910
And then there's the target machine,

91
00:04:53,910 --> 00:04:55,640
that's your new machine
that doesn't have the data.

92
00:04:56,660 --> 00:05:00,660
Your target is always going to be
Yosemite, it's the new system.

93
00:05:00,660 --> 00:05:04,480
So I'm gonna go to my target and
I'm gonna run that Migration Assistant.

94
00:05:04,480 --> 00:05:06,940
Now if this is the first time I booted,
it's already running.

95
00:05:06,940 --> 00:05:09,750
But if it's not the first time I've
booted, I just need to launch it.

96
00:05:09,750 --> 00:05:13,473
And I can fire up my Finder, and
I can go to Applications, and

97
00:05:13,473 --> 00:05:16,980
I can find that Utilities folder in here.

98
00:05:16,980 --> 00:05:20,690

00:05:20,690 --> 00:05:22,870
So I'll go ahead and

it's just gonna let me

00:05:40,090 --> 00:05:43,870

00:05:49,020 --> 00:05:53,310
It can bring it in from another Mac,

00:05:53,310 --> 00:05:57,240
But there's actually a couple of

00:05:57,240 --> 00:05:59,990
Well, From a Windows PC,

That's what you would pick on

But I'm on the target.

00:06:16,390 --> 00:06:17,790

00:06:17,790 --> 00:06:23,400
Well, if I have another Mac and it's

00:06:23,400 --> 00:06:25,100
so I've got my old Mac and my new Mac.

121
00:06:25,100 --> 00:06:28,220
If they're both on the same network,
I can choose this.

122
00:06:28,220 --> 00:06:33,140
They'll find each other over the network,
and copy my data over.

123
00:06:33,140 --> 00:06:34,640
It's the easiest way to do it.

124
00:06:34,640 --> 00:06:36,870
They can both be on
the same wireless network.

125
00:06:36,870 --> 00:06:39,770
Or one can be on a wired network, and
one can be a on a wireless network.

126
00:06:39,770 --> 00:06:43,565
As long as it's the same IP subnet,
they'll find each other and communicate.

127
00:06:43,565 --> 00:06:49,140
But, what if you've got two Macs and
they're not on the same network?

128
00:06:49,140 --> 00:06:51,660
What if one of them

129
00:06:51,660 --> 00:06:54,220
One's kind of failing so
it's not connecting to the network.

130
00:06:54,220 --> 00:06:56,950
Well, there's a few other options for us.

131
00:06:56,950 --> 00:07:00,640
If they both have a valid network cable or
a network card in them, you can use

132
00:07:00,640 --> 00:07:04,920

plug directly between the two computers.

133
00:07:04,920 --> 00:07:08,290
You plug one cable into the new Mac and
one cable into the old Mac, and

134
00:07:08,290 --> 00:07:10,920
they'll find each other
over that crossover cable.

135
00:07:10,920 --> 00:07:13,240
Keep in mind that a normal network cable,

136
00:07:13,240 --> 00:07:15,850
a normal Ethernet patch cable
will not work for that.

137
00:07:15,850 --> 00:07:18,650
When you go computer-to-computer
it's gotta be a crossover cable.

138
00:07:19,790 --> 00:07:21,410
You can also do FireWire.

139
00:07:21,410 --> 00:07:23,480
If both of your Macs,
your new one and your old one,

140
00:07:23,480 --> 00:07:27,170

141
00:07:27,170 --> 00:07:29,950
to the other, and they'll find each
other over the FireWire connection.

142
00:07:31,290 --> 00:07:35,630
There is a third option which is a cool

143
00:07:35,630 --> 00:07:40,100
If I can just make the hard drive of

144
00:07:40,100 --> 00:07:42,340

00:07:42,340 --> 00:07:44,324

146
00:07:44,324 --> 00:07:49,016

drive out of my old Mac, take it apart,

147
00:07:49,016 --> 00:07:51,973

148
00:07:51,973 --> 00:07:54,165
It'll see that drive and
import the data from there.

149
00:07:54,165 --> 00:07:55,673
The problem is.

150
00:07:55,673 --> 00:07:57,328
Most Macs don't have room for that.

151
00:07:57,328 --> 00:08:00,113
Like mine, I can't remove
the hard drive from this one.

152
00:08:00,113 --> 00:08:03,500
And even if I open it up,
there's no room for me to add another one.

153
00:08:03,500 --> 00:08:05,090
It's a laptop, right?

154
00:08:05,090 --> 00:08:06,980
So that's not always an option.

155
00:08:06,980 --> 00:08:13,280
I could use an external,
they call them sleds or drive bays

156
00:08:13,280 --> 00:08:17,940
where you can hook up an external hard
drive via USB or Thunderbolt or whatever.

157
00:08:17,940 --> 00:08:20,560
So you could connect the drive
that way and it'll see it and

158
00:08:20,560 --> 00:08:23,410
allow us to import the data.

159
00:08:23,410 --> 00:08:28,670
But most iMacs, most MacBooks, support
booting into what's called target mode.

160
00:08:28,670 --> 00:08:31,040
And with target we don't
even have to take it apart.

161
00:08:31,040 --> 00:08:34,600
When you boot up your old Mac
you can hold down the letter T.

162
00:08:34,600 --> 00:08:37,930
And when you're holding down T and
you boot up it will boot into target mode.

163
00:08:37,930 --> 00:08:42,570
And basically it turns your entire
Mac into a big external hard drive.

164
00:08:42,570 --> 00:08:46,480
And now you can hook it up via USB or
Fire wire or Thunderbolt.

165
00:08:46,480 --> 00:08:47,560
Whatever you got.

166
00:08:47,560 --> 00:08:49,060
You hook it up to the system and

167
00:08:49,060 --> 00:08:51,500
your new mac will see that
as an external hard drive.

168
00:08:51,500 --> 00:08:54,080
And it will be able input
the data that way too.

169
00:08:54,080 --> 00:08:57,810
So, tons of options for how we can
get that data off of the old Mac.

All right.

The old Mac is the one that has my data,

tt'll show up as another drive and

And there's several different attacks that

14
00:01:08,760 --> 00:01:09,880

15

So there's a few different approaches
we can take to protecting ourselves.

16
00:01:12,930 --> 00:01:17,012
So that's what we're gonna look at in this
this episode as we move through with ACSP.

17
00:01:17,012 --> 00:01:22,230
All right well, I wanna kick off
the show talking about FileVault.

18
00:01:22,230 --> 00:01:24,890
I know I mentioned FileVault in
some of the other episodes, but

19
00:01:24,890 --> 00:01:28,460
we haven't actually seen it
implemented and put into use.

20
00:01:28,460 --> 00:01:31,612
And so I wanna take a look at that,
and so I wanna begin,

21
00:01:31,612 --> 00:01:33,407
with the original FileVault.

22
00:01:33,407 --> 00:01:38,900
If you install Mac OS Yosemite, right,
10.10 or 10.9 or 10.9 whatever.

23
00:01:38,900 --> 00:01:45,075
If you install any of the newer Mac OSs,
you're running what's called FileVault 2.

24
00:01:45,075 --> 00:01:48,770
And FileVault 2 provides
whole disk encryption.

25
00:01:48,770 --> 00:01:50,840
It encrypts your entire hard drive.

26
00:01:50,840 --> 00:01:53,910
And that is the best solution for
protecting your data.

27
00:01:55,320 --> 00:01:59,170
The original version of FileVault though,
didn't do that.

28
00:01:59,170 --> 00:02:02,570
Back in the,
back in the olden days, right?

29
00:02:02,570 --> 00:02:04,370
We had the original FileVault.

30
00:02:04,370 --> 00:02:08,650
And the original FileVault just
encrypted your home directory.

31
00:02:08,650 --> 00:02:09,600
And that's it.

32
00:02:09,600 --> 00:02:14,660
It didn't' encrypt any other part of
the hard drive, just your home directory.

33
00:02:14,660 --> 00:02:16,225
Now back then,
it was just called FileVault.

34
00:02:17,250 --> 00:02:19,190
But today, and
what you'll see on the exam,

35
00:02:19,190 --> 00:02:24,220
is that the original FileVault
is called legacy FileVault.

36
00:02:24,220 --> 00:02:24,980
That's the old one.

37
00:02:24,980 --> 00:02:27,900
And the new one is FileVault version 2.

38
00:02:27,900 --> 00:02:31,040
But on the exam they really
won't call it version 2.

39
00:02:31,040 --> 00:02:33,990
When they say FileVault,
they're talking about Version 2.

40
00:02:33,990 --> 00:02:39,330
When they say Legacy FileVault, they're
talking about Version 1, all right?

41
00:02:39,330 --> 00:02:41,180
Now, why one approach over the other?

42
00:02:41,180 --> 00:02:43,970
Well the original idea,
the original idea behind FileVault,

43
00:02:43,970 --> 00:02:46,360
was the each user could
make their own decision.

44
00:02:46,360 --> 00:02:51,030
They could to say, do I want to
encrypt my home directory, or not?

45
00:02:51,030 --> 00:02:53,400
And you might have some users
on your computer that do, and

46
00:02:53,400 --> 00:02:55,310
some users that don't, and that's it.

47
00:02:55,310 --> 00:03:00,270
So if I share my computer with four other
people, maybe two or three of us decide to

48
00:03:00,270 --> 00:03:03,490
encrypt our home directories,
and the other two people don't.

49
00:03:03,490 --> 00:03:05,680
You could do that with
the Legacy FileVault, with the original.

50
00:03:05,680 --> 00:03:08,520
And it would encrypt your home folder.

51
00:03:08,520 --> 00:03:10,440
But there were a couple
of problems with this.

52
00:03:10,440 --> 00:03:15,230
The main problem is that Some users
are really good about saving all of their

53
00:03:15,230 --> 00:03:18,180
data in their home directory and
so all their data was saved.

54
00:03:18,180 --> 00:03:21,780
But if a user saved their data
outside of the home directory for

55
00:03:21,780 --> 00:03:24,330
some reason,
as an administrator often can,

56
00:03:24,330 --> 00:03:28,120
the data wouldn't get encrypted and
people might not know that.

57
00:03:28,120 --> 00:03:30,490
Because FileVault for
the most part is invisible to the user.

58
00:03:30,490 --> 00:03:33,790
Once it's turned on they don't
really even notice that it's there.

59
00:03:33,790 --> 00:03:37,230
So that process is easy to forget about.

60
00:03:37,230 --> 00:03:39,290
And now we save data
outside of our directory,

61
00:03:39,290 --> 00:03:43,460
it's not encrypted and if someone
was to get a hold of our computer,

62
00:03:43,460 --> 00:03:48,010
they could boot it in target mode,
plug it into another Mac and they would

63
00:03:48,010 --> 00:03:52,120
have access to the entire file system
except for our home directory, right?

64
00:03:52,120 --> 00:03:53,850
So at least that's safe.

65
00:03:53,850 --> 00:03:56,120
If your users are goo about saving
their data in the home directory,

66
00:03:56,120 --> 00:03:58,330
the original file vault
worked really well.

67
00:03:58,330 --> 00:03:59,190
Right?

68
00:03:59,190 --> 00:04:02,250
But, it didn't give old disk encryption.

69
00:04:02,250 --> 00:04:03,240
And so, there were problems,

70
00:04:03,240 --> 00:04:07,150
there were areas like the preferences
folder, the library folder,

71
00:04:07,150 --> 00:04:10,490
that are off the root of the drive,
where applications store data.

72
00:04:10,490 --> 00:04:14,440
And that data wasn't getting encrypted and
it was still vulnerable.

73
00:04:14,440 --> 00:04:17,482
So Apple made the decision
to redo FileVault.

74
00:04:17,482 --> 00:04:19,320
In FileVault version 2,
they said, you know what?

75
00:04:19,320 --> 00:04:20,020
Forget it.
Let's

76
00:04:20,020 --> 00:04:22,190
just forget this home
user directory stuff.

77
00:04:22,190 --> 00:04:24,510
You can't trust users to
do everything they need.

78
00:04:24,510 --> 00:04:25,840
And the applications are unprotected.

79
00:04:25,840 --> 00:04:28,930
So instead, let's encrypt the whole drive.

80
00:04:28,930 --> 00:04:31,060
And Apple's not the only
company to decide this, right?

81
00:04:31,060 --> 00:04:33,500
It's been like this in Linux a long time.

82
00:04:33,500 --> 00:04:34,330
Microsoft Windows.

83
00:04:34,330 --> 00:04:35,300
They did it with BitLocker.

84
00:04:35,300 --> 00:04:36,210
Same thing.

85
00:04:36,210 --> 00:04:38,550
Encrypt the whole drive.

86
00:04:38,550 --> 00:04:40,730
And that way,
if somebody gets your computer and

87
00:04:40,730 --> 00:04:43,110
tries to boot to Target Mode, they can't.

88
00:04:43,110 --> 00:04:46,210
They can't boot to Target Mode
without your FileVault key, right?

89
00:04:46,210 --> 00:04:48,130
Or a valid login.

90
00:04:48,130 --> 00:04:49,645
If they take your hard drive out, and

91
00:04:49,645 --> 00:04:51,475
stick the hard drive
into another computer.

92
00:04:51,475 --> 00:04:53,235
It's entire encrypted.

93
00:04:53,235 --> 00:04:55,075
All of your applications,
your preferences,

94
00:04:55,075 --> 00:05:00,325
your library folder, your home directory,
the entire drive is secured.

95
00:05:00,325 --> 00:05:03,185
So, FileVault version 2,
the new FileVault?

96
00:05:03,185 --> 00:05:04,445
That's the one you want.

97
00:05:04,445 --> 00:05:05,175
Alright?

98
00:05:05,175 --> 00:05:07,825
Legacy FileVault, is not what you want.

99
00:05:07,825 --> 00:05:08,435
Alright?

100
00:05:08,435 --> 00:05:13,630
Well, if you install Yosemite, or
Mavericks, you can't do legacy file vault.

101
00:05:13,630 --> 00:05:18,430
The option's not even there,
you don't see it, so it's not a big deal.

102
00:05:18,430 --> 00:05:20,470
But what if you upgraded?

103
00:05:20,470 --> 00:05:22,840
And that's what I want to
kick off with right here.

104
00:05:22,840 --> 00:05:27,860
If you have a Mac that's older, so
maybe you've got Mac in the Leopard or

105
00:05:27,860 --> 00:05:31,270
Snow Leopard days, and
you're running the legacy file vault, and

106
00:05:31,270 --> 00:05:37,830
then you upgrade Yosemite.

107
00:05:37,830 --> 00:05:42,670
Well, you might still have legacy file
vault, and Yosemite does support it.

108
00:05:42,670 --> 00:05:46,690
It'll read it and access it, it just
won't let you create it on your own.

109
00:05:46,690 --> 00:05:48,530
All right, let me show you what I mean.

110
00:05:48,530 --> 00:05:52,270
So I have, right here,
a Yosemite machine, all right?

111
00:05:52,270 --> 00:05:55,710
And I upgraded this all
the way from Leopard,

112
00:05:55,710 --> 00:05:58,360
it was a lot of fun,
you guys should have seen it.

113
00:05:58,360 --> 00:06:00,700
But it's been upgraded all
the way from Snow Leopard.

114
00:06:00,700 --> 00:06:04,760
So, I've got my Snow Leopard background,
but if I go up here to About This Mac,

115
00:06:04,760 --> 00:06:08,221
you can see that I am running
10.10.2 Yosemite, right?

116
00:06:08,221 --> 00:06:09,210
So I'm up to date.

117
00:06:10,210 --> 00:06:11,880
And here I am, right.

118
00:06:11,880 --> 00:06:16,810
Well, back under Snow Leopard,
I turned on legacy File Vault, right,

119
00:06:16,810 --> 00:06:18,730
so I encrypted my home directory.

120
00:06:18,730 --> 00:06:21,440
I'm logged in as Don Poset and

00:06:21,440 --> 00:06:24,550
The whole drive is not encrypted,
just my home directory.

00:06:26,070 --> 00:06:29,740
And when I upgrade,
Yosemite was fine with that.

00:06:29,740 --> 00:06:31,470
It left it there.

124
00:06:31,470 --> 00:06:37,000
When I go into system preferences,
and I go to security and

125
00:06:37,000 --> 00:06:41,970
privacy right here, notice my tabs

126
00:06:41,970 --> 00:06:42,500
I've got, oops!

127
00:06:42,500 --> 00:06:43,850
Let's get that out of the way.

128
00:06:43,850 --> 00:06:49,910
I've got general, FileVault, legacy

00:06:49,910 --> 00:06:51,660
So I've got two FileVault tabs.

130
00:06:51,660 --> 00:06:55,450
And that's file vault version two and

131
00:06:56,490 --> 00:06:59,530
Versus if I look at a machine that wasn't

My actual laptop right here that

three pass security erase.

814
00:41:16,210 --> 00:41:19,950
So that is one that's been,
been approved by the DOE and

815
00:41:19,950 --> 00:41:22,300
it, it means their kind of requirements.

816
00:41:22,300 --> 00:41:22,930
Right?

817
00:41:22,930 --> 00:41:25,178
So you can see where you
can go even further.

818
00:41:26,760 --> 00:41:28,636
Right here to DoD.

819
00:41:28,636 --> 00:41:31,610
In the United States,
DoD is the Department of Defense.

820
00:41:31,610 --> 00:41:34,400
And Department of Defense,
that's our military, right?

821
00:41:34,400 --> 00:41:38,450
These are the people who hold sensitive
data for our government and our country.

822
00:41:38,450 --> 00:41:41,700
And for them,
a seven pass wipe is good enough to meet

823
00:41:41,700 --> 00:41:47,120
DoD 5220-22m standard to clear the data,
right?

824
00:41:47,120 --> 00:41:52,820
So if you do it this way now it

825
00:41:52,820 --> 00:41:56,730
Now the stronger you make this,

826
00:41:56,730 --> 00:42:01,190
But the longer it takes,
this could take a long time.

00:42:01,190 --> 00:42:01,910
The other thing is,

00:42:06,260 --> 00:42:10,150

journal partition.

00:42:28,750 --> 00:42:33,470
If the volume is supported by Mac OS,

00:42:35,910 --> 00:42:39,180
The button was there before,

But when I choose the volume it lights up

00:42:45,070 --> 00:42:47,900
I'm just erasing the empty space.

00:42:47,900 --> 00:42:52,010
And I can choose to do fastest or
I can do a three pass or

00:42:52,010 --> 00:42:53,900
I can do a seven pass, all right.

00:42:53,900 --> 00:42:56,030
The fastest, this one.

00:42:56,030 --> 00:43:00,080
Notice I've only got the three steps here,

00:43:00,080 --> 00:43:01,800
Three step and seven step.

00:43:01,800 --> 00:43:03,850
The fast one here is actually one.

00:43:03,850 --> 00:43:06,090
So one step, one set of zeros.

00:43:06,090 --> 00:43:08,590
When I did the drive, when I go to erase.

00:43:08,590 --> 00:43:09,290
Whoop, wait, shoot.

That's not what I wanted.

When I go to Security Options,

00:43:14,010 --> 00:43:19,580
Well this one, the second step, that's one

853
00:43:19,580 --> 00:43:23,430
Fastest on this screen
doesn't actually write zeros.

854
00:43:23,430 --> 00:43:25,590
It just flags the data as deleted.

855
00:43:25,590 --> 00:43:27,520
So it doesn't even bother writing zeros.

856
00:43:27,520 --> 00:43:30,680
But Apple figured if you're gonna go
through the trouble to erase free space,

857
00:43:30,680 --> 00:43:32,720

write one set of zeros.

858
00:43:32,720 --> 00:43:36,130
So we don't have that first option

859
00:43:36,130 --> 00:43:38,980
If it's free space,

00:43:38,980 --> 00:43:40,470
otherwise it wouldn't be free space,

00:43:40,470 --> 00:43:43,140
So that's why we don't

00:43:43,140 --> 00:43:45,810

00:43:45,810 --> 00:43:48,730

00:43:51,710 --> 00:43:53,970
Three passes will take

00:43:53,970 --> 00:43:56,090

00:43:56,090 --> 00:43:58,440
So, it gets longer and longer.

would be 230 some odd gigs of space It's

872
00:44:12,845 --> 00:44:13,450
That's gonna take awhile.

00:44:13,450 --> 00:44:14,650
I'm gonna go ahead and do it.

00:44:14,650 --> 00:44:16,012
I'll hit Erase Free Space.

00:44:16,012 --> 00:44:18,010
And it's gonna start doing that,

876
00:44:18,010 --> 00:44:20,460
See how down here it says

877
00:44:20,460 --> 00:44:21,810
That's writing a zero.

878
00:44:21,810 --> 00:44:24,290
It's writing a zero across all that space.

879
00:44:24,290 --> 00:44:26,800
And it's telling me it's gonna
take less than a minute.

880
00:44:26,800 --> 00:44:27,850
Well that's good.

881
00:44:27,850 --> 00:44:29,380
Less than a minute, that's not bad.

882
00:44:29,380 --> 00:44:32,630
But if you have a three terabyte
drive with a ton of free space,

883
00:44:32,630 --> 00:44:33,980
this can take hours.

884
00:44:33,980 --> 00:44:37,230
It can take a long time
to clear that data out.

885
00:44:37,230 --> 00:44:41,310
In my case it's this USB 2.0 drive,
it's reaching over to it and wiping it.

886
00:44:41,310 --> 00:44:42,250
And it's going to take about a minute.

887
00:44:43,882 --> 00:44:48,624
All right, now, the cool part here is If
your drive is encrypted with File Vault,

888
00:44:48,624 --> 00:44:52,341
this free space that's containing
data that's unencrypted,

889
00:44:52,341 --> 00:44:53,886
this is going to erase it.

890
00:44:53,886 --> 00:44:55,490
Right, this is gonna wipe it out.

891
00:44:55,490 --> 00:44:58,140
And as you put new data in there,
that new data will be encrypted and

892
00:44:58,140 --> 00:45:02,150
it will be protected, but
your old data will be removed.

00:45:02,150 --> 00:45:04,180
So this gives you that safety.

894
00:45:04,180 --> 00:45:06,920
If you've been using Your Mac.

00:45:06,920 --> 00:45:10,410
If you've actually got data already
on it you turn on File Vault.

896
00:45:10,410 --> 00:45:14,110
Your existing data is safe,
your deleted data is not.

897
00:45:14,110 --> 00:45:16,700
So your next step would be to come and
do this.

898
00:45:16,700 --> 00:45:17,290
All right.

00:45:17,290 --> 00:45:19,020

00:45:19,020 --> 00:45:23,490

00:45:23,490 --> 00:45:26,870
it's traditional SATA, but
if I come up and I choose, oh, shoot.

00:45:26,870 --> 00:45:27,950
It's gonna make me wait.

00:45:27,950 --> 00:45:31,810

what would happen if I

00:45:31,810 --> 00:45:35,660

00:45:44,210 --> 00:45:45,550

00:46:03,775 --> 00:46:06,695

00:46:06,695 --> 00:46:12,525
It's again not supported on the SSD,

00:46:15,690 --> 00:46:17,200

00:46:20,480 --> 00:46:22,920
So there's certain types of
storage where you won't see that.

00:46:22,920 --> 00:46:26,845
But on your magnetic storage, you will,

00:46:28,095 --> 00:46:32,540
All right, there's one other

00:46:32,540 --> 00:46:36,510
This is tackling all of our free space,

00:46:36,510 --> 00:46:40,320
Well if you're aware of this,
if you know that deleting a file doesn't

that it leaves some remnants behind.

00:46:43,420 --> 00:46:49,100
You might want to ensure that this

00:46:49,100 --> 00:46:52,790
Well the problem really rises

00:46:52,790 --> 00:46:55,920
when I delete a file

00:46:55,920 --> 00:46:58,240
Well, let me show you what I mean here.

00:46:58,240 --> 00:47:04,080
So if I go to my USB drive, and

00:47:05,900 --> 00:47:06,400
So it's in the trash.

If I go and empty my trash right now.

If I go and empty my trash right now,

00:47:15,980 --> 00:47:18,720
But the magnetic signature
will still be there, and

00:47:18,720 --> 00:47:21,310
somebody could recover the file, right?

00:47:21,310 --> 00:47:26,740
Well I could choose to do a secure

00:47:26,740 --> 00:47:28,460
A lot of people don't
know about this option.

00:47:28,460 --> 00:47:31,910
When you're in your trash like this,

00:47:31,910 --> 00:47:37,340
under Finder you've got Empty Trash,
and Secure Empty Trash.

944
00:47:37,340 --> 00:47:39,850
You don't actually have to be
in the trash to get there.

945
00:47:39,850 --> 00:47:42,040
I can just be right here on my
main screen and go to Finder and

946
00:47:42,040 --> 00:47:43,580
you've got Secure Empty Trash.

947
00:47:43,580 --> 00:47:48,084
And what that's gonna do is it's gonna
delete the items in the trash bin and

948
00:47:48,084 --> 00:47:52,170
it's gonna write zeroes to
the sectors where they were stored

949
00:47:52,170 --> 00:47:53,640
to give you that security.

950
00:47:53,640 --> 00:47:58,070
So I can choose Secure Empty Trash,
and here it goes giving me a warning.

951
00:47:58,070 --> 00:48:02,208
I can choose to do it, and now it's
gonna securely delete those files.

952
00:48:02,208 --> 00:48:04,625
Instead of doing all of my free space,

953
00:48:04,625 --> 00:48:07,501
here it's just doing it
as I delete the data.

954
00:48:07,501 --> 00:48:11,970
So if you make a habit of this, every
time I empty the trash do a secure empty.

00:48:11,970 --> 00:48:16,201
Well, at that point you really wouldn't
need to scrub all your free space because

00:48:16,201 --> 00:48:18,980

00:48:18,980 --> 00:48:21,310

00:48:21,310 --> 00:48:25,380

seven passes, it just does one pass.

00:48:25,380 --> 00:48:29,600
If that one pass isn't enough,

00:48:31,760 --> 00:48:33,530
So, there's that.

00:48:38,560 --> 00:48:41,380

Turn on FileVault, purge the free space.

00:48:58,020 --> 00:48:59,560

else has a valid account on your system.

1377
01:13:09,210 --> 01:13:11,020
They could login and get at it.

1378
01:13:11,020 --> 01:13:14,470
If you enable the guest account,
guest can get into your system.

1379
01:13:14,470 --> 01:13:16,280
Guest is part of the everyone group,

1380
01:13:16,280 --> 01:13:18,940
which means they'd be able to

1381
01:13:18,940 --> 01:13:22,270
So definitely something

01:13:22,270 --> 01:13:28,710
I'm trying to find real quick, somewhere

01:13:28,710 --> 01:13:37,430

01:13:37,430 --> 01:13:38,820
All right.

01:13:38,820 --> 01:13:39,570

01:13:45,300 --> 01:13:46,920

01:13:46,920 --> 01:13:51,270
So I'm connecting to an SSH host, and

01:13:51,270 --> 01:13:54,870

01:13:54,870 --> 01:13:55,700

01:14:00,650 --> 01:14:03,210

01:14:07,280 --> 01:14:10,850
But nobody else has access,

01:14:10,850 --> 01:14:14,740
So when I change into that folder,

01:14:14,740 --> 01:14:17,930

01:14:17,930 --> 01:14:22,260

01:16:19,190 --> 01:16:20,540

01:16:28,100 --> 01:16:33,220

01:16:33,220 --> 01:16:36,470

01:16:36,470 --> 01:16:38,700
They run as your user and

1445
01:16:42,750 --> 01:16:45,730
Versus applications that run out

1446
01:16:45,730 --> 01:16:47,490
they may have access to the whole system.

1447
01:16:47,490 --> 01:16:50,840
To a lot of administrative activities,
these applications will not.

1448
01:16:50,840 --> 01:16:53,830
So it's like a special
protected applications folder.

1449
01:16:53,830 --> 01:16:58,747

1450
01:16:58,747 --> 01:17:02,963

now's the time for me to do that.

15
00:01:14,760 --> 00:01:17,460
Let's talk about this sticky bit and
what it is.

16
00:01:17,460 --> 00:01:21,930
When you do a default install
of Mac OS Yosemite, when you

17
00:01:21,930 --> 00:01:26,520
put that default install in, there's
a folder that's created called Shared, and

18
00:01:26,520 --> 00:01:29,900
that Shared folder is
designed to be shared,

19
00:01:29,900 --> 00:01:34,810
thus the name, amongst all
the local users on your computer.

20
00:01:34,810 --> 00:01:39,040

00:01:39,040 --> 00:01:39,810

I've got three different user

23
00:01:42,155 --> 00:01:47,320
Well, all three accounts have
access to that Shared folder, and

24
00:01:47,320 --> 00:01:49,970
all three accounts can
write data to that folder.

25
00:01:49,970 --> 00:01:52,620
The idea is that if I want to share
something with another user, and

26
00:01:52,620 --> 00:01:53,980
I'm not worried about it being secret,

27
00:01:53,980 --> 00:01:59,100
then I can put it in that Shared folder
and we can all have access to it.

28
00:01:59,100 --> 00:02:03,300
But the Shared folder has
a really special property to it.

29
00:02:03,300 --> 00:02:06,324
Cuz so far, it doesn't really sound any
different than the public folder that we

30
00:02:06,324 --> 00:02:08,370
have in our user profile, does it?

31
00:02:08,370 --> 00:02:13,740
What it has that's different is,
if I put a file in the Shared folder,

32
00:02:13,740 --> 00:02:18,710
the other users can see it,
but they can't delete it.

33
00:02:18,710 --> 00:02:20,750
Deleting is blocked.

34
00:02:20,750 --> 00:02:23,270
Only the owner of the file
is able to delete.

35
00:02:23,270 --> 00:02:26,350
And that means that more than
one person can store stuff

36
00:02:26,350 --> 00:02:30,990
safely in the shared folder without having
to worry about other users deleting it.

37
00:02:30,990 --> 00:02:33,920
Now, when we looked at
the permissions the other day,

38
00:02:33,920 --> 00:02:37,340
we saw where there were read and
write and execute.

39
00:02:37,340 --> 00:02:40,280
There really wasn't a permission for

00:02:40,280 --> 00:02:43,620
Right, deleting is technically
a type of writing, but

41
00:02:43,620 --> 00:02:46,650
it is different cuz you're
actually removing the file.

42
00:02:46,650 --> 00:02:50,080
Well, it's the sticky
bit that controls that.

43
00:02:50,080 --> 00:02:53,480
The sticky bit is a special type of
permission that can be assigned to

44
00:02:53,480 --> 00:02:57,030
the everyone group that says,
if you create a file,

45
00:02:57,030 --> 00:02:59,790
the file is now stuck to you.

46
00:02:59,790 --> 00:03:01,510
You're the owner, you made it.

47
00:03:01,510 --> 00:03:05,150
You're allowed to delete it, but
nobody else is allowed to delete it.

48
00:03:05,150 --> 00:03:09,150
The file is stuck right where it is,
unless the owner or

49
00:03:09,150 --> 00:03:11,230
an administrator removes it.

50
00:03:11,230 --> 00:03:15,680
Other people can see it, other people can
work with it, but they can't delete it

51
00:03:15,680 --> 00:03:18,950
because it's stuck to the original owner,
that's why they call it a sticky bit.

52
00:03:18,950 --> 00:03:20,440
And it's a bit.

53
00:03:20,440 --> 00:03:22,900
Our permissions are all stored
in little bit values, and

54
00:03:22,900 --> 00:03:27,660
this replaces the last bit
of the everyone permissions.

55
00:03:27,660 --> 00:03:31,150
Remember the everyone permissions
are represented in three values,

56
00:03:31,150 --> 00:03:32,880
read, write, and execute.

57
00:03:32,880 --> 00:03:36,660
The sticky bit actually
replaces the execute bit.

58
00:03:36,660 --> 00:03:39,220
Now, me just talking about
it is a little confusing, so

59
00:03:39,220 --> 00:03:40,900

00:03:40,900 --> 00:03:44,760
I've got a computer fired up here, and

00:03:44,760 --> 00:03:49,070
I'll jump over to old JaneDoe here and
just get logged in.

62
00:03:50,360 --> 00:03:53,690
And for Jane, she's just a regular user,
not an administrator or

63
00:03:53,690 --> 00:03:57,340
anything like that, and
she's logged in on this computer.

64
00:03:57,340 --> 00:04:02,230
And if she browses to
the computer's root folder, right?

65
00:04:02,230 --> 00:04:08,270
So if I jump to my root of the drive,
she'll see various folders in here,

66
00:04:08,270 --> 00:04:11,560
Applications, Library, System,
Users, stuff like that.

67
00:04:11,560 --> 00:04:14,930
If she takes a look at her Documents,
her Downloads,

68
00:04:14,930 --> 00:04:19,150
these are all things she has access
to that are available to her.

69
00:04:19,150 --> 00:04:21,160
Right, they're just available to her.

70
00:04:21,160 --> 00:04:24,980
But, if she goes back
to that root folder and

71
00:04:24,980 --> 00:04:30,110
goes into Users,
there's a folder in here called Shared.

72
00:04:30,110 --> 00:04:31,380
Now, I don't have a user called Shared.

73
00:04:31,380 --> 00:04:33,800
There just happens to be
a folder called Shared.

74
00:04:33,800 --> 00:04:36,120
There's John Doe and Don Pezet.

75
00:04:36,120 --> 00:04:40,230
If she goes into my folder,
she doesn't have access to all my stuff.

76
00:04:40,230 --> 00:04:42,670
She has access to a couple of
the folders that we've made, but

77
00:04:42,670 --> 00:04:44,830
she doesn't have access
to my main folders.

78
00:04:44,830 --> 00:04:49,760
But if she goes into Shared,
it's empty, all right?

79
00:04:49,760 --> 00:04:52,140
She can jump in here and
start to create things.

80
00:04:52,140 --> 00:04:54,150
She can create files and
throw them in there.

81
00:04:54,150 --> 00:04:57,320
So for example,
if I just fire up a text document here.

00:04:59,390 --> 00:05:02,430
So, here's my document, and
I'll go ahead and save that.

00:05:03,600 --> 00:05:06,670
And I'm gonna save that

Actually, you know what?

85
00:05:08,840 --> 00:05:11,690
Here, let me just save it to my desktop

00:05:11,690 --> 00:05:19,121
So this is going to be my JaneDoe.txt or
rtf, get my extension right.

87
00:05:22,754 --> 00:05:25,883
All right, so there's that document and
I'm just gonna drag that and

00:05:25,883 --> 00:05:27,600
drop it right into there.

89
00:05:27,600 --> 00:05:32,098
And so now, that file is right
here inside of Shared, all right?

90
00:05:32,098 --> 00:05:36,030
She had access to be able to
write data into that folder,

91
00:05:36,030 --> 00:05:39,430
that Shared folder,
inside of the Users folder.

92
00:05:39,430 --> 00:05:43,732
If I switch over to John Doe now, so I'll

00:05:43,732 --> 00:05:49,880
All right, and once I'm in there as him,

00:05:49,880 --> 00:05:56,485
I navigate to that root folder, and

00:05:56,485 --> 00:06:01,360

You don't have permission to write to it.

Jane created it.

So it's able to track that.
