00:30:13,350 --> 00:30:19,320
If you don't have a directory service
though, then that doesn't work, and so

567
00:30:19,320 --> 00:30:24,940
by default Apple does not
track ownership on USB keys,

568
00:30:24,940 --> 00:30:27,160
all right, on removable media in general.

569
00:30:27,160 --> 00:30:31,240
In fact, they don't even track
it on secondary hard drives.

570
00:30:31,240 --> 00:30:33,465
If you add a second internal hard drive.

571
00:30:33,465 --> 00:30:34,955
Like if you have a Mac Pro, and

572
00:30:34,955 --> 00:30:39,765
you add a second hard drive to it, it
won't track ownership on those, all right?

573
00:30:39,765 --> 00:30:42,615
And it's doing it because of that risk.

574
00:30:42,615 --> 00:30:46,505
If you move it to another system, it's not
gonna know who the owner is anyway, and

575
00:30:46,505 --> 00:30:47,865
inappropriate access might be given out.

576
00:30:47,865 --> 00:30:51,735
So instead it treats them
as public shared disks.

577
00:30:51,735 --> 00:30:56,480
So when you're dealing with a USB key,
understand that it's not secure.

578
00:30:56,480 --> 00:30:57,830
Let me show you what I mean.

579
00:30:57,830 --> 00:30:59,240
I'm going to take this USB key here.

580
00:30:59,240 --> 00:31:02,880
This is one that I got for
free from my bank.

581
00:31:02,880 --> 00:31:08,130
You know, it's funny, a lot of companies
these days are trying to stay edgy and

582
00:31:08,130 --> 00:31:10,300
hip and so
they give you things like USB keys.

583
00:31:10,300 --> 00:31:16,310
But then you look at it and it's 500 megs
and you can't store one photo on it.

584
00:31:16,310 --> 00:31:17,470
But I just do it on here.

585
00:31:17,470 --> 00:31:21,100
I'm going to format this thing just to
make sure that we're looking at the honest

586
00:31:21,100 --> 00:31:22,610
default MAC view.

587
00:31:22,610 --> 00:31:27,890
So I'm going to take this USB stick and
I'm just going to, we'll erase the thing.

588
00:31:27,890 --> 00:31:32,370
We'll do MAC OS extended journaled and
we'll erase that one.

589
00:31:34,400 --> 00:31:35,110
All right.

590
00:31:35,110 --> 00:31:38,730
So I've got a brand new
formatted USB key here,

591
00:31:38,730 --> 00:31:43,210
just straight from the factory,
and oh, that's not good.

592
00:31:43,210 --> 00:31:44,510
Couldn't unmount the disk.

593
00:31:44,510 --> 00:31:46,320
Well, isn't that a shame?

594
00:31:46,320 --> 00:31:47,710
Let's try that again.

595
00:31:51,860 --> 00:31:53,800
See, this is what I get for
using a free USB,

596
00:31:53,800 --> 00:31:57,015
I should have probably used one of my
nicer ones that I've got on my desk.

597
00:31:57,015 --> 00:31:59,919
We will try that one more time.

598
00:31:59,919 --> 00:32:00,974
There it goes.

599
00:32:00,974 --> 00:32:04,360
So it's gonna format it and so now I know
I'll have those default permissions.

600
00:32:05,720 --> 00:32:09,960
Now once that's thrown on there,
the data's there, right?

601
00:32:09,960 --> 00:32:13,591
It's formatting which is apparently
taking forever, what is this USB 1.1?

602
00:32:13,591 --> 00:32:16,423
I'm gonna end up regretting
using this disk.

603
00:32:16,423 --> 00:32:18,530
But, [LAUGH] there it goes.

604
00:32:18,530 --> 00:32:22,430
Once it's done it's created,
the volume has been formatted, and

605
00:32:22,430 --> 00:32:24,000
permissions have been set on it.

606
00:32:24,000 --> 00:32:30,100
If I start to create things, like here,
let me just create a quick file.

607
00:32:32,180 --> 00:32:36,470
So, I will just create
this is a quick file,

608
00:32:37,980 --> 00:32:41,380
and I'm going to save that
over onto my USB key.

609
00:32:43,870 --> 00:32:48,490
All right, so this is gonna be
Quick File.rtf, and we'll save that.

610
00:32:48,490 --> 00:32:51,470
All right, so now I've got this quick
little file that I save on there,

611
00:32:51,470 --> 00:32:54,220
let's take a look at what
the permissions end up.

612
00:32:54,220 --> 00:32:59,690
If I open up that USB stick,
I can see Quick File right there,

613
00:32:59,690 --> 00:33:04,320
and if I pull up its information
I can look at its output, and

614
00:33:04,320 --> 00:33:06,520
let me just shrink some
of this stuff down.

615
00:33:06,520 --> 00:33:08,530
It's expanded everything.

616
00:33:08,530 --> 00:33:12,550
And if I get in the permissions I can see
Deep Pezet, me, I can read and write.

617
00:33:12,550 --> 00:33:15,530
I can see staff is read only,
everyone is read only.

618
00:33:15,530 --> 00:33:18,310
Permissions are set just like they
would be on my normal hard drive.

619
00:33:18,310 --> 00:33:21,000
That's what we normally expect.

620
00:33:21,000 --> 00:33:23,810
So that doesn't look any different but

621
00:33:23,810 --> 00:33:28,660
what it's not showing us here is that
it's not actually tracking that owner.

622
00:33:28,660 --> 00:33:32,590
And if I were to pull up the information
for the USB drive itself,

623
00:33:32,590 --> 00:33:35,340
I would see something interesting.

624
00:33:35,340 --> 00:33:38,774
When I pull up the USB drive itself,
I see Deep Pezet has read and write,

625
00:33:38,774 --> 00:33:41,420
staff has read and write,
everyone else is read only.

626
00:33:41,420 --> 00:33:43,450
I see those default permissions.

627
00:33:43,450 --> 00:33:47,210
But notice in gray text on
the gray background this

628
00:33:47,210 --> 00:33:49,330
little information right here,
you can barely see it.

629
00:33:49,330 --> 00:33:53,970
It says, ignore ownership on this volume,
all right.

630
00:33:53,970 --> 00:33:57,950
And what that means is that
Mac OS knows there's an owner,

631
00:33:57,950 --> 00:33:59,900
there is an owner set, it's me, Don Pezet.

632
00:33:59,900 --> 00:34:03,760
I'm the one who formatted it,
but It's gonna ignore that.

633
00:34:03,760 --> 00:34:08,260
It's gonna ignore that and
treat everybody as the owner.

634
00:34:08,260 --> 00:34:11,650
Everybody can go in here and override
permissions and take over this disk,

635
00:34:11,650 --> 00:34:14,220
or format it, or do whatever it is
that they wanna do with that disc.

636
00:34:14,220 --> 00:34:15,260
Because it's removable,

637
00:34:15,260 --> 00:34:19,560
because it can't verify that you
are actually the owner, right.

638
00:34:20,660 --> 00:34:23,910
If you're only going to be using this disk

639
00:34:24,950 --> 00:34:28,680
inside of a directory environment where
you know that you'll have that same owner

640
00:34:28,680 --> 00:34:32,050
across all the different computers,
you can turn that option off.

641
00:34:32,050 --> 00:34:35,550
And then it will respect the owner flag,
but

642
00:34:35,550 --> 00:34:37,740
it'll only respect the owner
flag on your computers.

643
00:34:37,740 --> 00:34:40,290
If somebody were steal that USB key and

644
00:34:40,290 --> 00:34:43,040
plug it into their own computer
that's not on the directory.

645
00:34:43,040 --> 00:34:47,150
Well, that's going to
basically ignore ownership,

646
00:34:47,150 --> 00:34:48,820
that's their option they've set.

647
00:34:48,820 --> 00:34:50,760
So, it's not something we can rely on.

648
00:34:50,760 --> 00:34:52,690
And that is on by default.

649
00:34:52,690 --> 00:34:55,900
I didn't turn that on, you guys saw me
format that right here during the show.

650
00:34:55,900 --> 00:34:58,150
It did it and it set that option.

651
00:34:58,150 --> 00:35:01,350
And if we wanna turn it off, you have to
unlock, you have to be an administrator.

652
00:35:01,350 --> 00:35:05,630
So I'll unlock that, and
now I can turn that option off.

653
00:35:05,630 --> 00:35:07,350
And now the owner's going to be respected.

654
00:35:07,350 --> 00:35:08,840
And see what it just did?

655
00:35:08,840 --> 00:35:12,780
It says I can only read because
the owner just became system.

656
00:35:12,780 --> 00:35:16,390
Now the system owns that
disk because that's what was

657
00:35:16,390 --> 00:35:18,910
actually happening in
the background before.

658
00:35:18,910 --> 00:35:22,910
Sure, it was lying to me and
telling me that I was the owner.

659
00:35:22,910 --> 00:35:24,250
But I really wasn't.

660
00:35:24,250 --> 00:35:26,160
In the background it was
the system that was the owner.

661
00:35:26,160 --> 00:35:27,960
And when I turned that option off,
I can see that.

662
00:35:27,960 --> 00:35:30,500
I can see that I wasn't
actually the owner.

663
00:35:30,500 --> 00:35:32,680
And so
now I'll have to seize control of that.

664
00:35:32,680 --> 00:35:34,360
I'll have to use C-H-O-W-N.

665
00:35:34,360 --> 00:35:38,040
The change owner command to
seize ownership of that disk,

666
00:35:38,040 --> 00:35:40,480
assign it back to me, and
go and set those permissions.

667
00:35:41,480 --> 00:35:45,340
Be very aware of that, because what
it basically boils down to is you

668
00:35:45,340 --> 00:35:48,810
cannot trust permissions
on removable media.

669
00:35:48,810 --> 00:35:51,930
That is not a way to
secure removable media.

670
00:35:51,930 --> 00:35:55,950
If you want to secure your removable
media, it's gonna need to be encrypted or

671
00:35:55,950 --> 00:35:58,290
secured through some other mechanism.

672
00:35:58,290 --> 00:36:01,280
You can't trust file permissions for that.

673
00:36:01,280 --> 00:36:04,800
And in this case,
it's Mac OS extended journal.

674
00:36:04,800 --> 00:36:07,350
I have it formatted that way so
I have full support for permissions and

675
00:36:07,350 --> 00:36:08,360
things like that.

676
00:36:08,360 --> 00:36:12,320
If I had formatted it with
a different file system, like,

677
00:36:12,320 --> 00:36:17,670
if I take that USB stick and
format it, let's go exFAT, oops.

678
00:36:17,670 --> 00:36:18,420
Here we go.

679
00:36:18,420 --> 00:36:19,950
So I'm gonna format it exFAT.

680
00:36:19,950 --> 00:36:22,880
ExFAT's a great file system cuz we
can move in between Windows and

681
00:36:22,880 --> 00:36:24,040
MAC really easy.

682
00:36:24,040 --> 00:36:25,900
It's compatible with all of them.

683
00:36:25,900 --> 00:36:27,660
So if I go ahead and do that.

684
00:36:29,110 --> 00:36:31,770
We'll just give it a quick
format over to that.

685
00:36:31,770 --> 00:36:35,250
ExFAT doesn't support file permissions.

686
00:36:35,250 --> 00:36:38,470
So now, if I start copying data into it,

687
00:36:38,470 --> 00:36:41,310
there's not gonna be any
permissions on it at all, right?

688
00:36:41,310 --> 00:36:43,650
And so that's got its own little issues.

689
00:36:45,820 --> 00:36:48,340
So if I fire up text edit and
create another document,

690
00:36:50,850 --> 00:36:54,580
a smarter me would've saved
the other one somewhere else, but

691
00:36:54,580 --> 00:36:58,550
I'll go ahead and just save this one
right here out on the USB stick.

692
00:36:59,580 --> 00:37:00,790
I can use it just fine.

693
00:37:01,920 --> 00:37:04,890
But if I browse into the USB stick and
I take that document and

694
00:37:04,890 --> 00:37:09,660
I pull up its information, notice under
sharing and permission, it's empty.

695
00:37:09,660 --> 00:37:12,320
It just says you can read and
write and that's it.

696
00:37:12,320 --> 00:37:15,470
There's no permissions being
tracked on that file at all.

697
00:37:15,470 --> 00:37:19,868
And if I pull up the USB drive,
pull up its information.

698
00:37:19,868 --> 00:37:22,760
Under Sharing & Permission,
you can read and write.

699
00:37:22,760 --> 00:37:23,530
And that's it.

700
00:37:23,530 --> 00:37:25,470
No permissions tracked at all.

701
00:37:25,470 --> 00:37:27,940
If it's an NTFS drive, it's read-only.

702
00:37:27,940 --> 00:37:31,380
If it's exFAT, you can read and
write, but there's no permissions.

703
00:37:31,380 --> 00:37:36,280
Only with Mac OS journal do we actually
get the full permission set, and

704
00:37:36,280 --> 00:37:40,260
even that's not really functional when
you move from computer to computer.

705
00:37:40,260 --> 00:37:42,110
So real important stuff to be aware of.

706
00:37:42,110 --> 00:37:43,490
Just something to keep in mind.

707
00:37:43,490 --> 00:37:45,340
And it is something that
turns up on the exam.

708
00:37:47,040 --> 00:37:49,440
All right, so that's about it for
removable media.

709
00:37:49,440 --> 00:37:53,090
Was there anything else I
wanted to mention on there?

710
00:37:53,090 --> 00:37:54,420
No, I believe that's it.

711
00:37:54,420 --> 00:37:57,790
I know I called out in another show how
we have to be careful that when you

712
00:37:57,790 --> 00:38:02,680
add removable media to a system,
if you're using fast user switching,

713
00:38:02,680 --> 00:38:06,270
the other users that login would have
access to that removal media, too.

714
00:38:06,270 --> 00:38:10,020
And that all ties back to this
ignoring ownership thing.

715
00:38:10,020 --> 00:38:11,770
This is the cause of that problem.

716
00:38:11,770 --> 00:38:15,430
So if you watched an earlier show where
I talked about fast user switching,

717
00:38:15,430 --> 00:38:19,340
this is what caused that problem that I
was talking about in the other episode.

718
00:38:19,340 --> 00:38:21,140
So, it all kind of ties together.

719
00:38:21,140 --> 00:38:22,760
All links back to the original stuff.

720
00:38:24,142 --> 00:38:26,680
All right but that's about it for
file permission, so

721
00:38:26,680 --> 00:38:29,390
I think this is probably a good place for
us to stop.

Let me remind you guys,

if you have questions on any of this,

episodes.description: There are times when one might want to have a file in more than one place on a hard drive, but not want more than one copy of the file. Managing files are a good way to keep track of important information that could be buried beneath all the different files a system holds. Viewers will hear discussions on cloning or linking files, making an alias for a file, and managing metadata.
episodes.title: Managing Files Part 1
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,020 --> 00:00:10,020
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,380 --> 00:00:22,799
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,799 --> 00:00:32,280
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:32,280 --> 00:00:35,269
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

5
00:00:35,269 --> 00:00:39,250
welcome back to another episode of
ITProTV, I'm your host, Don Pezet.

6
00:00:39,250 --> 00:00:43,200
Back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

7
00:00:43,200 --> 00:00:45,150
We're gonna be diving
into a neat area today.

8
00:00:45,150 --> 00:00:47,280
We're gonna take a look at managing files.

9
00:00:47,280 --> 00:00:51,970
And no, I'm not gonna bore to death
with how to copy, cut, and paste.

10
00:00:51,970 --> 00:00:54,130
I think we all probably
have that by this point.

11
00:00:54,130 --> 00:00:57,680
But there's some neat functionality in the
background that Mac OS can do that allows

12
00:00:57,680 --> 00:00:59,840
us to handle files in a special way.

13
00:00:59,840 --> 00:01:01,760
And so we're gonna run through
some of those technologies.

14
00:01:01,760 --> 00:01:04,090
These are not just ones that
show up on the exam, but

15
00:01:04,090 --> 00:01:06,190
also ones that you'll use in real life,
all right?

16
00:01:07,280 --> 00:01:12,140
I wanna start off with cloning or
linking files, all right?

17
00:01:12,140 --> 00:01:15,970
There are times when you want to
have a file more than one place

18
00:01:15,970 --> 00:01:20,710
on your hard drive, but you don't want
to have more than one copy of the file.

19
00:01:20,710 --> 00:01:22,000
Let me give you an example.

20
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:25,720
So I like to keep all of my
documents nice and organized.

21
00:01:25,720 --> 00:01:28,880
So I have a folder structure that
all of my documents are in and

22
00:01:28,880 --> 00:01:32,040
everything is kind of placed
away deep down in these folders.

23
00:01:32,040 --> 00:01:34,370
Well the problem is if I need a file,

24
00:01:34,370 --> 00:01:37,080
I know exactly where it is
because of my structure.

25
00:01:37,080 --> 00:01:41,410
But I might have to browse five folders
deep to get to the file that I want and

26
00:01:41,410 --> 00:01:43,040
that can be a little frustrating.

27
00:01:43,040 --> 00:01:46,360
So if I've got a file that I
know I'm working with every day,

28
00:01:46,360 --> 00:01:49,160
I might want to have it right
there on my desktop, in MacOS,

29
00:01:49,160 --> 00:01:52,330
right where I can get to it immediately,
without having to navigate through all

30
00:01:52,330 --> 00:01:54,320
this deep folder structure
to get to where I'm going.

31
00:01:55,390 --> 00:01:57,480
Well, I could just copy the file, but

32
00:01:57,480 --> 00:02:01,260
the problem with copying a file
is that now I have two files.

33
00:02:01,260 --> 00:02:04,130
If you modify one,
the other doesn't get modified.

34
00:02:04,130 --> 00:02:06,630
Or if you modify the other one,
your link doesn't get modified, right?

35
00:02:06,630 --> 00:02:08,730
So it's two separate files.

36
00:02:08,730 --> 00:02:10,900
It's also taking up twice as much space,
right?

37
00:02:10,900 --> 00:02:12,260
You duplicated that file.

38
00:02:12,260 --> 00:02:14,060
So it's eating up twice
the hard drive space.

39
00:02:14,060 --> 00:02:16,320
So that's not necessarily
the greatest way to do it.

40
00:02:16,320 --> 00:02:20,330
Well, in Mac OS,
we can actually do what are called links.

41
00:02:20,330 --> 00:02:24,860
And a link is where you have what
looks like a copy of the file, but

42
00:02:24,860 --> 00:02:27,970
it's actually just a pointer
back to the original file.

43
00:02:27,970 --> 00:02:30,250
And there's a few
different ways to do links.

44
00:02:30,250 --> 00:02:32,700
There's actually three main
ways we can do links, and for

45
00:02:32,700 --> 00:02:36,080
the exam you need to be familiar
with all three, all right?

46
00:02:36,080 --> 00:02:39,600
Let's start with the one that
most people are familiar with but

47
00:02:39,600 --> 00:02:42,370
is also the one that Apple
doesn't want you to use.

48
00:02:42,370 --> 00:02:47,300
In Mac OS, for a long time, we've had
what's called the make alias feature.

49
00:02:47,300 --> 00:02:49,310
You can take any file and
you can make an alias of it.

50
00:02:49,310 --> 00:02:51,600
Let me show you what I mean.

51
00:02:51,600 --> 00:02:56,080
Let me just go to My Documents folder, and

52
00:02:56,080 --> 00:02:59,818
I've got a document in here,
this PDF, that I use all the time.

53
00:02:59,818 --> 00:03:04,430
It's a Cisco\g routing book and I
literally use this book almost every day.

54
00:03:04,430 --> 00:03:07,840
And I can right click on that and

00:14:41,250 --> 00:14:44,490

X FAT USB key here, then the metadata
is just as visible as the data itself.

748
00:39:23,770 --> 00:39:26,640
And there have been quite a few high
profile examples of that where companies

749
00:39:26,640 --> 00:39:31,290
let improper information leak out in
the metadata of a file accidentally.

750
00:39:31,290 --> 00:39:34,270
Fortunately, with Mac OS we really
just have like the comment flag,

751
00:39:34,270 --> 00:39:35,500
would be the real dangerous one.

752
00:39:35,500 --> 00:39:39,650
If you put comments in there, that you
didn't want people to see when you copy

753
00:39:39,650 --> 00:39:44,050
that file around, it'll drag that metadata
along with it and it can be visible.

754
00:39:44,050 --> 00:39:45,366
So, just keep that in mind.

755
00:39:45,366 --> 00:39:50,624
What we're looking at there is
the metadata associated with the extended

756
00:39:50,624 --> 00:39:55,393
attributes of a file as well as
that Appledouble metadata format.

757
00:39:55,393 --> 00:39:57,228
And that's the official name for
that too, so

758
00:39:57,228 --> 00:39:59,872
on the exam they'll write as
Appledouble all one word, no space.

759
00:39:59,872 --> 00:40:01,823
Apple Double metadata.

760
00:40:01,823 --> 00:40:03,147
That's that extra shadow file.

761
00:40:03,147 --> 00:40:07,090
There's one other type of metadata
they don't really call out in the exam

762
00:40:07,090 --> 00:40:07,860
objectives.

763
00:40:07,860 --> 00:40:12,700
But I want to mention when you store files
on your Mac when you throw them onto

764
00:40:12,700 --> 00:40:16,530
the file system for the most part
you just have a single file right?

765
00:40:16,530 --> 00:40:22,020
And so my br1.text file my routing bits
handbook.pdf those are just single files.

766
00:40:22,020 --> 00:40:23,770
And when I open them up
they've got data in them.

767
00:40:25,230 --> 00:40:28,530
But Apple supports what's
called a forked file system.

768
00:40:29,610 --> 00:40:32,340
If you've ever installed
a program in Microsoft Windows,

769
00:40:32,340 --> 00:40:36,810
you'll know that one application, one
program, might actually have hundreds or

770
00:40:36,810 --> 00:40:39,130
even thousands of files
that go along with it.

771
00:40:39,130 --> 00:40:44,030
All sorts of library files, and
executables, and just tons and

772
00:40:44,030 --> 00:40:45,170
tons of files.

773
00:40:45,170 --> 00:40:48,150
But it's not like that in Mac is it?

774
00:40:48,150 --> 00:40:51,130
In Mac OS when I install an application,
I just have one file.

775
00:40:51,130 --> 00:40:53,410
And I drag it and
I drop it in my applications folder and

776
00:40:53,410 --> 00:40:56,350
that's it, it's there, I'm done.

777
00:40:56,350 --> 00:40:57,660
It's easy and it just works.

778
00:40:57,660 --> 00:40:58,340
That's the mantra.

779
00:40:59,660 --> 00:41:03,670
The reality is, we actually do have
thousands of files that are there inside

780
00:41:03,670 --> 00:41:04,950
the Mac OS, we just don't see them.

781
00:41:04,950 --> 00:41:06,570
They are hidden from us.

782
00:41:06,570 --> 00:41:10,450
And that's because Mac OS, of course,
was called a forked file system.

783
00:41:10,450 --> 00:41:13,080
That one little icon
that you're dragging and

784
00:41:13,080 --> 00:41:16,800
dropping to that application,
it's actually what is called a bundle.

785
00:41:16,800 --> 00:41:21,480
And in that bundle are thousands of
files stored in their own private,

786
00:41:21,480 --> 00:41:23,060
little file system that's forked.

787
00:41:23,060 --> 00:41:24,800
Think about a fork in a road, right.

788
00:41:24,800 --> 00:41:27,790
So you've got your main hard drive,
and now you've got this spore, for

789
00:41:27,790 --> 00:41:31,780
the application that drifts off into
some other different direction.

790
00:41:31,780 --> 00:41:35,410
And inside of that application's
own little private file system

791
00:41:35,410 --> 00:41:38,000
are all the little files that it uses.

792
00:41:38,000 --> 00:41:40,110
Now, that is hidden from the end users,

793
00:41:40,110 --> 00:41:42,390
because the end users
don't care about that.

794
00:41:42,390 --> 00:41:44,890
The end users don't want to see all
of those files and know about it.

795
00:41:44,890 --> 00:41:49,190
They want to drag an application, drop it
in the applications folder, and be done.

796
00:41:50,540 --> 00:41:53,560
But it is there and
the reason why I bring it up

00:41:53,560 --> 00:41:58,810

00:41:58,810 --> 00:42:00,830
That doesn't apply for

But, for applications, they can store

00:42:07,850 --> 00:42:11,520

inside of one of those bundles.

802
00:42:11,520 --> 00:42:12,990
And you can see this stuff.

803
00:42:12,990 --> 00:42:13,810
It is hidden, right?

If I go into my hard drive, and

are special separate folders or whatever,

00:42:27,390 --> 00:42:30,390
I just see these icons and
that's basically it, right.

00:42:30,390 --> 00:42:32,875
Let's take, here,
we'll take my write application.

00:42:32,875 --> 00:42:33,995
This guy, all right.

So I've got right.

00:42:35,075 --> 00:42:36,355
I just see it as an icon.

00:42:36,355 --> 00:42:39,075
And if I want to use it,

00:42:39,075 --> 00:42:42,295
when I installed it I just dragged it and

00:42:42,295 --> 00:42:44,055
I might have installed that

00:42:44,055 --> 00:42:45,615
it doesn't matter either way, right?

So it's just there.

That's gonna take you from the normal

Show Package Contents,

If I were to open that up.

00:45:45,030 --> 00:45:48,240
All right, so that's another place

00:45:49,680 --> 00:45:53,840

You take the bundle, you drop it in your

00:46:04,090 --> 00:46:04,790

00:46:04,790 --> 00:46:07,420

A package or a PKG file, those package

00:46:16,400 --> 00:46:16,900
Right?

00:46:16,900 --> 00:46:18,500
Sometimes when you install an application,

887
00:46:18,500 --> 00:46:21,300
it needs to run some scripts or
change some permissions.

888
00:46:21,300 --> 00:46:24,100
It needs to do more actions
than just being copied over.

889
00:46:24,100 --> 00:46:26,500
You see this most commonly with drivers.

00:46:26,500 --> 00:46:29,780
So if you download a driver for
your Mac, maybe you have some printer or

00:46:29,780 --> 00:46:33,640

00:46:33,640 --> 00:46:36,410
An application ends in .app.

893
00:46:36,410 --> 00:46:38,180
A package and it's in .pkg.

894
00:46:38,180 --> 00:46:41,302
They're both bundles, they're just

895
00:46:41,302 --> 00:46:46,020
The .app files for an application, that
just runs the program, that's all it does.

896
00:46:46,020 --> 00:46:49,890

the package, when you run that bundle,

00:46:49,890 --> 00:46:53,860

00:59:27,012 --> 00:59:30,452

00:59:30,452 --> 00:59:34,540
could just right click and get it out

00:59:34,540 --> 00:59:37,750

00:59:40,620 --> 00:59:42,540

01:00:29,560 --> 01:00:31,770

I wanna make it easy to

of stuff including all those

01:02:51,120 --> 01:02:51,781
There's those fonts.

The exam objective is how to manage fonts,

So on the exam, you definitely

1216
01:03:33,200 --> 01:03:38,390
guys right here that you got,
/Users/Username/Library,

that's the first domain, called the user

1218
01:03:42,220 --> 01:03:46,070
Then you got /Library,
which is the local domain, and

1219
01:03:46,070 --> 01:03:47,310
that's the one that comes in second place.

1220
01:03:47,310 --> 01:03:49,266
Those are the global settings for
the computer.

1221
01:03:49,266 --> 01:03:53,474
Then you've got /Network/Library, that's
the network domain, comes in third place

1222
01:03:53,474 --> 01:03:57,029
and that's when there are settings

1223
01:03:57,029 --> 01:04:01,739
And then lastly, /System/Library,
those are the system domain and

1224
01:04:01,739 --> 01:04:06,050
that's the defaults from Apple,
those are in last place.

1225
01:04:06,050 --> 01:04:09,360
They'll take effect if nobody
else overrides them otherwise,

1226
01:04:09,360 --> 01:04:09,890
they get ignored.

1227
01:04:10,910 --> 01:04:11,600
All right.

1228
01:04:11,600 --> 01:04:12,890
So, those are the four domains.

1229
01:04:12,890 --> 01:04:15,890
That's why we have so many library

episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:05,329 --> 00:00:15,329
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:16,866 --> 00:00:22,590
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,590 --> 00:00:33,494
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,494 --> 00:00:36,090
Alright, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

5
00:00:36,090 --> 00:00:38,610
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,610 --> 00:00:39,390
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

7
00:00:40,760 --> 00:00:44,670
Back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

8
00:00:44,670 --> 00:00:49,330
In this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at file archives and images.

9
00:00:49,330 --> 00:00:52,850
And really, those are just fancy ways of
saying ways that we can bundle up our

10
00:00:52,850 --> 00:00:57,680
files together and make them easier to
move around, back up, and deal with.

11
00:00:57,680 --> 00:00:59,590
Let's start with file archives.

12
00:00:59,590 --> 00:01:03,240
When you have a large quantity of files
that you need to send to somebody via

13
00:01:03,240 --> 00:01:05,690
email, or shared folders or whatever.

14
00:01:05,690 --> 00:01:08,980
Sometimes it can be useful to
bundle them together into one file,

15
00:01:08,980 --> 00:01:11,790
instead of dealing with a bunch
of individual files, right?

16
00:01:11,790 --> 00:01:13,550
I don't know if you've
ever had this before,

17
00:01:13,550 --> 00:01:16,210
where you get an email from somebody
that says hey look at these pictures.

18
00:01:16,210 --> 00:01:19,250
And there's 50 pictures attached to
the email, all as separate attachments.

19
00:01:19,250 --> 00:01:22,322
And you're like great, now I gotta
download each of those attachments and

20
00:01:22,322 --> 00:01:22,918
deal with it.

21
00:01:22,918 --> 00:01:28,400
It's far easier if they're
compressed all into one file, right?

22
00:01:28,400 --> 00:01:32,390
Stored in one archive file,
I can just download that one file, and

23
00:01:32,390 --> 00:01:35,070
then extract all the individual
files from inside of it.

24
00:01:35,070 --> 00:01:38,810
Well, Mac OS has support for that
built right into the operating system.

25
00:01:38,810 --> 00:01:40,710
We don't even need third party software.

26
00:01:40,710 --> 00:01:46,160
You can combine, and then un-combine
files really, really easily.

27
00:01:46,160 --> 00:01:48,660
Mac OS uses the ZIP file format.

28
00:01:48,660 --> 00:01:51,920
And ZIP, it originated from
a company called PKWARE.

29
00:01:51,920 --> 00:01:54,870
They created this archive
format that did two things.

30
00:01:54,870 --> 00:01:57,460
One, it combined the files together.

31
00:01:57,460 --> 00:02:02,120
And two, it applied a compression
algorithm to try and make the files

32
00:02:02,120 --> 00:02:05,680
smaller than they were normally,
right, if they weren't compressed.

33
00:02:05,680 --> 00:02:07,840
And so
it's kind of neat that it does both.

34
00:02:07,840 --> 00:02:11,790
A smaller file will transmit over
a network easier, and then once it gets to

35
00:02:11,790 --> 00:02:14,860
the other side, they can extract it and
the files are back to their normal size.

36
00:02:14,860 --> 00:02:16,310
So pretty neat functionality, all right?

37
00:02:16,310 --> 00:02:19,870
Let me show you how it works
right here inside of Mac OS.

38
00:02:19,870 --> 00:02:24,470
So on my desktop I've got some router
configuration files from our Cisco show.

39
00:02:24,470 --> 00:02:27,580
And if I browse in there,
they're just a bunch of text files,

40
00:02:27,580 --> 00:02:28,422
I can see them right here.

41
00:02:28,422 --> 00:02:32,265
These are Different routers that I have,
and their config files, all right?

42
00:02:32,265 --> 00:02:37,135
If pull up my detailed list,
I can see they're all about 2 KB in size.

43
00:02:37,135 --> 00:02:39,415
The biggest one is 5 KB right there.

44
00:02:39,415 --> 00:02:41,635
So they're not terribly large files.

45
00:02:41,635 --> 00:02:45,085
But I don't wanna have to attach each
one to an email individually, or

46
00:02:45,085 --> 00:02:47,475
have somebody on the other side try and
download them that way.

47
00:02:47,475 --> 00:02:49,570
I wanna combine these Into one file.

48
00:02:50,730 --> 00:02:54,380
So to do that all you have to do
is highlight the files, right?

49
00:02:54,380 --> 00:02:56,920
So I've highlighted all of those files,
and

50
00:02:56,920 --> 00:03:00,110
then you can Ctrl+click or right-click.

51
00:03:00,110 --> 00:03:04,744
And you'll see the option in here
Compress 7 Items, all right?

52
00:03:04,744 --> 00:03:09,810
It's gonna say compress and then whatever
number of files you've selected, items.

53
00:03:09,810 --> 00:03:12,520
And that's gonna take those files and

54
00:03:12,520 --> 00:03:16,360
shrink them all into one file
that's compressed, all right?

55
00:03:16,360 --> 00:03:17,720
If I compress those seven items,

56
00:03:17,720 --> 00:03:21,220
it's gonna do it and
it's gonna create this file Archive.zip.

57
00:03:21,220 --> 00:03:25,210
Now, notice that Archive.zip
file is only 6 KB in size.

58
00:03:25,210 --> 00:03:29,100
Well, any three of my files
would have been 6 KB.

59
00:03:29,100 --> 00:03:31,140
What happened to all the rest of it,
right?

60
00:03:31,140 --> 00:03:33,660
There's over, well, I don't know,

61
00:03:33,660 --> 00:03:36,540
probably about 20k more data
right there that disappeared.

62
00:03:36,540 --> 00:03:40,630
Well it didn't disappear, all
the duplicates, all that other information

63
00:03:40,630 --> 00:03:43,670
is able to be extracted and
removed and the files are shrunk down.

64
00:03:43,670 --> 00:03:47,850
And at the other end, whoever receives
this will be able to extract the data and

65
00:03:47,850 --> 00:03:49,640
get it out of there, all right?

66
00:03:49,640 --> 00:03:50,740
Now there are many,

67
00:03:50,740 --> 00:03:54,720
many other file formats that
are out there other than just .ZIP.

68
00:03:54,720 --> 00:03:57,250
But Apple settled on .ZIP because almost

69
00:03:57,250 --> 00:03:59,510
every operating system
out there supports it.

70
00:03:59,510 --> 00:04:02,990
Most UNIX and Linux distributions
have ZIP support by default.

71
00:04:02,990 --> 00:04:06,250
All versions of Microsoft Windows
have ZIP support by default.

72
00:04:06,250 --> 00:04:09,780
iPhone and Android phones
have ZIP support by default.

73
00:04:09,780 --> 00:04:11,360
So it's pretty ubiquitous, right?

74
00:04:11,360 --> 00:04:13,870
A lot people have support for
it, and that's why we've got it.

75
00:04:13,870 --> 00:04:15,608
But there other formats
that are out there.

76
00:04:15,608 --> 00:04:21,420
Like the Tar GZip format or
TGZ, you'll see a lot of that.

77
00:04:21,420 --> 00:04:27,670
Unix system have TGZ support baked in, but
system's like Windows don't, all right?

78
00:04:27,670 --> 00:04:31,140
You might see RAR, or
7-Zip, or other formats.

79
00:04:31,140 --> 00:04:33,270
Those are great formats too.

80
00:04:33,270 --> 00:04:35,190
But not natively supported by the OS.

81
00:04:35,190 --> 00:04:39,485
So if you want a guarantee that the person
on the other end of this communication is

82
00:04:39,485 --> 00:04:42,070
gonna be able to open that file,
you stick with ZIP.

83
00:04:42,070 --> 00:04:43,940
And so that's why Apple chose that one.

84
00:04:43,940 --> 00:04:49,208
And that file, you can rename it, right?

85
00:04:49,208 --> 00:04:50,725
I might want to call it
Router Configs.zip, right, so

86
00:04:50,725 --> 00:04:52,160
that I know what it is.

87
00:04:52,160 --> 00:04:54,220
But at the end of the day,
my configuration files are in there,

88
00:04:54,220 --> 00:04:59,890
and if I delete my files, so I'll just
throw those down there in my trash.

89
00:04:59,890 --> 00:05:01,950
So they're gone,
I'm just left with my configs.

90
00:05:01,950 --> 00:05:05,020
If I wanna get the files
out of there again,

91
00:05:05,020 --> 00:05:06,510
I can always just right-click on that.

92
00:05:06,510 --> 00:05:10,170
And you'll see the option
in here to extract,

93
00:05:10,170 --> 00:05:13,460
and actually it doesn't show up does it?

94
00:05:13,460 --> 00:05:16,440
I use a slightly different
program called Entropy so

95
00:05:16,440 --> 00:05:17,890
I have my option way down there.

96
00:05:17,890 --> 00:05:19,810
But in our user interface,
we can just double-click on it and

97
00:05:19,810 --> 00:05:21,420
that will extract it also.

98
00:05:21,420 --> 00:05:24,350
I forgot, I've got this third
party software installed

99
00:05:24,350 --> 00:05:26,500
that's kind of getting in the way of this.

100
00:05:26,500 --> 00:05:27,920
Normally with Mac OS,

101
00:05:27,920 --> 00:05:31,040
if you were to just double-click on that,
it would extract out.

102
00:05:31,040 --> 00:05:34,580
But since I've got this Entropy software
installed, when I double-click on it,

103
00:05:34,580 --> 00:05:36,060
it's gonna fire up in Entropy.

104
00:05:36,060 --> 00:05:40,860
So let me just change that real quick so

00:24:02,210 --> 00:24:04,000

00:02:56,760 --> 00:03:01,020

00:03:01,020 --> 00:03:04,460

00:03:15,640 --> 00:03:17,450

External media like this is

$300, if you actually had a failure,

00:46:38,630 --> 00:46:41,420
If you ever want to see it,
it's hidden by default.

930
00:46:41,420 --> 00:46:43,610
You can't see it here inside of Mac OS.

931
00:46:43,610 --> 00:46:48,430
And I usually disable it on my system cuz
I, I eat up hard drive space like crazy.

932
00:46:48,430 --> 00:46:51,300
The local backup that it makes,
is made right here on your desk so

933
00:46:51,300 --> 00:46:52,630
it does eat up some space.

934
00:46:52,630 --> 00:46:55,420
So you might wanna disable it too,
I usually do.

935
00:46:55,420 --> 00:46:57,850
But, it is a nice feature to have.

936
00:46:57,850 --> 00:47:00,530
If you want to see it in terminal,

937
00:47:00,530 --> 00:47:05,910
if you jump to your volumes folder,
yeah I don't have one.

938
00:47:05,910 --> 00:47:10,930
If you go into your volumes folder and
do an ls -la, that la

939
00:47:10,930 --> 00:47:16,730
means the long form, and a means
show all folders, even hidden ones.

940
00:47:16,730 --> 00:47:21,810
You might see a volume in here that's
named to be that local backup.

941
00:47:21,810 --> 00:47:23,140
I'm trying to remember the name of it.

942
00:47:23,140 --> 00:47:24,610
Oh, Mobile Backups.

943
00:47:24,610 --> 00:47:28,700
So you might see a folder in here
that's called Mobile Backups.

944
00:47:28,700 --> 00:47:33,740
If you see that folder, that's
the local cache copy of Time Machine.

945
00:47:33,740 --> 00:47:36,980
So it's doing a backup of it right
here to your own hard drive.

946
00:47:36,980 --> 00:47:40,840
Again, does not help at all
with a hard drive failure.

947
00:47:40,840 --> 00:47:44,892
It just helps with accidental deletions or
changes when you haven't plugged in your

948
00:47:44,892 --> 00:47:47,360
actual Time Machine back
up disk in a little while.

949
00:47:47,360 --> 00:47:48,974
So, useful thing to have,

950
00:47:48,974 --> 00:47:53,269
not something you'd wanna bank on
as you're only back up destination.

951
00:47:53,269 --> 00:47:59,420
All right, now let's say that I wanted
to make sure that feature was turned on.

952
00:47:59,420 --> 00:48:00,940
I don't have that folder here.

953
00:48:00,940 --> 00:48:03,220
So do I know if a feature is turned on or
not?

954
00:48:03,220 --> 00:48:05,910
Well, I turned it off so
I know it's not turned on.

955
00:48:05,910 --> 00:48:07,310
It's on be default.

956
00:48:07,310 --> 00:48:09,720
So most of you guys, if you've never
looked at this, you should have that.

957
00:48:09,720 --> 00:48:11,480
You should have mobile backups folder.

958
00:48:11,480 --> 00:48:14,383
If I want to turn it on the command
is pretty simple, it's,

959
00:48:14,383 --> 00:48:17,415
you do have to be an administrator so
I've got to do a.

960
00:48:17,415 --> 00:48:21,240
And then the command itself is T-M util,

961
00:48:21,240 --> 00:48:26,730
that's the time machine utility,
and then enable local.

962
00:48:26,730 --> 00:48:30,385
That's gonna tell it that
it's okay to go ahead and

963
00:48:30,385 --> 00:48:34,720
maintain a local time machine
backup right here on my drive.

964
00:48:34,720 --> 00:48:39,498
Right, now if I disconnect my time
machine backup and I wait long enough,

965
00:48:39,498 --> 00:48:42,811
it will do another backup
right here on my own disk,

966
00:48:42,811 --> 00:48:45,680
as opposed to just not
doing a backup at all.

967
00:48:47,120 --> 00:48:51,480
And if I wanna turn it off, so
it's not eating up space on my disk,

968
00:48:51,480 --> 00:48:56,150
I can come in and I can say, sudu tm util

969
00:48:56,150 --> 00:49:00,240
disable local.

970
00:49:00,240 --> 00:49:05,010
And that's gonna turn it off, and
wipe out that local backup, all right?

971
00:49:05,010 --> 00:49:10,350
So, if you're on something like an SSD,
like I am, and your space is at a premium,

972
00:49:10,350 --> 00:49:12,850
I, you can't get the giant hard
drive cuz they're too expensive.

973
00:49:12,850 --> 00:49:16,080
So, your space is at a premium and you
need all the hard drive space you can get,

974
00:49:16,080 --> 00:49:18,100
you might want to remove
that time machine back up,

975
00:49:18,100 --> 00:49:20,750
just because you need the space for
other things.

976
00:49:20,750 --> 00:49:25,500
But it is nice to have that little go
to backup you can get to, and in fact,

977
00:49:25,500 --> 00:49:27,570
I'll just go ahead and
turn mine back on, lately,

978
00:49:27,570 --> 00:49:31,650
cuz there was one show where I need
a lot of VMs and I ran out of space.

979
00:49:31,650 --> 00:49:34,130
I don't have those anymore, so
I'll go ahead and turn it back on, and

980
00:49:34,130 --> 00:49:36,120
then later on, it'll recreate that file.

981
00:49:36,120 --> 00:49:38,220
So if you're ever poking around
in the volumes folder and

982
00:49:38,220 --> 00:49:41,510
you see that mobile backups folder
in there, that's what it is.

983
00:49:41,510 --> 00:49:43,310
It's a local cache of time machine.

984
00:49:45,810 --> 00:49:47,740
All right.
Well, I think that is about it.

985
00:49:47,740 --> 00:49:52,030
I'm trying to think if there's anything
else I need to mention on time machine.

986
00:49:52,030 --> 00:49:53,270
It's pretty straight forward.

987
00:49:53,270 --> 00:49:56,200
The whole focus of the thing
is to make it easy to use.

988
00:49:56,200 --> 00:49:57,640
And I think they achieve that.

989
00:49:57,640 --> 00:50:02,190
Of the backup software I've worked with,
time machine's is probably the easiest,

990
00:50:02,190 --> 00:50:03,450
and it's very good at what it does.

991
00:50:03,450 --> 00:50:03,970
It's very effective.

992
00:50:05,542 --> 00:50:09,090
All right, well that's a pretty good
spot for us to wrap us this episode.

993
00:50:09,090 --> 00:50:12,690
Let me remind you guys if you
have questions on any of this,

994
00:50:12,690 --> 00:50:13,800
just let us know.

995
00:50:13,800 --> 00:50:16,680
Live during the show you
can go to ITpro.tv/live,

996
00:50:16,680 --> 00:50:19,560
and you'll see the chat room
right beneath the video.

997
00:50:19,560 --> 00:50:23,000
Post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

998
00:50:23,000 --> 00:50:25,600
If you have any questions after the show,
use our Q and A forums.

999
00:50:25,600 --> 00:50:28,540
At the top of every page on IT Pro TV,
you'll see a link that says Q and A.

1000
00:50:28,540 --> 00:50:30,151
Click on it.

1001
00:50:30,151 --> 00:50:33,080
It will take you to the forums,
you can post your questions there.

1002
00:50:33,080 --> 00:50:34,990
We monitor and answer after the show.

1003
00:50:37,610 --> 00:50:39,820
I feel like i'm forgetting something.

1004
00:50:39,820 --> 00:50:42,540
Sometimes when you have stuff like
a time machine, it's so simple,

1005
00:50:42,540 --> 00:50:45,990
you just feel like you forget
something but, yeah all right well.

1006
00:50:45,990 --> 00:50:48,799
So, I'm gonna wrap it up here, if I can
think of what I forgot I'll record another

1007
00:50:48,799 --> 00:50:51,385
segment and stick it on to the end of
this show, but that should be about it.

1008
00:50:51,385 --> 00:50:52,753
So I hope you guys enjoyed it.

1009
00:50:52,753 --> 00:50:56,873
Signing off for ITPro tv, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

episodes.description: Applications can do a wide variety of different things and be very helpful to a user, but sometimes applications downloaded outside of the App Store can be less secure to download. Viewers will hear advantages and disadvantages of using the app store, different types of applications, and the process of uninstalling them.
episodes.title: Managing Applications
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,500 --> 00:00:22,831
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,831 --> 00:00:33,420
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,420 --> 00:00:34,161
All right.

5
00:00:34,161 --> 00:00:34,930
Good morning.

6
00:00:34,930 --> 00:00:36,280
Good afternoon and good evening and

7
00:00:36,280 --> 00:00:38,570
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:38,570 --> 00:00:40,590
I'm your host Don Pezet,

9
00:00:40,590 --> 00:00:44,160
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

10
00:00:44,160 --> 00:00:46,080
Today, we're going to be
jumping into part five,

11
00:00:46,080 --> 00:00:49,650
a whole new section,
which is focused on applications.

12
00:00:49,650 --> 00:00:53,220
And boy, there's a lot to talk about
when it comes to applications.

13
00:00:53,220 --> 00:00:56,780
We're gonna start off just by talking
about how we get applications loaded

14
00:00:56,780 --> 00:00:58,080
onto the system in the first place.

15
00:00:58,080 --> 00:01:00,750
And then we're gonna move into some of
the different types of applications that

16
00:01:00,750 --> 00:01:02,570
are out there and
the ways that we manage them and

17
00:01:02,570 --> 00:01:05,680
then have to deal with them
on an Apple system, right?

18
00:01:05,680 --> 00:01:09,250
So let's just start with the basic
process of how we get applications

19
00:01:09,250 --> 00:01:10,140
in the first place.

20
00:01:10,140 --> 00:01:12,280
Well, when you install MAC OS,

21
00:01:12,280 --> 00:01:15,890
it comes with the suite of
applications already built into it.

22
00:01:15,890 --> 00:01:20,330
So for example, I've got here
a pretty stock install of Mac OS.

23
00:01:20,330 --> 00:01:23,785
And I fired up Yosemite here and
I've got my calendar.

24
00:01:23,785 --> 00:01:25,380
Right?
I can see when Groundhog's Day is,

25
00:01:25,380 --> 00:01:27,210
that's very, very exciting stuff.

26
00:01:27,210 --> 00:01:31,540
I've got things like Safari the web
browser, Apple mail, or iMail or

27
00:01:31,540 --> 00:01:34,190
whatever you want to call it,
which is their mail client.

28
00:01:34,190 --> 00:01:37,680
We've got all these other different
applications and you may have even more.

29
00:01:37,680 --> 00:01:40,670
You may have things like
the iWork Suite installed, so

30
00:01:40,670 --> 00:01:45,770
you have iPhoto and Pages, and
all those other guys, Numbers.

31
00:01:45,770 --> 00:01:51,250
If we go into our applications on
our drive, we can actually go in and

32
00:01:51,250 --> 00:01:54,530
start to see some of that and
see what we've got installed, right?

33
00:01:54,530 --> 00:01:58,150
So, just a bunch of applications
that come with the operating system.

34
00:01:58,150 --> 00:02:02,090
And for your average home user,
those might be enough.

35
00:02:02,090 --> 00:02:05,210
You might not need to install
any other applications.

36
00:02:05,210 --> 00:02:08,060
But if you're like me,
you'll probably install a ton more.

37
00:02:08,060 --> 00:02:10,950
There's so many other applications we
can get out there to provide special

38
00:02:10,950 --> 00:02:15,300
functionality that what comes with the
system is not necessarily gonna be enough.

39
00:02:15,300 --> 00:02:15,950
Right.

40
00:02:15,950 --> 00:02:20,410
So, if we need to get additional programs,
where do we get them from?

41
00:02:20,410 --> 00:02:23,260
Well in Apple land there's really
two different places we can

42
00:02:23,260 --> 00:02:24,420
pull that data from.

43
00:02:24,420 --> 00:02:27,310
The first place is from the app store.

44
00:02:27,310 --> 00:02:30,090
Now the app store originally
launched to support the IOS devices,

45
00:02:30,090 --> 00:02:30,875
the mobile devices.

46
00:02:30,875 --> 00:02:32,870
Right?
It launched on the iPhone and

47
00:02:32,870 --> 00:02:34,740
when the iPad came out it was there to, so

48
00:02:34,740 --> 00:02:38,150
they had the IOS app store where you could
get all the mobile apps that you wanted.

49
00:02:39,650 --> 00:02:42,830
On the desktop though,
you were left to going and

50
00:02:42,830 --> 00:02:44,380
getting third party applications.

51
00:02:44,380 --> 00:02:47,260
You would just go to websites,
they would have programs,

52
00:02:47,260 --> 00:02:48,880
you would download them and install them.

53
00:02:48,880 --> 00:02:51,330
Or you'd go to the store and
you'd buy a DVD or

54
00:02:51,330 --> 00:02:54,040
whatever it was they were selling,
the media of the day.

55
00:02:54,040 --> 00:02:56,760
And you'd pop that into your computer and
you install the software that way.

56
00:02:56,760 --> 00:02:59,820
And so Apple said,
why don't we make life easier on people?

57
00:02:59,820 --> 00:03:03,430
Why don't we go ahead and
create an app store for the desktop also?

58
00:03:03,430 --> 00:03:05,010
And, that's exactly what they did.

59
00:03:05,010 --> 00:03:09,220
So, when you install Yosemite,
you'll have the Mac app store.

60
00:03:09,220 --> 00:03:12,800
Now, the Mac app store is
different than the IOS app store.

61
00:03:12,800 --> 00:03:14,990
The IOS app store has all the mobile apps,
and

62
00:03:14,990 --> 00:03:19,290
they don't run on regular Mac,
on OSX, right.

63
00:03:19,290 --> 00:03:22,780
And in the Mac app store,
we have all of these OS10 apps, and

64
00:03:22,780 --> 00:03:24,320
they don't run on IOS.

65
00:03:24,320 --> 00:03:26,510
So they're two completely separate stores,

66
00:03:26,510 --> 00:03:29,870
don't expect to see the same
applications when you go into them.

67
00:03:29,870 --> 00:03:34,240
It's gonna fire up.

68
00:03:34,240 --> 00:03:37,180
And I'll see the application
they're promoting this week,

69
00:03:37,180 --> 00:03:39,660
as well as various other
applications I can go in and buy.

70
00:03:39,660 --> 00:03:41,150
And they're categorized,

71
00:03:41,150 --> 00:03:45,280
you can search and find them all
right here in one easy to use place.

72
00:03:46,390 --> 00:03:49,770
Now I probably don't have to tell
you guys about the advantages and

73
00:03:49,770 --> 00:03:50,580
disadvantages of this.

74
00:03:50,580 --> 00:03:53,850
But let's just cover it
to be on the safe side.

75
00:03:53,850 --> 00:03:57,760
The primary advantage of using
the app store is security.

76
00:03:57,760 --> 00:03:58,550
Right?

77
00:03:58,550 --> 00:04:02,890
Every single application that is in
this list has been reviewed by Apple.

78
00:04:02,890 --> 00:04:04,160
Apple's looked at it.

79
00:04:04,160 --> 00:04:06,220
Made sure it's a legitimate application.

80
00:04:06,220 --> 00:04:07,702
And put it in the app store.

81
00:04:07,702 --> 00:04:12,570
All right, so we know that it's going to
be virus free, that it's not malware,

82
00:04:12,570 --> 00:04:15,870
that it's not spy software.

83
00:04:15,870 --> 00:04:17,085
We assume, right?

84
00:04:17,085 --> 00:04:20,270
[LAUGH] So it's been tested by somebody.

85
00:04:21,350 --> 00:04:22,970
The other advantage is,

86
00:04:22,970 --> 00:04:27,700
when we install software through the app
store, it automatically updates.

87
00:04:27,700 --> 00:04:30,290
So if a new update comes out for
Core Animator, and

88
00:04:30,290 --> 00:04:31,314
that's what I have installed.

89
00:04:31,314 --> 00:04:34,180
Then it'll update my system to Havoc,

90
00:04:34,180 --> 00:04:36,440
that another advantage of
getting it from the app store.

91
00:04:37,850 --> 00:04:41,060
There are some disadvantages of
getting things from the app store.

92
00:04:41,060 --> 00:04:44,710
For example, if I'm a software vendor,
and I wrote my own software package, and

93
00:04:44,710 --> 00:04:47,410
I want to give that out to my customers,
if I put it in the app store,

94
00:04:47,410 --> 00:04:49,530
that's a great way to do it.

95
00:04:49,530 --> 00:04:51,780
But now Apple gets
a percentage of my revenue.

96
00:04:51,780 --> 00:04:54,110
Right?
The developers have to pay Apple,

97
00:04:54,110 --> 00:04:58,450
so software is either more
expensive in the app store or

98
00:04:58,450 --> 00:05:01,840
a lot of developers just choose not to
put their apps in the app store because

99
00:05:01,840 --> 00:05:04,610
they don't want to pay Apple
part of their profits.

100
00:05:04,610 --> 00:05:06,580
Right?
Profit margins on software is not that

101
00:05:06,580 --> 00:05:08,320
great anyway, so.

102
00:05:08,320 --> 00:05:09,190
They might choose not to do that.

103
00:05:10,970 --> 00:05:12,840
Now the other option though
is that you can go out and

104
00:05:12,840 --> 00:05:14,610
you can install applications yourself.

105
00:05:14,610 --> 00:05:16,750
You can go to a website for somebody and

106
00:05:16,750 --> 00:05:22,650
I know earlier in the show I went
to a Royal TS, that's not it.

107
00:05:23,890 --> 00:05:26,990
A program that I use just all the time.

108
00:05:26,990 --> 00:05:28,310
And, oh that was the right web page.

109
00:05:28,310 --> 00:05:30,670
Apparently they've changed their
page since I've been there last.

110
00:05:30,670 --> 00:05:32,900
But you can go to some
vendors' web page and

111
00:05:32,900 --> 00:05:35,090
download the applications
right from there.

112
00:05:35,090 --> 00:05:38,680
So if I want Royal TSX, the Apple version,
I can just download it and

113
00:05:38,680 --> 00:05:40,910
now I've got a copy and
I can install it from there.

114
00:05:40,910 --> 00:05:41,640
All right.

115
00:05:41,640 --> 00:05:44,000
Now on a positive side, it was very easy.

116
00:05:44,000 --> 00:05:44,990
I just went and got it.

117
00:05:44,990 --> 00:05:47,490
Right?
And the vendor they can charge money for

118
00:05:47,490 --> 00:05:50,720
the application and
they get all that money so it helps them.

119
00:05:50,720 --> 00:05:53,660
On a negative,
it's not gonna automatically update

120
00:05:53,660 --> 00:05:57,080
unless that developer wrote some kind
of update functionality in there.

121
00:05:57,080 --> 00:06:00,850
In the case of Royal TSX, it checks for
updates but it won't actually do them.

122
00:06:00,850 --> 00:06:03,330
So I've gotta go and
download an update when I'm ready,

123
00:06:03,330 --> 00:06:05,450
so that's a little bit more challenging.

124
00:06:05,450 --> 00:06:08,650
The other thing is,
if I go to download this application and

125
00:06:08,650 --> 00:06:13,140
it sends me to a mirror site,
to some other website to download it.

126
00:06:13,140 --> 00:06:15,960
How do I know I'm getting
the actual application and

127
00:06:15,960 --> 00:06:18,590
not one that's been modified or
compromised, right?

128
00:06:18,590 --> 00:06:21,940
We see that with a lot of software, where
to save money the developers are using

129
00:06:21,940 --> 00:06:24,830
mirror sites, and you don't know
who those mirror companies are.

130
00:06:24,830 --> 00:06:26,830
You don't know if you can trust them.

131
00:06:26,830 --> 00:06:30,960
So they might have MD5 checksums along
with the download so you can compare to

132
00:06:30,960 --> 00:06:33,940
make sure the file wasn't tampered with,
but that's a lot of burden.

133
00:06:33,940 --> 00:06:35,760
The app store does it for you, right?

134
00:06:35,760 --> 00:06:38,860
So pros and cons for going either way.

135
00:06:38,860 --> 00:06:40,070
Both are supported.

136
00:06:40,070 --> 00:06:41,770
You can install your
applications either way.

137
00:06:41,770 --> 00:06:43,770
Apple leaves that up to you.

138
00:06:43,770 --> 00:06:44,780
All right.

139
00:06:44,780 --> 00:06:48,710
But on the exam, when they talk
about downloading applications and

140
00:06:48,710 --> 00:06:51,500
installing them, if it's from the app
store, they just call it that.

141
00:06:51,500 --> 00:06:53,500
Installing from the app store or
installing an application.

142
00:06:53,500 --> 00:06:54,620
That's what they're referring to.

143
00:06:54,620 --> 00:06:57,720
If they just, in general,
say you install an application.

144
00:06:57,720 --> 00:06:59,510
You can assume they mean

00:40:24,212 --> 00:40:26,434
But I've got each of these widgets,
they're running,

837
00:40:26,434 --> 00:40:27,910
they are separate programs.

838
00:40:27,910 --> 00:40:30,150
We can hit our plus sign, and
we can pick what we wanna add.

839
00:40:30,150 --> 00:40:33,070
Maybe I want the tile game,
gotta have my tile game right?

840
00:40:33,070 --> 00:40:35,595
And you can throw that in and
start to to use it.

841
00:40:35,595 --> 00:40:37,025
It's incredibly exciting.

842
00:40:37,025 --> 00:40:37,825
Right?

843
00:40:37,825 --> 00:40:43,045
Well, if a user adds a custom application
to this list, one that's not here,

844
00:40:43,045 --> 00:40:46,765
If we hit that plus sign there's a button
at the bottom that says more widgets.

845
00:40:46,765 --> 00:40:49,357
And they can hit more and
it'll take them to a web page

846
00:40:49,357 --> 00:40:53,157
where they can start to add in other
ones from the Internet, right?

847
00:40:53,157 --> 00:40:57,127
And you can even download ones
yourself and install them.

848
00:40:57,127 --> 00:41:00,467
They end up, if we go into our,
into terminal.

849
00:41:01,803 --> 00:41:05,168
The widgets end up in a couple
of different folders.

850
00:41:05,168 --> 00:41:10,438
There's /Library/Widgets, right?

851
00:41:10,438 --> 00:41:13,713
This is where the ones from Apple
come from, they're right there.

852
00:41:13,713 --> 00:41:16,073
But the users can install
them in their own folder too.

853
00:41:16,073 --> 00:41:22,766
So, if I go to like
/Users/donpezet/Library/Widgets,

854
00:41:22,766 --> 00:41:24,110
all right.

855
00:41:24,110 --> 00:41:25,650
Oh, I don't have it.

856
00:41:25,650 --> 00:41:28,760
They can go to the library and they can
create a widgets folder if they don't have

857
00:41:28,760 --> 00:41:31,140
one already, so I'll just make one.

858
00:41:31,140 --> 00:41:35,200
And now I can download widgets from third
party sites, and throw them in here, and

859
00:41:35,200 --> 00:41:36,840
they'll run with my dashboard.

860
00:41:36,840 --> 00:41:37,950
Well, are those safe?

861
00:41:37,950 --> 00:41:39,120
Are they trusted?

862
00:41:39,120 --> 00:41:40,720
Are they ones that we want to allow?

863
00:41:40,720 --> 00:41:41,950
That can be a little dangerous right?

864
00:41:41,950 --> 00:41:46,100
So we have to be aware that the dashboard,
there's still applications right?

865
00:41:46,100 --> 00:41:50,060
Fortunately, Gatekeeper applies to widgets
just like it does regular applications,

866
00:41:50,060 --> 00:41:52,170
so if they download it
they've got to approve it.

867
00:41:52,170 --> 00:41:55,419
But just be aware that it
isn't another type of program.

868
00:41:55,419 --> 00:41:58,564
And the way we uninstall those is
by dragging them to the trash.

869
00:41:58,564 --> 00:42:01,365
We can throw them away if
they're ones we've downloaded.

870
00:42:01,365 --> 00:42:04,505
If they're ones that we got from Apple,
like that ESPN one,

871
00:42:04,505 --> 00:42:07,750
well you just delete it from the dashboard
screen and that knocks it out.

872
00:42:07,750 --> 00:42:10,470
But you can't actually
delete the application.

873
00:42:10,470 --> 00:42:13,040
It stays on the hard drive because
it's considered part of the OS.

874
00:42:13,040 --> 00:42:17,370
All right, so those are widgets and
that's about that.

875
00:42:17,370 --> 00:42:21,338
I can't think of anything else
exciting to say about them.

876
00:42:21,338 --> 00:42:24,800
All right, well that's about all I've
got for installing, supporting and

877
00:42:24,800 --> 00:42:26,360
in removing applications.

878
00:42:26,360 --> 00:42:30,970
We still have a tun of other things to
talk about in this section that are kind

879
00:42:30,970 --> 00:42:35,588
of more fringe type topics, things like
the quick look functionality, autosave,

880
00:42:35,588 --> 00:42:38,790
resume, Java applications and so on.

881
00:42:38,790 --> 00:42:41,440
But, this is a good spot to stop for
this episode.

882
00:42:41,440 --> 00:42:43,454
So let's wrap it up right here,
stay tuned,

883
00:42:43,454 --> 00:42:47,111
cuz we're gonna have a part two where we
jump into all the additional technologies

884
00:42:47,111 --> 00:42:48,761
that are kind of a mixed bag of stuff.

885
00:42:48,761 --> 00:42:51,410
So we'll get a chance to see
those in the next episode.

886
00:42:51,410 --> 00:42:55,960
All right, let me remind you guys if you
have questions on anything that I covered,

887
00:42:55,960 --> 00:42:57,160
please feel free to ask.

888
00:42:57,160 --> 00:42:57,900
Live during the show,

889
00:42:57,900 --> 00:43:02,400
you can go to itpro.tv/live and you'll
see the chat box right beneath the video.

890
00:43:02,400 --> 00:43:05,760
Post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

891
00:43:05,760 --> 00:43:08,920
If you have any questions after the show,
use the Q&A forums.

892
00:43:08,920 --> 00:43:12,042
You hit that Q&A link at the top
of all the ITProTV pages,

893
00:43:12,042 --> 00:43:13,747
it'll take you to the forums.

894
00:43:13,747 --> 00:43:17,509
You can post your questions there,
we monitor and answer after the show.

895
00:43:17,509 --> 00:43:20,991
Take advantage of those resources,
they are there for you.

896
00:43:20,991 --> 00:43:22,861
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

897
00:43:22,861 --> 00:43:26,320
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,
and I'll see you next time.

episodes.description: Every application installed onto Mac OS is going to generate data, so there are some things one should be aware of when it comes to that data. Viewers will hear about the preview functionality behind Quick Look, preserving data through the Autosave feature, and about preference files and how they work.
episodes.title: Application Data
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,786 --> 00:00:10,786
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:32,513 --> 00:00:35,452
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening and

3
00:00:35,452 --> 00:00:37,490
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:37,490 --> 00:00:38,900
I'm your host Don Pezet,

5
00:00:38,900 --> 00:00:43,060
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

6
00:00:44,060 --> 00:00:48,460
In our last episode, we got a chance
to see installing applications and

7
00:00:48,460 --> 00:00:52,070
uninstalling applications,
working with those programs.

8
00:00:52,070 --> 00:00:56,880
In this episode, we're gonna talk about
the data that those programs generate.

9
00:00:56,880 --> 00:01:02,130
Every app that you install inside of Mac
OS is gonna generate some kind of data.

10
00:01:02,130 --> 00:01:05,560
At a minimum,
it's gonna generate a preferences file.

11
00:01:05,560 --> 00:01:09,980
A file that stores settings that
reflect what that program does or

12
00:01:09,980 --> 00:01:11,670
has set, all right.

13
00:01:11,670 --> 00:01:14,890
You know the preferences,
the options that we flag inside of it.

14
00:01:14,890 --> 00:01:18,400
But more commonly, the programs you
run are gonna generate actual data,

15
00:01:18,400 --> 00:01:22,640
like text documents,
images, photos, music,

16
00:01:22,640 --> 00:01:26,448
whatever it is that your programs make,
they'll generate files for that, too.

17
00:01:26,448 --> 00:01:29,020
So, I wanna highlight some of
the things that we want to be aware of

18
00:01:29,020 --> 00:01:29,890
with that data.

19
00:01:29,890 --> 00:01:33,908
And some of the neat stuff we can do
with that data once it's on our system,

20
00:01:33,908 --> 00:01:34,800
all right.

21
00:01:34,800 --> 00:01:36,520
Let's start with preferences?

22
00:01:37,550 --> 00:01:40,560
If our system is running applications,

23
00:01:40,560 --> 00:01:44,170
each user might use those
applications a different way.

24
00:01:44,170 --> 00:01:47,600
So when they launch an application they
might wanna customize the user interface,

25
00:01:47,600 --> 00:01:49,250
change the way things are laid out.

26
00:01:49,250 --> 00:01:51,040
Well, the programs remember that.

27
00:01:51,040 --> 00:01:54,000
And they remember that
by tracking preferences.

28
00:01:54,000 --> 00:01:56,970
The preferences are stored in a file
in the hard drive which is called

29
00:01:56,970 --> 00:01:59,258
a p-list file, it's short for
preference list.

30
00:01:59,258 --> 00:02:03,490
And the p-list files are these little
binary files that contain all of

31
00:02:03,490 --> 00:02:05,090
those settings and options.

32
00:02:05,090 --> 00:02:10,130
There's typically one generic p-list
file that's the default settings,

33
00:02:10,130 --> 00:02:13,650
and that's located in
/library/preferences, right.

34
00:02:13,650 --> 00:02:17,930
So, it's on the root of the hard
drive in that global settings area.

35
00:02:17,930 --> 00:02:23,080
But then, each individual user will
typically have a preference file also,

36
00:02:23,080 --> 00:02:25,410
so that every user can set
the program up a different way,

37
00:02:25,410 --> 00:02:27,540
and they might override each other.

38
00:02:27,540 --> 00:02:31,180
Just remember that the user's
preference file is the one that wins,

39
00:02:31,180 --> 00:02:34,190
that will override the global
preference file if one exists.

40
00:02:34,190 --> 00:02:37,520
Sometimes a global preference
file doesn't even exist because

41
00:02:37,520 --> 00:02:39,200
it knows each user will have their own,
right.

42
00:02:39,200 --> 00:02:42,808
Let me show you what I'm talking about,
all right.

43
00:02:42,808 --> 00:02:46,950
If I have a program,
like the VLC video player.

44
00:02:46,950 --> 00:02:51,330
So, here on my laptop I have the VLC
video player, and I can go in and

45
00:02:51,330 --> 00:02:52,930
I can customize its options.

46
00:02:52,930 --> 00:02:57,065
If I go into my VLC menu up here, and
go to Preferences I'll see all these

47
00:02:57,065 --> 00:03:00,135
different things that I can turn on and
off, right.

48
00:03:00,135 --> 00:03:00,845
Maybe for

49
00:03:00,845 --> 00:03:04,555
the language I don't want it set to auto
I want to set it to American English.

50
00:03:04,555 --> 00:03:07,185
And for the interface style I
want it to be the dark interface

51
00:03:07,185 --> 00:03:08,805
not the bright interface.

52
00:03:08,805 --> 00:03:12,175
Maybe down here, I don't want to
automatically check for updates so

53
00:03:12,175 --> 00:03:12,765
I'll turn that off, all right.

54
00:03:14,195 --> 00:03:18,530
When I save all that and
I get out of VLC, and

55
00:03:18,530 --> 00:03:23,020
I go back into VLC,
it's gonna remember all of those options.

56
00:03:23,020 --> 00:03:26,760
It's gonna remember them because it
saved them into a preferences file.

57
00:03:26,760 --> 00:03:30,750
And so all those settings remain
set exactly the way that I want it.

58
00:03:30,750 --> 00:03:33,380
Now, where did that preferences file go?

59
00:03:33,380 --> 00:03:35,730
It could have gone into the global
preferences folder, but

60
00:03:35,730 --> 00:03:38,640
the odds are it went into my
personal preferences folder.

61
00:03:38,640 --> 00:03:39,800
Let's go see that.

62
00:03:39,800 --> 00:03:43,429
If I drop into my terminal,
if I want to go to the global folder,

63
00:03:43,429 --> 00:03:45,700
that's in /library/preferences.

64
00:03:45,700 --> 00:03:49,581
So I'm just gonna change
into that directory, and

65
00:03:49,581 --> 00:03:52,928
let me see if I can find
any VLC files in here.

66
00:03:52,928 --> 00:03:58,370
Remember you might not and yeah,
sure enough it doesn't seem like I do.

67
00:03:58,370 --> 00:04:01,440
I guess it could be under
the company name in videolan.

68
00:04:01,440 --> 00:04:04,730
Nope, all right, so
I don't have a global preference file and

69
00:04:04,730 --> 00:04:06,360
I'm not terribly surprised.

70
00:04:06,360 --> 00:04:10,065
A lot of applications forgo that one
because you can just have individual ones

71
00:04:10,065 --> 00:04:10,810
for each user.

72
00:04:10,810 --> 00:04:14,568
So I need to look into my user profile, so

73
00:04:14,568 --> 00:04:20,544
I'll switch into /users/dpezet/
Library/Preferences,

74
00:04:20,544 --> 00:04:25,317
which I'm going to have
a hard time spelling here.

75
00:04:25,317 --> 00:04:28,830
So, Preferences,
actually that's not right either.

76
00:04:28,830 --> 00:04:32,310
There we go, Preferences,
I will spell it right sooner or later.

77
00:04:32,310 --> 00:04:34,900
Once I'm in that folder, I can look and

78
00:04:34,900 --> 00:04:37,210
I'm sure that I've got
tons of preferences.

79
00:04:37,210 --> 00:04:40,910
All the different programs that I've run
over the years, all laid out in here.

80
00:04:40,910 --> 00:04:43,830
There could be a lot of information,
all right,

81
00:04:43,830 --> 00:04:45,910
including applications you've uninstalled.

82
00:04:45,910 --> 00:04:47,880
When you uninstall an application,
when you drag and

83
00:04:47,880 --> 00:04:51,870
drop it in the trash, it will typically
leave its preferences behind.

84
00:04:51,870 --> 00:04:53,840
So that if you go and
run the application again later,

85
00:04:53,840 --> 00:04:56,680
if you install it, it'll remember
all the settings from before.

86
00:04:56,680 --> 00:04:59,720
These files are all really small,
you know, 118 bytes,

87
00:04:59,720 --> 00:05:02,990
645 bytes, that's not even 1 kilobyte.

88
00:05:02,990 --> 00:05:06,690
Some of them are bigger this one is
13 kilobytes for Parallels Desktop.

89
00:05:06,690 --> 00:05:08,750
Parallels Desktop is
a pretty hefty program,

90
00:05:08,750 --> 00:05:10,550
there's a lot of options and
settings there.

91
00:05:10,550 --> 00:05:12,762
Some of them can be a little bit larger,
but

92
00:05:12,762 --> 00:05:15,040
even the large ones
are still really small.

93
00:05:15,040 --> 00:05:18,420
27 kilobytes, that's a drop in the bucket
compared to your hard drive space.

94
00:05:20,252 --> 00:05:25,240
All right but down on the bottom, I can
see where I've got a whole folder for

95
00:05:25,240 --> 00:05:28,350
VideoLAN right there, but I'll see
this guy is the one I'm looking for

96
00:05:28,350 --> 00:05:32,000
right here, org.videolan.vlc.plist.

97
00:05:32,000 --> 00:05:36,000
That's the preferences list for
that program.

98
00:05:36,000 --> 00:05:38,930
And if I wanna read it, well,
it's a little bit challenging.

99
00:05:38,930 --> 00:05:41,500
Because it's stored in a binary format.

100
00:05:41,500 --> 00:05:47,070
If I use the more command to try and view
it, so like if I try and pull that up.

101
00:05:50,734 --> 00:05:51,953
Let me just type in that full name.

102
00:05:51,953 --> 00:05:56,956
So I'm just typing
more./org.videolan.vlc.plist.

103
00:05:56,956 --> 00:05:59,040
It's gonna give me a warning.

104
00:05:59,040 --> 00:06:02,750
It says it may be a binary file,
should I see it anyway?

105
00:06:02,750 --> 00:06:04,550
Sure, why not, show it to me.

106
00:06:04,550 --> 00:06:05,490
Here it is.

107
00:06:05,490 --> 00:06:09,560
And when I look at it, there's some
words I can make out, but most of it is

108
00:06:09,560 --> 00:06:14,850
comprised of this garbage, right,
this junk text that's just dumped in here.

109
00:06:14,850 --> 00:06:18,840
And I'm not actually able to
interpret what that means, okay.

110
00:06:18,840 --> 00:06:21,960
So what I need to do is
I need to convert this.

111
00:06:21,960 --> 00:06:26,230
At the end of the day a p-list file is
actually an XML file, it's human readable.

112
00:06:26,230 --> 00:06:30,390
But it's compiled into a binary format so
it runs more securely and quickly.

113
00:06:30,390 --> 00:06:32,780
We just need to decompile it,
and we can do that.

114
00:06:32,780 --> 00:06:36,880
Well we've got a command line utility for
that, the plutil, right,

115
00:06:36,880 --> 00:06:40,580
the p-list utility, and
it allows us to convert these files.

116
00:06:40,580 --> 00:06:44,510
I can say, plutil-convert, and

117
00:06:44,510 --> 00:06:46,380
then specify the format I
want it converted into.

118
00:06:46,380 --> 00:06:48,430
There's really only two formats.

119
00:06:48,430 --> 00:06:51,600
There's XML1 and Binary1.

120
00:06:51,600 --> 00:06:54,770
And that one is a reference to
the version of the p-list format.

121
00:06:54,770 --> 00:06:57,315
Apple only has one version,
or at least one I know of.

122
00:06:57,315 --> 00:07:00,405
So I'm converting it to
the p-list XML version 1 format.

123
00:07:00,405 --> 00:07:04,385
And then I need to specify
the file name that I'm converting.

124
00:07:04,385 --> 00:07:08,966
Which mine was org.videolan.vlc.plist.

125
00:07:08,966 --> 00:07:13,786
So I'll just punch that in there, let
me make my screen a little bit wider so

126
00:07:13,786 --> 00:07:15,635
it doesn't word wrap on us.

127
00:07:17,940 --> 00:07:19,680
And it's gonna convert it.

128
00:07:19,680 --> 00:07:23,940
Now the file name doesn't change,
but it is an XML file now.

129
00:07:23,940 --> 00:07:28,350
The program won't be able to work
quite right while it's an XML file.

130
00:07:28,350 --> 00:07:32,785
I can do this, make my changes or
look at the data and when I'm done

131
00:07:32,785 --> 00:07:36,805
I can recompile it back again and
then it'll be available for the program.

132
00:07:36,805 --> 00:07:40,565
So if I take a look at it now, if I run
that same more command from before,

133
00:07:40,565 --> 00:07:43,437
instead of warning me about being
a binary It'll show me the data.

134
00:07:43,437 --> 00:07:46,557
And it's just an XML file,
it's not very hard to read.

135
00:07:46,557 --> 00:07:47,710
And you can look in here and

136
00:07:47,710 --> 00:07:50,181
see the settings like what
folders it shows by default.

137
00:07:50,181 --> 00:07:52,165
The window location on the screen so

138
00:07:52,165 --> 00:07:55,352
it can launch back into the same
place that it was before.

139
00:07:55,352 --> 00:07:59,281
As I continue to look down,
you'll spot other things in here

140
00:07:59,281 --> 00:08:02,758
like Enable automatic update
checks is set to false.

141
00:08:02,758 --> 00:08:03,288
All right?
So

142
00:08:03,288 --> 00:08:06,330
it's remembering don't do
those automatic update checks.

143
00:08:07,370 --> 00:08:10,290
And if I were to launch VLC Player
it would show that, right?

144
00:08:10,290 --> 00:08:11,960
I turned that off before.

145
00:08:11,960 --> 00:08:13,690
But it is just an XML file.

146
00:08:13,690 --> 00:08:19,540
I could go and edit that and
change it to true.

147
00:08:19,540 --> 00:08:23,050
And so then it would say enable
automatic update checks True.

148
00:08:23,050 --> 00:08:24,410
And that would be turned on.

149
00:08:24,410 --> 00:08:28,450
Just storing it right here inside of this.

150
00:08:28,450 --> 00:08:29,510
You'll see the language.

151
00:08:29,510 --> 00:08:31,700
I hard set the language to English.

152
00:08:31,700 --> 00:08:35,030
I also set the screen to show
the dark view instead of light.

153
00:08:35,030 --> 00:08:37,080
I don't know where in here that's stored.

154
00:08:37,080 --> 00:08:40,530
Whoever writes the application can pick
whatever name they want for these options.

155
00:08:40,530 --> 00:08:43,380
So sometimes it's really
easy to spot language.

156
00:08:43,380 --> 00:08:44,700
EN for English.

157
00:08:44,700 --> 00:08:45,920
Done, right?

158
00:08:45,920 --> 00:08:49,260
Other times it can be a little bit more
difficult, this, the theme that I chose,

159
00:08:49,260 --> 00:08:51,490
that could be called any number of things.

160
00:08:51,490 --> 00:08:52,490
So I'd have to look through here and

161
00:08:52,490 --> 00:08:55,400
see if I couldn't figure out which one
of these actually referred to the theme.

Post your question there.

864
