episodes.title: Application Support
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,192 --> 00:00:22,710
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,710 --> 00:00:33,443
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,443 --> 00:00:36,517
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

5
00:00:36,517 --> 00:00:38,729
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,729 --> 00:00:40,210
I'm your host, Don Pezet,

7
00:00:40,210 --> 00:00:44,820
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

8
00:00:44,820 --> 00:00:48,630
Well, in this episode we're gonna be
winding down the application section.

9
00:00:48,630 --> 00:00:49,590
In our previous episodes,

10
00:00:49,590 --> 00:00:53,970
we've covered installing applications and
making sure they run smoothly.

11
00:00:53,970 --> 00:00:56,560
And how they save their preferences and
all that good stuff.

12
00:00:56,560 --> 00:01:00,570
In this episode, we've really
got a grab bag of miscellaneous

13
00:01:00,570 --> 00:01:03,195
technologies that all kind of
rotate around our applications.

14
00:01:03,195 --> 00:01:05,210
So,we're gonna get to see
some neat stuff here.

15
00:01:05,210 --> 00:01:08,360
This just didn't quite fit
into the other categories.

16
00:01:08,360 --> 00:01:11,730
The first one that I wanna talk about
is,probably one of the best examples of

17
00:01:11,730 --> 00:01:15,580
something that doesn't fit in the other
categories and that's Java applications.

18
00:01:16,640 --> 00:01:17,940
What is Java?

19
00:01:17,940 --> 00:01:21,430
Java is a programming language
originally created by Sun microsystems.

20
00:01:21,430 --> 00:01:25,370
And they were acquired by Oracle so
now it's Oracle Java.

21
00:01:25,370 --> 00:01:29,720
And the idea behind Java was
that with a normal application

22
00:01:29,720 --> 00:01:32,070
a programmer has to right the application.

23
00:01:32,070 --> 00:01:35,550
And then compile it for each operating
system they want to support.

24
00:01:35,550 --> 00:01:38,440
And that means they usually have to write
it a little bit differently if they want

25
00:01:38,440 --> 00:01:42,890
the application to run on Windows and
MacOS and Linux and

26
00:01:42,890 --> 00:01:44,180
whatever else is out there.

27
00:01:44,180 --> 00:01:47,000
They've got to rewrite the application
more than once to meet the needs of

28
00:01:47,000 --> 00:01:48,290
the different OSs.

29
00:01:48,290 --> 00:01:51,820
And with Java, what Sun said
was let's create a framework.

30
00:01:51,820 --> 00:01:56,090
A framework that real customized
to run on each platform, and then

31
00:01:56,090 --> 00:02:00,510
all the developers have to do is write
their programs to work with our platform.

32
00:02:00,510 --> 00:02:03,860
Then they don't have to customize their
program for every operating system.

33
00:02:03,860 --> 00:02:08,110
They can write a program once,
and it'll run on every OS.

34
00:02:08,110 --> 00:02:11,180
It sounded like a great idea,
and back in the beginning,

35
00:02:11,180 --> 00:02:15,480
back in the early 90s,
it was really a revolutionary idea.

36
00:02:15,480 --> 00:02:18,030
A lot of people adopted
Java really quickly.

37
00:02:18,030 --> 00:02:20,230
But there were a few problems with it.

38
00:02:20,230 --> 00:02:22,600
The biggest problem with Java
are the security concerns.

39
00:02:23,750 --> 00:02:27,170
There are a number of significant
security vulnerabilities that

40
00:02:27,170 --> 00:02:30,620
have come out over the last few
years that center around Java.

41
00:02:30,620 --> 00:02:34,880
And that's made it a real challenge to
get Java support like we used to have.

42
00:02:34,880 --> 00:02:38,070
In fact, if you install Mac OS Yosemite.

43
00:02:38,070 --> 00:02:41,020
It does not have Java
support out of the box.

44
00:02:41,020 --> 00:02:45,240
That's different than some of the
different versions like in Mountain Lion.

45
00:02:45,240 --> 00:02:46,610
When you installed Mountain Lion,

46
00:02:46,610 --> 00:02:49,570
it had Java support baked
in right out of the box.

47
00:02:49,570 --> 00:02:51,580
We don't have that in Yosemite anymore.

48
00:02:51,580 --> 00:02:52,180
All right?.

49
00:02:52,180 --> 00:02:54,210
So security concerns were one problem.

50
00:02:54,210 --> 00:02:57,917
The only problem I always joke
about is that the old slogan is,

51
00:02:57,917 --> 00:03:00,000
write once run anywhere, right?

52
00:03:00,000 --> 00:03:02,460
They say you write your program once so
you could run it anywhere.

53
00:03:02,460 --> 00:03:06,640
And I always said it should be called
write once, run slowly anywhere.

54
00:03:06,640 --> 00:03:08,190
Java applications are slow.

55
00:03:08,190 --> 00:03:11,110
They don't run very fast because
they're doing what's called just in

56
00:03:11,110 --> 00:03:12,280
time compiling.

57
00:03:12,280 --> 00:03:16,410
When you run the application it's
laying it on top of a Java framework,

58
00:03:16,410 --> 00:03:18,760
what's called the Java
run time environment.

59
00:03:18,760 --> 00:03:21,670
And that Java run time
environment is executing that

60
00:03:21,670 --> 00:03:24,030
program inside of a Java space and
that takes time.

61
00:03:24,030 --> 00:03:25,130
It slows things down.

62
00:03:25,130 --> 00:03:26,710
You're not running one program.

63
00:03:26,710 --> 00:03:27,700
You're actually running two.

64
00:03:27,700 --> 00:03:30,880
You're running the program
the developer created, and then you're

65
00:03:30,880 --> 00:03:35,470
running an interpreter that's translating
it into what a Mac is expecting.

66
00:03:35,470 --> 00:03:37,450
And that's not the most
efficient thing in the world.

67
00:03:38,690 --> 00:03:41,800
All I being said,
tons of companies still use Java for

68
00:03:41,800 --> 00:03:46,100
a lot of things and
I know from the security perspective alone

69
00:03:46,100 --> 00:03:49,220
I do not like to have Java
installed on my machines.

70
00:03:49,220 --> 00:03:53,330
I typically uninstall it if it's
already on there but every now and

71
00:03:53,330 --> 00:03:57,580
then you will come across some
application that requires Java to run.

72
00:03:57,580 --> 00:04:01,970
So for example I took a course
at a college not too long ago

73
00:04:01,970 --> 00:04:05,140
where they had lab machines you
could remote in to and connect to.

74
00:04:05,140 --> 00:04:07,670
And the viewer was Java only.

75
00:04:07,670 --> 00:04:11,750
Or I've got a Firewall here in the office
that it's a Cisco firewall and

76
00:04:11,750 --> 00:04:14,550
the management software for
it is Java only.

77
00:04:14,550 --> 00:04:17,140
If I want to manage that firewall.

78
00:04:17,140 --> 00:04:18,680
I've gotta use their Java software,

79
00:04:18,680 --> 00:04:21,370
and that means I've gotta
install Java on my machine.

80
00:04:21,370 --> 00:04:25,830
So it's not uncommon to run into that,
a lot of people have to run it.

81
00:04:25,830 --> 00:04:28,330
Well, if it's not installed on
your machine by default and

82
00:04:28,330 --> 00:04:30,020
you need it, where do we get it?

83
00:04:30,020 --> 00:04:31,610
We've got two choices.

84
00:04:31,610 --> 00:04:35,630
I've said that Apple no longer includes it
with the OS, and that's absolutely true.

85
00:04:35,630 --> 00:04:37,630
Let me show you how to test that, right?

86
00:04:37,630 --> 00:04:40,340
If you're ever on a Mac and
you wanna know if it has Java or

87
00:04:40,340 --> 00:04:43,780
not, well you can search for it,
like I could bring up spotlight and

88
00:04:43,780 --> 00:04:46,240
do a search for Java and
see if it turns up.

89
00:04:46,240 --> 00:04:49,290
But it may not actually turn up
there even if it is installed.

90
00:04:49,290 --> 00:04:53,990
The number one best way to tell wether
you've got Java is to open up a terminal.

91
00:04:55,890 --> 00:05:01,015
And in your terminal window,
just type java--version.

92
00:05:02,590 --> 00:05:05,910
This command right here will tell
you not only if you have Java but

93
00:05:05,910 --> 00:05:09,270
if you do,
what version of it you're running?

94
00:05:09,270 --> 00:05:13,485
So I'll just run Java--version and when
I run that, see the message that I got?

95
00:05:13,485 --> 00:05:17,132
No Java runtime present,
requesting install.

96
00:05:17,132 --> 00:05:18,260
All right?

97
00:05:18,260 --> 00:05:20,570
So I don't have Java on this machine.

98
00:05:20,570 --> 00:05:23,760
If I want it,
I'm going to have to install it.

99
00:05:23,760 --> 00:05:25,230
Now, it prompts me with this window.

100
00:05:25,230 --> 00:05:29,000
It says here to use Java to command
line tool, you need to install the JDK.

101
00:05:29,000 --> 00:05:29,537
All right?

102
00:05:29,537 --> 00:05:32,000
JDK stands for Java Development Kit.

103
00:05:32,000 --> 00:05:34,930
If you're gonna be a Java developer,
you're gonna write Java software,

104
00:05:34,930 --> 00:05:36,710
you install the JDK.

105
00:05:36,710 --> 00:05:39,440
Most of us though,
aren't gonna be a developer.

106
00:05:39,440 --> 00:05:43,530
We really just need what's called the JRE,
the Java Runtime Environment.

107
00:05:43,530 --> 00:05:46,420
That's enough for us to be able
to execute Java applications, and

108
00:05:46,420 --> 00:05:47,830
that's typically all we need.

109
00:05:47,830 --> 00:05:48,660
All right.

110
00:05:48,660 --> 00:05:51,550
Now it's offering for
me to hit More Info to get additional

111
00:05:51,550 --> 00:05:54,150
information about this or
I can just say okay to dismiss it.

112
00:05:54,150 --> 00:05:57,050
If I hit More Info,
it's gonna fire up a web browser and

113
00:05:57,050 --> 00:06:00,390
it's gonna take me to Oracle, all right?

114
00:06:00,390 --> 00:06:02,480
Oracle is the company that owns Java now.

115
00:06:02,480 --> 00:06:06,080
It was originally developed by
Sun Microsystems, but now it's at Oracle.

116
00:06:06,080 --> 00:06:11,440
And if we want to install Java
on our system, we can do that.

117
00:06:11,440 --> 00:06:14,000
You'll see there are several
different versions of Java.

118
00:06:14,000 --> 00:06:17,070
This is the page that Apple sends you to,
but

119
00:06:17,070 --> 00:06:22,711
the easier page if we want to install
Java is to just go to java.com.

120
00:06:22,711 --> 00:06:26,800
Java.com is a webpage owned by
Oracle that's designed to make it

121
00:06:26,800 --> 00:06:28,480
really easy to install Java.

122
00:06:30,040 --> 00:06:33,620
Now the current version of Java is Java 8.

123
00:06:33,620 --> 00:06:39,850
Apple has blacklisted the certificates for
every previous version of Java.

124
00:06:39,850 --> 00:06:44,130
So if you try and install Java 7 or
Java 6, the Java runtime environments for

125
00:06:44,130 --> 00:06:45,750
those, you're gonna get a red flag.

126
00:06:45,750 --> 00:06:48,410
It's gonna warn you, and
it's not gonna let the install go in,

127
00:06:48,410 --> 00:06:52,590
unless you disable Gatekeeper and a few
other security features on your system.

128
00:06:52,590 --> 00:06:54,410
Which you don't want to do.

129
00:06:54,410 --> 00:06:59,020
The reason they did that is there are some
known exploits that are out there

130
00:06:59,020 --> 00:07:03,660
in the wild that hackers can use right
now to infect and damage your machine.

131
00:07:03,660 --> 00:07:07,200
And so the way Apple protects you
from that is saying you can only run

132
00:07:07,200 --> 00:07:09,920
the newest version of Java,
the Java 8 version.

133
00:07:10,940 --> 00:07:13,380
So if you're trying to install a previous
version of Java and it's failing,

134
00:07:13,380 --> 00:07:14,460
that's probably why.

135
00:07:14,460 --> 00:07:15,350
It's not gonna let you do that.

136
00:07:15,350 --> 00:07:16,790
It's gonna stop it from running.

137
00:07:17,890 --> 00:07:22,060
Now in the past,
Java used to be included with Mac OS.

138
00:07:22,060 --> 00:07:25,960
And that version that was included,
that was actually made by Apple.

139
00:07:25,960 --> 00:07:27,840
It wasn't made by Oracle,
it was made by Apple.

140
00:07:27,840 --> 00:07:29,630
They created their own internal one.

141
00:07:29,630 --> 00:07:35,800
They took the Java code and customized
it to meet their security requirements.

142
00:07:35,800 --> 00:07:38,970
When they stopped baking it
into the operating system,

143
00:07:38,970 --> 00:07:41,640
they stopped providing
their own version of Java.

144
00:07:41,640 --> 00:07:42,270
All right?

145
00:07:42,270 --> 00:07:46,590
But they do still have it, so if you ever
run into a scenario where you come up with

146
00:07:46,590 --> 00:07:50,370
a developer and the developer says, we
wrote this program specifically to support

147
00:07:50,370 --> 00:07:54,580
Apple's version of Java, well,
Apple's version of Java is gone now.

148
00:07:54,580 --> 00:07:56,030
That doesn't mean it's gone completely,
though.

149
00:07:56,030 --> 00:07:57,473
You can go in and install it.

150
00:07:57,473 --> 00:08:01,355
Apple doesn't package it with the OS,
because they want it to be as secure as

151
00:08:01,355 --> 00:08:04,520
possible, but if you absolutely
need their version of Java.

152
00:08:04,520 --> 00:08:05,078
You can still get it from Apple's website,
right?

153
00:08:05,078 --> 00:08:11,280
And I'll post this in the show notes,
when this episode gets up on the website.

154
00:08:11,280 --> 00:08:15,150
But I've got a link in the show
notes to Apple's webpage,

155
00:08:15,150 --> 00:08:19,580
where you can actually go to
download their version of Java.

156
00:08:19,580 --> 00:08:24,664
So if I wanted to go and get the one from
Apple, you would go to the support page.

157
00:08:24,664 --> 00:08:31,930
And see how it says Java for
OS X 2014-001, well this is the year 2015.

158
00:08:31,930 --> 00:08:33,130
It's old.

159
00:08:33,130 --> 00:08:35,380
It's not updated like it used to be.

160
00:08:35,380 --> 00:08:39,030
In fact, it's based off the Java
runtime environment for version 6.

161
00:08:39,030 --> 00:08:42,520
So this is based on GRE 6.

162
00:08:42,520 --> 00:08:43,120
That's pretty old.

163
00:08:44,220 --> 00:08:49,150
But Apple has found it to be secure, found
it to be safe, and they make it available.

164
00:08:49,150 --> 00:08:51,230
But that's why it still
has the lion logo up here.

165
00:08:51,230 --> 00:08:52,630
It's not being updated anymore.

166
00:08:52,630 --> 00:08:56,250
Apple is not gonna push anything
beyond the security update to it.

167
00:08:56,250 --> 00:08:59,870
So if you have to have it, you can come
in here, and you can download it and

168
00:08:59,870 --> 00:09:02,060
get it right from Apple, if you want.

169
00:09:02,060 --> 00:09:03,910
But, it is Java 6.

170
00:09:03,910 --> 00:09:07,880
More ideally, you'll wanna get it from
Oracle so you get the latest one.

171
00:09:07,880 --> 00:09:09,340
And it's Java 8.

172
00:09:09,340 --> 00:09:10,920
And if I just go to java.com and

173
00:09:10,920 --> 00:09:14,910
hit the free Java download button,
it's gonna let me agree and download it.

174
00:09:14,910 --> 00:09:18,040
And see how it says recommended version 8,
update 31, all right.

175
00:09:19,140 --> 00:09:23,610
So Java version 8 came out last year,
and there's been 31 updates to it.

176
00:09:23,610 --> 00:09:28,440
All security updates to improve
the reliability of the software.

177
00:09:28,440 --> 00:09:30,200
But, you can agree and download it.

178
00:09:30,200 --> 00:09:33,040
And when it downloads,
it installs like most software.

179
00:09:33,040 --> 00:09:34,690
It's gonna download onto my machine, and

180
00:09:34,690 --> 00:09:37,420
then it's going to be a packaged
file that we'll install.

181
00:09:37,420 --> 00:09:42,050
And that will add that framework to
enable us to run Java applications.

182
00:09:42,050 --> 00:09:43,989
Once that's done,
we'll be able to run those.

183
00:09:45,290 --> 00:09:49,658
So if I jump into my downloads folder and
I find my install file.

184
00:09:49,658 --> 00:09:52,290
I'm trying to jump to my downloads file.

185
00:09:52,290 --> 00:09:53,230
There we go.

186
00:09:53,230 --> 00:09:54,610
I can see where I just installed.

187
00:09:54,610 --> 00:09:56,580
And see how it says JRE, right?

188
00:09:56,580 --> 00:09:58,350
Java Runtime Environment.

189
00:09:58,350 --> 00:10:01,030
I didn't actually download
the JDK cuz I'm not a developer.

190
00:10:01,030 --> 00:10:02,770
I'm not gonna write a Java app.

191
00:10:02,770 --> 00:10:05,320
I just needed the runtime environment,
and that's what it downloaded.

192
00:10:05,320 --> 00:10:07,120
It's just a DMG file.

193
00:10:07,120 --> 00:10:13,450
And notice also that it says jre8u31,
so version eight, update 31.

194
00:10:13,450 --> 00:10:14,910
It's MacOSX.

195
00:10:14,910 --> 00:10:17,570
This is the Mac version,
there's a different one for windows, and

196
00:10:17,570 --> 00:10:19,000
a different one for Linux.

197
00:10:19,000 --> 00:10:19,970
And this one says x64.

198
00:10:21,570 --> 00:10:25,040
This is the 64 bit version of Java.

199
00:10:25,040 --> 00:10:26,760
There is a 32 bit version also.

200
00:10:26,760 --> 00:10:30,040
And I'm gonna talk later in this episode
about the difference between 32 bit and

201
00:10:30,040 --> 00:10:31,230
64 bit applications.

202
00:10:31,230 --> 00:10:34,320
But, it went ahead and
pulled the 64 bit one for me.

203
00:10:34,320 --> 00:10:35,270
And it's just a DMG.

204
00:10:35,270 --> 00:10:37,100
It's a disk image file.

205
00:10:37,100 --> 00:10:39,830
And so if I double click on that,
it'll mount and open, and

206
00:10:39,830 --> 00:10:42,370
I'll see the installer for Java.

207
00:10:42,370 --> 00:10:45,110
Now, Java is not an application by itself.

208
00:10:45,110 --> 00:10:46,160
It's a framework.

209
00:10:46,160 --> 00:10:48,280
It allows other applications to run.

210
00:10:48,280 --> 00:10:52,170
So this is not an app that you drag and
drop to your applications folder.

211
00:10:52,170 --> 00:10:53,480
It's more like a driver.

212
00:10:53,480 --> 00:10:55,570
It's low level system software.

213
00:10:55,570 --> 00:10:58,990
So it ships as a PKG, a package file.

214
00:10:58,990 --> 00:11:00,580
When you load a package,

215
00:11:00,580 --> 00:11:05,020
that's gonna copy to some of your global
locations on the drive to be installed.

216
00:11:05,020 --> 00:11:07,750
Now, I'm getting a warning here telling me
that it can't be opened because it wasn't

217
00:11:07,750 --> 00:11:09,620
downloaded from the Mac App Store.

218
00:11:09,620 --> 00:11:11,130
Well in a previous episode,

219
00:11:11,130 --> 00:11:14,090
I had locked my machine down so that it
would only run things from the App Store.

00:52:12,060 --> 00:52:16,890
Well Yosemite is a 64-bit
operating system.

1076
00:52:16,890 --> 00:52:24,271
And what that means is that it's able to
address more memory than non 64-bit OSs.

1077
00:52:24,271 --> 00:52:29,730
For the longest time,
Mac OS has been a 32-bit operating system.

1078
00:52:29,730 --> 00:52:34,510
And what that meant is that any time a
program needed to reach out to memory, and

1079
00:52:34,510 --> 00:52:39,050
all programs do that, all of your running
programs store their running data in RAM.

1080
00:52:39,050 --> 00:52:41,190
And so
when a program would reach out to RAM,

1081
00:52:41,190 --> 00:52:44,910
it had to reach out to particular spots
in the RAM to where it stored its data.

1082
00:52:44,910 --> 00:52:47,560
So think of it as like a pirate map.

1083
00:52:47,560 --> 00:52:51,250
So if you bury your treasure out
there on some [LAUGH] island,

1084
00:52:51,250 --> 00:52:53,470
how do you find that

1085
00:52:53,470 --> 00:52:56,910
You have a map and it's got little dots

1086
00:52:56,910 --> 00:52:59,290
Well, your programs
are basically doing that.

1087
00:52:59,290 --> 00:53:00,245
Your programs are pirates.

1088
00:53:00,245 --> 00:53:04,350
[LAUGH] And they store their golden RAM

1089
00:53:04,350 --> 00:53:05,530
I need to go back and get that gold.

00:53:05,530 --> 00:53:07,740
Where is it?

1091
00:53:07,740 --> 00:53:09,720
And that map was simply an address number.

1092
00:53:09,720 --> 00:53:13,880
It was a number that identified
where in the memory their data was.

1093
00:53:13,880 --> 00:53:17,310
And so
way back in the early days of computing,

1094
00:53:17,310 --> 00:53:19,330
they came up with this
idea of having a number.

1095
00:53:19,330 --> 00:53:22,210
And as time went on people got more and
more memory, and

1096
00:53:22,210 --> 00:53:25,570
they had to pick a number that was
big enough to account for memory.

1097
00:53:25,570 --> 00:53:29,993
Well most systems, back in the 90s,
switched to a 32-bit number.

1098
00:53:29,993 --> 00:53:33,466
A 32-bit, that means 32 binary bits,
1s and 0s.

1099
00:53:33,466 --> 00:53:38,280

you can write any number from 0

00:53:38,280 --> 00:53:42,000

00:53:43,740 --> 00:53:50,010
That meant if your computer had 2 gigs of

1102
00:53:50,010 --> 00:53:55,070

that referenced all of those bytes of RAM.

00:53:55,070 --> 00:53:56,810
It wasn't that big of a deal.

1104
00:53:56,810 --> 00:54:01,200
But as we started getting more and more
memory in our computer, we get a problem.

1105
00:54:01,200 --> 00:54:05,200
When people started getting 4
GB of memory in their computer,

1106
00:54:05,200 --> 00:54:06,780

was gonna be an issue.

1107
00:54:06,780 --> 00:54:11,250
They said, well, we only use a 32-bit
number to reference that memory.

1108
00:54:11,250 --> 00:54:13,460
What if somebody gets
more than 4 GB of memory?

1109
00:54:13,460 --> 00:54:14,140
Now we're out of luck.

1110
00:54:15,380 --> 00:54:17,770
Well, you're not completely out of luck.

1111
00:54:17,770 --> 00:54:20,920
Apple stepped in and did some neat
things with 32-bit technologies.

1112
00:54:20,920 --> 00:54:25,920
They made it where your desktop could
recognize more than 4 gigs of RAM, but

1113
00:54:25,920 --> 00:54:30,140
each of your programs were
limited to 4 gigs of RAM each.

1114
00:54:30,140 --> 00:54:36,340
So if I had 16 gigs of RAM in my computer,
no one program could use all 16 gigs.

1115
00:54:37,430 --> 00:54:40,315
One program could use 4 gigs,
another program could use 4 gigs,

1116
00:54:40,315 --> 00:54:42,180
a third program could use 4 gigs, right?

1117
00:54:42,180 --> 00:54:47,170
Now I'm using 12 gigs of RAM, but no one
program could use more than 4 gigs of RAM.

1118
00:54:47,170 --> 00:54:49,310
Well, that wasn't a big deal in the 90s.

1119
00:54:49,310 --> 00:54:52,200
Having a gigabyte of RAM
in the '90s was unheard of.

00:54:52,200 --> 00:54:55,250
But in today's world where I may be

1121

00:54:57,390 --> 00:54:58,430
It happens all the time.

00:54:58,430 --> 00:55:02,220
We have applications that consume
more memory than we used to.

So they had to move to a bigger number.

00:55:05,660 --> 00:55:10,148
The 32-bit number wasn't big enough,

00:55:10,148 --> 00:55:13,428
By having 64-bit memory addressing,

00:55:13,428 --> 00:55:18,499
one application can now reference

00:55:18,499 --> 00:55:25,420
One application can actually reference

So if I fire up my calendar, or
Write, my little text editor.

1794
01:29:03,570 --> 01:29:07,050
When I fire up Write,
it's running as me, as dpezet, and so

1795
01:29:07,050 --> 01:29:09,650
it gets the same permissions that I do.

1796
01:29:09,650 --> 01:29:13,460
And when we're in the activity monitor,
and I look at the applications they're

1797
01:29:13,460 --> 01:29:18,260
running, I can sort it by user, and I can
see all the things that dpezet is running.

1798
01:29:18,260 --> 01:29:21,910
And somewhere in here, I should be
able to find that Write application,

1799
01:29:21,910 --> 01:29:24,350
which should be running as me.

1800
01:29:24,350 --> 01:29:26,950
And so I'm just looking in
here trying to find it.

1801
01:29:26,950 --> 01:29:28,710
Apparently it's buried in, there it is.

1802
01:29:28,710 --> 01:29:29,680
Right.

1803
01:29:29,680 --> 01:29:31,810
Now, there's that write application,
it's running as me.

1804
01:29:31,810 --> 01:29:34,970
It says it's not responding, but
it's actually working just fine.

1805
01:29:34,970 --> 01:29:37,580
But I can see it, it's running,
and it show it's running as me.

1806
01:29:37,580 --> 01:29:38,500
That's what I expect to see.

1807
01:29:39,640 --> 01:29:45,220
But, there are sometimes when you run an
application and it runs as somebody else.

1808
01:29:46,400 --> 01:29:49,590
Underneath the hood in Mac OS,
we have the BSD operating system,

1809
01:29:49,590 --> 01:29:51,600
which is based on Unix.

1810
01:29:51,600 --> 01:29:56,090
In Unix, there's a special
file flag called the SUID.

1811
01:29:56,090 --> 01:29:57,560
If any files or

1812
01:29:57,560 --> 01:30:02,420
app has been flagged with SUID flag,
when it runs, it will run as root.

1813
01:30:03,680 --> 01:30:08,240
So don't be surprised if you look in here
and you see some things running as root.

1814
01:30:08,240 --> 01:30:10,850
That means they're running as the system.

1815
01:30:10,850 --> 01:30:15,110
And there's certain applications, usually
drivers, that have to run as the system.

1816
01:30:15,110 --> 01:30:18,310
They have to run as that underlying,
high-admin account, and

1817
01:30:18,310 --> 01:30:20,050
they'll run as root.

1818
01:30:20,050 --> 01:30:24,110
But, if you see an application in there
that you didn't approve, that you didn't

1819
01:30:24,110 --> 01:30:27,970
install yourself, that's a great indicator
that your system's been compromised.

1820
01:30:27,970 --> 01:30:32,060
That somebody is running
an application not as they should be.

1821
01:30:32,060 --> 01:30:32,630
Right?

1822
01:30:32,630 --> 01:30:34,610
So mine looks pretty clean.

1823
01:30:34,610 --> 01:30:38,810
I don't see anything jumping out at me
here that shouldn't be run as root,

1824
01:30:38,810 --> 01:30:42,430
but you'll see things in here like
the Logitech software that I added.

1825
01:30:42,430 --> 01:30:44,810
That will be running
SUID in the background.

1826
01:30:44,810 --> 01:30:47,470
No matter what user logs
in on the computer,

1827
01:30:47,470 --> 01:30:50,740
that needs to run as root because it's
interacting with hardware on the computer.

1828
01:30:50,740 --> 01:30:52,660
It's not tied to a particular user.

1829
01:30:52,660 --> 01:30:56,410
Our applications, though,
those are tied to us as a user, and

1830
01:30:56,410 --> 01:30:59,420
they run with our permission, so
that's what we expect to see.

1831
01:31:01,190 --> 01:31:02,260
All right.

1832
01:31:02,260 --> 01:31:05,670
I've got all sorts of random applications
saying they're not responding.

1833
01:31:05,670 --> 01:31:09,245
This is turning out to be a good
troubleshooting instance, so

1834
01:31:09,245 --> 01:31:11,940
[LAUGH] sometimes you get that, right.

1835
01:31:11,940 --> 01:31:12,900
It's kind of jumping all over the place.

1836
01:31:12,900 --> 01:31:15,490
I can see Write is showing
up as healthy now.

1837
01:31:15,490 --> 01:31:16,690
So, strange stuff.

1838
01:31:17,820 --> 01:31:19,210
All right.
Well those are some of the utilities that

1839
01:31:19,210 --> 01:31:20,300
are built into the system.

1840
01:31:20,300 --> 01:31:21,310
Kind of a quick view of them.

1841
01:31:21,310 --> 01:31:24,410
I can't think of anything else
worth mentioning on that, so

1842
01:31:24,410 --> 01:31:27,230
this is probably a pretty good spot for
us to wrap this episode up.

1843
01:31:27,230 --> 01:31:28,420
All right.

1844
01:31:28,420 --> 01:31:29,860
Well let me remind you guys,

1845
01:31:29,860 --> 01:31:33,930
if you have questions on any of this,
you're always welcome to ask.

1846
01:31:33,930 --> 01:31:36,370
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live and

1847
01:31:36,370 --> 01:31:39,015
you'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

1848
01:31:39,015 --> 01:31:41,470
Post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

1849
01:31:41,470 --> 01:31:45,080
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

1850
01:31:45,080 --> 01:31:48,160
You can click on the Q&A link at
the top of every ITProTV page,

1851
01:31:48,160 --> 01:31:51,470
it'll take you to the forums, you can
post your question there, we monitor and

1852
01:31:51,470 --> 01:31:52,570
answer after the show.

1853
01:31:52,570 --> 01:31:54,400
Take advantage of that resource.

1854
01:31:54,400 --> 01:31:56,306
It is there for you.

1855
01:31:56,306 --> 01:31:58,257
All right, well I hope you
guys enjoyed today's episode.

1856
01:31:58,257 --> 01:32:02,554
Signing off for IT Pro TV, I'm Don Pezet,

episodes.description: Configuring a network connection is important because that's what allows one to share a connection with other computers and connect to the internet. Viewers will hear about basic connectivity to a network, different network protocols, and about wireless networks.
episodes.title: Network Configuration
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,464 --> 00:00:37,400
All right good morning, good afternoon and
good evening and welcome back!

3
00:00:37,400 --> 00:00:40,610
For another episode of
ITProTV I'm your host Don Pezet.

4
00:00:40,610 --> 00:00:44,662
Back in with another episode of Apple
certified support professional.

5
00:00:44,662 --> 00:00:47,126
We're gonna be diving into
a new objective area today.

6
00:00:47,126 --> 00:00:51,010
It is 6.0 or part 6,
however you want to call it

7
00:00:51,010 --> 00:00:56,010
Network configuration,and this is an area
that is really important today because it

8
00:00:56,010 --> 00:01:00,480
is a rare rare computer that
isn't connected to a network.

9
00:01:00,480 --> 00:01:02,470
And you might not have other
computers on the network with you.

10
00:01:02,470 --> 00:01:06,090
You might just use Internet access which
means you are connected the largest

11
00:01:06,090 --> 00:01:07,690
network in the world.

12
00:01:07,690 --> 00:01:08,930
And that's just a given, right?

13
00:01:08,930 --> 00:01:13,450
A computer without Internet access
these days is like a car without gas.

14
00:01:13,450 --> 00:01:15,140
We expect to have that access.

15
00:01:15,140 --> 00:01:17,920
We need to be able to set up and
get configured for it.

16
00:01:17,920 --> 00:01:22,510
Fortunately, Mac OS is a full
network operating system.

17
00:01:22,510 --> 00:01:26,370
It wasn't always like that,
all right, back in the old OS 9 and

18
00:01:26,370 --> 00:01:30,250
OS 8 days, the operating system back then,
it had networking support, but

19
00:01:30,250 --> 00:01:34,650
it wasn't built in as the original
idea for the operating system.

20
00:01:34,650 --> 00:01:37,900
The original Apples were designed
to be standalone units, and

21
00:01:37,900 --> 00:01:40,700
they added networking
kinda as an afterthought.

22
00:01:40,700 --> 00:01:43,800
Well, with OS 10, when we became OS X,

23
00:01:43,800 --> 00:01:48,510
right, that's when they switched to
having a Unix BSD core under the hood.

24
00:01:48,510 --> 00:01:50,980
And that operating system was designed,

25
00:01:50,980 --> 00:01:53,220
as a network operating
system from the beginning.

26
00:01:53,220 --> 00:01:56,040
And what that means is that now
we benefit from that, right?

27
00:01:56,040 --> 00:02:00,790
That Mac OS is a fully functional network
operating system that is very powerful.

28
00:02:00,790 --> 00:02:02,700
It can be an excellent client.

29
00:02:02,700 --> 00:02:03,760
As well as a server.

30
00:02:03,760 --> 00:02:06,730
There's a lot of stuff
that's located inside of it.

31
00:02:06,730 --> 00:02:10,270
Well, in this episode we're focused
more on just basic connectivity.

32
00:02:10,270 --> 00:02:13,730
We're gonna have another episode coming
up which is gonna be our network services

33
00:02:13,730 --> 00:02:17,110
where we're focused on all the different
little things we can provide on a network,

34
00:02:17,110 --> 00:02:21,590
but as far as basic connectivity, there's
two main areas we need to worry about.

35
00:02:21,590 --> 00:02:25,210
There's physical connectivity,
how we connect our Mac

36
00:02:25,210 --> 00:02:28,310
physically to whatever network it
is that we're gonna be on, and

37
00:02:28,310 --> 00:02:31,900
then there's logical connectivity,
the addressing that we use,

38
00:02:31,900 --> 00:02:35,019
the protocols that we use to
communicate between two computers.

39
00:02:36,400 --> 00:02:38,860
We need to take a look at some
of those different pieces.

40
00:02:38,860 --> 00:02:44,220
On the physical side, most of us are gonna
be connecting to a network via wireless,

41
00:02:44,220 --> 00:02:46,290
right, like 802-11 a,

42
00:02:46,290 --> 00:02:51,190
b, g, n, a, c, whatever standard is
out when you guys watch this episode.

43
00:02:51,190 --> 00:02:53,640
That's how we're gonna connect
to a wireless network which

44
00:02:53,640 --> 00:02:55,660
doesn't involve wires.

45
00:02:55,660 --> 00:02:57,700
But, thus the wireless name, I guess.

46
00:02:57,700 --> 00:03:00,530
But it is still considered
a physical connection medium.

47
00:03:00,530 --> 00:03:05,130
We're connecting to that network
via RF waves, radio frequency.

48
00:03:05,130 --> 00:03:08,390
The other option,
is to do a copper based connection.

49
00:03:08,390 --> 00:03:10,880
Right?
Where we plug in via a network cable of

50
00:03:10,880 --> 00:03:11,820
some sort.

51
00:03:11,820 --> 00:03:14,030
And that's usually common
if you have a desktop.

52
00:03:14,030 --> 00:03:17,650
If you're trying to do something that
requires a constant network connection,

53
00:03:17,650 --> 00:03:21,070
that's very reliable, you'll normally
use a physical network cable.

54
00:03:21,070 --> 00:03:24,770
Well apple devices, laptops,
desktops, they support all of that.

55
00:03:24,770 --> 00:03:26,800
We can do wired and wireless.

56
00:03:26,800 --> 00:03:27,300
That's easy.

57
00:03:28,780 --> 00:03:30,890
Once we connect to that network though.

58
00:03:30,890 --> 00:03:33,230
Now we need to deal with
the logical side of things.

59
00:03:33,230 --> 00:03:34,630
And on the logical side,

60
00:03:34,630 --> 00:03:39,440
most networks that are out there
are going to run IP version four.

61
00:03:39,440 --> 00:03:41,670
Internet Protocol version four, all right.

62
00:03:41,670 --> 00:03:44,013
And we normally here
refered to it as TCPIP.

63
00:03:44,013 --> 00:03:47,110
But TCPIP,
that's actually two different protocols,

64
00:03:47,110 --> 00:03:50,390
transmission control protocol and
Internet protocol.

65
00:03:50,390 --> 00:03:51,970
And we're gonna talk about
those in this episode.

66
00:03:51,970 --> 00:03:54,080
Make sure we have a good
understanding of what they are.

67
00:03:54,080 --> 00:03:57,538
But for right now,
let's just think about IPv4.

68
00:03:57,538 --> 00:04:01,128
IPv4, that's
the Internet Protocol Version 4,

69
00:04:01,128 --> 00:04:05,350
it's the most common network
protocol on the planet.

70
00:04:05,350 --> 00:04:09,460
It is a open protocol so
any vendor can support it and that means,

71
00:04:09,460 --> 00:04:13,880
if your Mac is running IPB4 and
there's a Linux machine running IPB4 and

72
00:04:13,880 --> 00:04:17,970
a Windows machine running IPB4,
and a refrigerator

73
00:04:17,970 --> 00:04:22,220
running IPB4 they can all talk to
each other cuz the common protocol.

74
00:04:22,220 --> 00:04:24,922
That makes it very attractive so
a lot of devices support it,

75
00:04:24,922 --> 00:04:29,580
now IPv4 has some problems I'll talk
about a little bit later, but it's being

76
00:04:29,580 --> 00:04:35,490
replaced with IPv6 and Mac OS was one of
the first operating systems to provide

77
00:04:35,490 --> 00:04:40,250
really good vendor support for IPv6.

78
00:04:40,250 --> 00:04:43,050
Apple got behind IPv6 pretty early on.

79
00:04:43,050 --> 00:04:45,140
And so we have good support for
that in here too.

80
00:04:45,140 --> 00:04:50,040
It's a lot less common than IPv4, but
it is out there and over the next five to

81
00:04:50,040 --> 00:04:53,920
ten years, we'll see people migrating
over to it and eventually replacing IPv4.

82
00:04:55,040 --> 00:04:56,470
But those aren't the only protocols.

83
00:04:56,470 --> 00:04:58,980
There's other protocols
that our Mac supports.

84
00:04:58,980 --> 00:05:00,520
Things like NetBios,

85
00:05:00,520 --> 00:05:04,510
which is an old Windows protocol that
we can use to communicate with them.

86
00:05:04,510 --> 00:05:08,980
There's Bonjour, which we'll learn about
later on, which is an Apple type protocol.

87
00:05:08,980 --> 00:05:12,600
There's Apple file-sharing or
Apple File Protocol, AFP.

88
00:05:12,600 --> 00:05:16,040
There's a bunch of other different
protocols that stack on to allow us

89
00:05:16,040 --> 00:05:17,100
to communicate.

90
00:05:17,100 --> 00:05:21,380
But under the hood most of our
communication is gonna happen with IPv4,

91
00:05:21,380 --> 00:05:21,890
or IPv6, right?

92
00:05:23,890 --> 00:05:27,410
Another one that I wanna mention, I don't
think it'll turn up on the exam, but

93
00:05:27,410 --> 00:05:32,430
your Mac still has support for things
like PPP, the Point-to-Point Protocol.

94
00:05:32,430 --> 00:05:36,740
Some of you, if you're younger, you might
not remember this, but if you're over 30,

95
00:05:36,740 --> 00:05:41,290
you probably remember having to dial up
via phone line to connect to the Internet.

96
00:05:41,290 --> 00:05:44,540
Maybe that was via AOL or
portage, or a local ISP but

97
00:05:44,540 --> 00:05:48,000
you dialed up via a phone line to connect.

98
00:05:48,000 --> 00:05:53,300
Well, regular protocols like IPv4 aren't
designed to go over a phone line, and

99
00:05:53,300 --> 00:05:57,560
so we had to leverage a special protocol
called PPP, Point to- Point Protocol,

100
00:05:57,560 --> 00:06:02,490
to be able to hide or encapsulated our
IPv4 traffic, send it across the phone

101
00:06:02,490 --> 00:06:05,760
line, and your Internet service
provider could then unencapsulate it,

102
00:06:05,760 --> 00:06:07,730
to release it on the network
on the other end.

103
00:06:07,730 --> 00:06:09,200
That protocol is still supported.

104
00:06:09,200 --> 00:06:11,790
If you still need to connect via modem,
you can.

105
00:06:11,790 --> 00:06:15,510
Now, I can't think of a single
Mac sold today that actually has

106
00:06:15,510 --> 00:06:18,720
an analog modem in it, so you'd have
to get like an external analog modem,

107
00:06:18,720 --> 00:06:20,680
or USB modem to hook up and use it.

108
00:06:20,680 --> 00:06:23,300
But you still can,
those protocols are still there.

109
00:06:23,300 --> 00:06:26,090
No reason for Apple to remove them so
they leave them.

110
00:06:26,090 --> 00:06:28,300
It's not as prominent as they use to be.

111
00:06:28,300 --> 00:06:32,640
We don't see them in a lot of
the menus but they are there.

112
00:06:32,640 --> 00:06:35,440
Well, I mentioned TCPIP.

113
00:06:35,440 --> 00:06:38,390
Before we start diving into
a lot of this stuff too crazy,

114
00:06:38,390 --> 00:06:43,530
I wanna spend some time on what TCPIP is,
and how it functions all right.

115
00:06:43,530 --> 00:06:48,390
TCPIP is the most common protocol that's
used and when we say TCPIP we're typically

116
00:06:48,390 --> 00:06:53,310
referring to IP version four right so
the most common protocol mechanism or

117
00:06:53,310 --> 00:06:57,340
communication that we can use that's out
there and what its designed to do is to

118
00:06:57,340 --> 00:07:02,600
facilitate, two computers finding
each other and talking, right?

119
00:07:02,600 --> 00:07:06,800
If you have two computers that are right
on the same network, they're local.

120
00:07:06,800 --> 00:07:08,560
They can talk directly to each other.

121
00:07:08,560 --> 00:07:09,360
There's no big deal.

122
00:07:11,115 --> 00:07:14,505
What if one computer is here
at the IT Pro TV studio, and

123
00:07:14,505 --> 00:07:17,245
the other computer is right there
at the desk in front of you?

124
00:07:17,245 --> 00:07:20,925
Well, we may be separated
by 100 of 1000's of miles.

125
00:07:20,925 --> 00:07:25,677
We may be separated by huge amounts
of Internet infrastructure.

126
00:07:25,677 --> 00:07:31,007
How do our two computers find each other,
well, that's where IPv4

127
00:07:31,007 --> 00:07:35,137
kicks in IPv4 uses a hierarchical
addressing structure that allows us to

128
00:07:35,137 --> 00:07:39,467
define networks and then be able to find
those networks if we need to get at them.

129
00:07:39,467 --> 00:07:42,067
And it's designed to scale very large.

130
00:07:42,067 --> 00:07:44,237
Now, I say it's designed
to scale very large.

131
00:07:44,237 --> 00:07:46,570
That's actually one of
the problems we have with IPv4.

132
00:07:46,570 --> 00:07:48,450
It's designed the scale very large.

133
00:07:48,450 --> 00:07:51,392
But not large enough, okay.

134
00:07:51,392 --> 00:07:55,293
Let's talk a little bit about the IPv4
addresses and I'll show you what I mean.

135
00:07:55,293 --> 00:08:00,342
Let me just bring up like a notepad Window
here, and I'll show you guys an example.

136
00:08:00,342 --> 00:08:03,802
When I have a computer that's
operating on an IPv4 network,

137
00:08:03,802 --> 00:08:06,940
it will have an address that
looks something like this.

138
00:08:06,940 --> 00:08:11,218
I might have 192.168.0.1.

139
00:08:11,218 --> 00:08:17,584
Or I might have 172.16.5.23 or

140
00:08:17,584 --> 00:08:23,277
209.251.159.188.

141
00:08:23,277 --> 00:08:25,770
Something of that nature.

142
00:08:25,770 --> 00:08:30,590
An IPv4 is written in what's
called a dotted decimal notation.

143
00:08:30,590 --> 00:08:31,930
It's broken into four pieces.

144
00:08:31,930 --> 00:08:35,430
So, I've got a number here,
192, and a dot, and

145
00:08:35,430 --> 00:08:39,280
then a 168, and a dot, and
a 0, and a dot, and a 1.

146
00:08:39,280 --> 00:08:41,980
So, it's written as dotted decimal.

147
00:08:41,980 --> 00:08:44,630
Well, that's how we see it as humans,

148
00:08:44,630 --> 00:08:47,670
because when it's written this way
it's somewhat easy to remember.

149
00:08:47,670 --> 00:08:51,210
The maximum amount of the numbers
we would have in there is 12, and

150
00:08:51,210 --> 00:08:52,210
12 numbers people can handle.

151
00:08:52,210 --> 00:08:56,330
We remember ten digit phone numbers pretty
easy, and it's just two extra digits.

152
00:08:56,330 --> 00:09:01,180
So, people can remember these IP addresses
pretty easily written the way they are.

153
00:09:01,180 --> 00:09:03,980
But your computer doesn't
wanna see it this way.

154
00:09:03,980 --> 00:09:06,950
Your computer will see it as binary.

155
00:09:06,950 --> 00:09:13,040
And when we write an IPv4 address in
binary, it's actually a 32-bit number.

156
00:09:13,040 --> 00:09:16,654
It's a 32-bit binary number
the way the system writes it.

157
00:09:16,654 --> 00:09:20,918
So if I were to take 192.168.0.1 for
example, and

158
00:09:20,918 --> 00:09:25,100
convert that to binary,

00:22:41,290 --> 00:22:44,830

00:23:14,500 --> 00:23:19,310

00:23:19,310 --> 00:23:20,140

00:23:20,140 --> 00:23:22,070
How do we get to that

00:23:22,070 --> 00:23:23,150
And that's where the router comes in.

404
00:23:24,810 --> 00:23:29,390

00:23:29,390 --> 00:23:32,170

406
00:23:32,170 --> 00:23:34,030
We're setting an address,

407
00:23:34,030 --> 00:23:38,990

408
00:23:40,640 --> 00:23:43,270
The address,
well that's the address of our machine.

409
00:23:43,270 --> 00:23:45,980
The IP address that our machine is using.

410
00:23:45,980 --> 00:23:49,770
The router,
that's the person we need to go to

411
00:23:49,770 --> 00:23:52,388
when we're talking to someone

00:23:52,388 --> 00:23:56,536
If I wanna get to a different network,

00:23:56,536 --> 00:24:00,633
I only know if somebody's on a different

00:24:00,633 --> 00:24:04,178
And I can figure that out

00:24:04,178 --> 00:24:08,814
Now the sub net mask is simply a number
That represents how many bits of my

00:24:08,814 --> 00:24:11,593
IP address, when we look at the bits here,

417
00:24:11,593 --> 00:24:15,320
how many bits of that IP address
match up with my network?

418
00:24:16,320 --> 00:24:20,820
And fortunately, there's really just

00:24:20,820 --> 00:24:23,800
They're based on this old class

00:24:24,670 --> 00:24:26,040
It doesn't exist anymore.

00:24:26,040 --> 00:24:29,340
But it's kind of stuck around as
far as the subnet mask that we use.

423
00:24:29,340 --> 00:24:32,840
What you'll see is that

424
00:24:32,840 --> 00:24:38,340
it'll normally be coupled with a subnet

00:24:38,340 --> 00:24:43,420
So these are Common Subnet Masks.

00:24:43,420 --> 00:24:49,246

00:24:49,246 --> 00:24:52,513
Or 255.0.0.0.

00:24:52,513 --> 00:24:53,750
All right,

00:24:53,750 --> 00:24:58,720

00:24:58,720 --> 00:25:01,700
And so it's saying these eight ones here,

431
00:25:01,700 --> 00:25:05,150
these eight bits are going to be
considered part of the network ID.

432
00:25:05,150 --> 00:25:06,260
And these next eight bits, and

433
00:25:06,260 --> 00:25:08,010
these eight next bits are all going
to be part of the network ID.

434
00:25:08,010 --> 00:25:10,980
And when you see a zero,
that's gonna be eight zeroes.

435
00:25:10,980 --> 00:25:13,000
And those eight zeroes
are part of the host ID.

436
00:25:13,000 --> 00:25:15,350
There's something that mask is telling us.

00:25:15,350 --> 00:25:20,290
What part of our address is our network

00:25:20,290 --> 00:25:23,680
So if this where my subnet mask, and

Where it really even bigger

00:28:25,230 --> 00:28:27,610

00:28:28,810 --> 00:28:31,120
That's how an IP address functions.

00:28:31,120 --> 00:28:36,760
You have an IP, you have a subnet mask,

00:52:11,580 --> 00:52:15,870

you use the IP

968
00:52:15,870 --> 00:52:19,090
address to determine if the other
person is on the same network as you.

969
00:52:19,090 --> 00:52:21,980

to communicate to them,

970
00:52:21,980 --> 00:52:25,870
you don't use the IP address,
you use what's called their mac address.

971
00:52:25,870 --> 00:52:30,530
And not mac as in macintosh but
mac as in media access control.

972
00:52:31,560 --> 00:52:33,610
Every network interface, be it wireless or

973
00:52:33,610 --> 00:52:37,550
wired, has a MAC address,
has a Media Access Control address.

974
00:52:38,590 --> 00:52:41,990
When they speak on those networks they're
using a protocol called Ethernet.

975
00:52:41,990 --> 00:52:46,780
And Ethernet uses media control to
determine who's allowed to talk when.

976
00:52:46,780 --> 00:52:52,130
And every frame, every set of data that
we throw on the network has to have

977
00:52:52,130 --> 00:52:56,370
a Mac address attached to it, a source Mac
address, where the data's coming from, and

978
00:52:56,370 --> 00:52:58,630
a destination Mac address,
where it's going to.

979
00:52:58,630 --> 00:53:01,270
Now, that sounds a little redundant,

00:53:01,270 --> 00:53:05,670
because if I'm communicating to
somebody out on the internet,

00:53:05,670 --> 00:53:10,500
I've got a source IP address, mine,
and a destination IP address, theirs.

982
00:53:10,500 --> 00:53:14,480
If I've already got a source and a
destination address, that's a IP address,

983
00:53:14,480 --> 00:53:17,650

address that's a Mac address also?

984
00:53:17,650 --> 00:53:19,530
Why have that duplication?

985
00:53:19,530 --> 00:53:23,640
Well, the reason is sometimes I
have data that's destined for

00:53:23,640 --> 00:53:28,120

00:53:28,120 --> 00:53:30,010

00:53:47,520 --> 00:53:50,360
But it's not on the same network as me,

00:53:50,360 --> 00:53:52,580
So, even though my data is destined for

00:53:52,580 --> 00:53:56,030
apple, I need to send it
to my router instead.

00:53:56,030 --> 00:53:58,000
And then my router will forward it along.

00:53:58,000 --> 00:54:03,100
So the IP address is the start and

00:54:03,100 --> 00:54:04,750

00:54:04,750 --> 00:54:09,030

00:54:09,030 --> 00:54:14,140

00:54:14,140 --> 00:54:17,440

00:59:19,980 --> 00:59:23,380

00:59:23,380 --> 00:59:27,710

00:59:27,710 --> 00:59:28,970

1109
00:59:53,300 --> 00:59:57,270

it sent out a broadcast on the network and

00:59:57,270 --> 01:00:02,300

01:41:56,930 --> 01:41:58,790
Well, I hope you guys
enjoyed today's show.

1961
01:41:58,790 --> 01:42:00,140
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1962
01:42:00,140 --> 01:42:01,907
And I'll see you next time.

1963
01:42:01,907 --> 01:42:11,907
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Network services are the things that one can use across a network once a connection is established. Viewers will hear about all the different things one can use a network for including different iCloud services like Back to My Mac, Find My Mac, and other sharing services featured on a local computer system.
episodes.title: Network Services
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,628 --> 00:00:36,296
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:36,296 --> 00:00:38,921
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,921 --> 00:00:41,902
I'm your host Don Pezet back
again with another episode

5
00:00:41,902 --> 00:00:44,255
of Apple Certified Support Professional.

6
00:00:44,255 --> 00:00:47,400
We're gonna be diving back in to
the world of networking in this episode.

7
00:00:47,400 --> 00:00:48,760
I know if you're watching
all these in order,

8
00:00:48,760 --> 00:00:51,700
our last episode was on
network configuration.

9
00:00:51,700 --> 00:00:54,430
But now we're gonna take
a look at network services.

10
00:00:54,430 --> 00:00:56,080
And what do I mean by network services?

11
00:00:56,080 --> 00:00:59,840
Well, once you've got network
connectivity, once you're plugged in or

12
00:00:59,840 --> 00:01:03,540
connected via wireless or whatever,
what do you do with your network?

13
00:01:03,540 --> 00:01:05,300
It's there, how do you use it?

14
00:01:05,300 --> 00:01:09,400
Well, network services are the things
that we can use across that network.

15
00:01:09,400 --> 00:01:12,770
And network services used to be
really basic, it used to be file and

16
00:01:12,770 --> 00:01:14,390
printer sharing and that was it.

17
00:01:14,390 --> 00:01:15,470
I could share files,

18
00:01:15,470 --> 00:01:18,710
I could share printers between
my machines and that was it.

19
00:01:18,710 --> 00:01:20,540
And then in came the Internet.

20
00:01:20,540 --> 00:01:22,480
And we started having these
like Web browsers, right?

21
00:01:22,480 --> 00:01:26,960
So we could get to Web pages and
FTP servers for file transfer.

22
00:01:26,960 --> 00:01:29,030
And now, now it's just gone crazy, right?

23
00:01:29,030 --> 00:01:32,010
We have all sorts of crazy services
that are available out there.

24
00:01:32,010 --> 00:01:33,060
And they're not crazy.

25
00:01:33,060 --> 00:01:34,160
They're all useful.

26
00:01:34,160 --> 00:01:35,450
It's just so diverse.

27
00:01:35,450 --> 00:01:36,680
We use the network for so

28
00:01:36,680 --> 00:01:40,200
many different things now that we never
even thought of years and years ago.

29
00:01:40,200 --> 00:01:42,160
That it's really pretty amazing.

30
00:01:42,160 --> 00:01:46,030
So as a result, we end up having an entire
show like this one where we focus on

31
00:01:46,030 --> 00:01:48,380
the various things that we
can use the network for.

32
00:01:48,380 --> 00:01:51,760
And how we can do a basic figuration for
them, all right?

33
00:01:51,760 --> 00:01:54,930
Now, the first one that I'm gonna cover,
is probably the most important one.

34
00:01:54,930 --> 00:01:57,040
It's the one that Apple's
the most proud of.

35
00:01:57,040 --> 00:01:58,503
It's iCloud.

36
00:01:58,503 --> 00:02:01,970
One of the big challenges you have
with network services is getting them

37
00:02:01,970 --> 00:02:03,800
configured properly.

38
00:02:03,800 --> 00:02:04,920
When you have a network service,

39
00:02:04,920 --> 00:02:07,900
it's typically what's called
a client server model.

40
00:02:07,900 --> 00:02:12,420
That means that there's a server somewhere
that's actually running the service.

41
00:02:12,420 --> 00:02:15,000
And then you've got all your
various clients that connect to it.

42
00:02:15,000 --> 00:02:18,211
So for example if I'm doing file sharing,
there's a server somewhere.

43
00:02:18,211 --> 00:02:20,340
And by server,
that might be a workstation.

44
00:02:20,340 --> 00:02:23,253
It doesn't have to be some
hardcore piece of machinery.

45
00:02:23,253 --> 00:02:25,170
It could just be a laptop.

46
00:02:25,170 --> 00:02:28,130
It's serving up a shared folder.

47
00:02:28,130 --> 00:02:30,709
And all the clients on the network
scan and find that shared folder and

48
00:02:30,709 --> 00:02:31,295
connect to it.

49
00:02:31,295 --> 00:02:32,815
They're clients, they depend on it, right?

50
00:02:32,815 --> 00:02:34,830
Client-server model.

51
00:02:34,830 --> 00:02:37,350
So, that's normally what we have.

52
00:02:37,350 --> 00:02:41,020
But there are some services that
are what are called peer-to-peer.

53
00:02:41,020 --> 00:02:43,300
Where the clients just
connect to each other,

54
00:02:43,300 --> 00:02:45,250
and neither one of them is the server.

55
00:02:45,250 --> 00:02:47,240
No one client acts as that server role,

56
00:02:47,240 --> 00:02:50,500
everyone works together in kinda
like a communist environment, right?

57
00:02:50,500 --> 00:02:52,694
It's all everybody's treated equally,
right?

58
00:02:52,694 --> 00:02:55,142
Well, either model, client-server or

59
00:02:55,142 --> 00:02:59,220
client-to-client, the biggest challenge
is getting this set up, right?

60
00:02:59,220 --> 00:03:01,900
And if we're dealing with networks and
firewalls and

61
00:03:01,900 --> 00:03:05,430
routers and all the different
things that go in between our PCs,

62
00:03:05,430 --> 00:03:08,160
well we might end up in an environment
where we can't communicate, and

63
00:03:08,160 --> 00:03:10,800
then we gotta troubleshoot it and
figure it out.

64
00:03:10,800 --> 00:03:14,730
And so what Apple did is they stepped
in and said well, what if we do this?

65
00:03:14,730 --> 00:03:16,350
What if we provide the service?

66
00:03:16,350 --> 00:03:20,400
What if Apple provides that service
out on the Internet in the cloud?

67
00:03:20,400 --> 00:03:24,060
And then you don't have to worry about
setting it up and crazy configurations.

68
00:03:24,060 --> 00:03:25,753
You just connect up to our cloud.

69
00:03:25,753 --> 00:03:29,420
And it won't matter if you're at home or
at work or traveling.

70
00:03:29,420 --> 00:03:32,140
You'll always be able to connect to
that cloud service and have access.

71
00:03:32,140 --> 00:03:35,176
And if you lose your laptop or
your hard drive fails, well,

72
00:03:35,176 --> 00:03:37,628
all your data was up there in the cloud,
right?

73
00:03:37,628 --> 00:03:39,480
Centralized communications.

74
00:03:39,480 --> 00:03:42,540
Now iCloud has grown a lot
over the last few years.

75
00:03:42,540 --> 00:03:44,260
And they've expanded the services on it.

76
00:03:44,260 --> 00:03:48,350
So let's go over some of the services
that are supported inside of Yosemite.

77
00:03:48,350 --> 00:03:50,700
Assuming that we connect to iCloud, right?

78
00:03:50,700 --> 00:03:52,440
So I've got a workstation
here running Yosemite.

79
00:03:52,440 --> 00:03:56,340
And I'm just gonna jump
into my System Preferences.

80
00:03:56,340 --> 00:03:59,600
And we have a dedicated
iCloud system preference.

81
00:03:59,600 --> 00:04:01,740
It used to be tucked away
under Internet Accounts, but

82
00:04:01,740 --> 00:04:03,880
now it's got own dedicated thing.

83
00:04:03,880 --> 00:04:06,960
And I'm just gonna just jump right
into that iCloud preference.

84
00:04:06,960 --> 00:04:09,950
Now, if I haven't signed in with an Apple
ID, it's gonna prompt me at this point.

85
00:04:09,950 --> 00:04:11,880
If you don't have one
you'll need to create one.

86
00:04:11,880 --> 00:04:15,170
Because we're connecting to Apple's
servers, we've gotta authenticate.

87
00:04:15,170 --> 00:04:18,390
There's millions of users that
are on these servers also.

88
00:04:18,390 --> 00:04:20,650
You wanna keep your data separate and
safe.

89
00:04:20,650 --> 00:04:22,110
So you gotta pick an account.

90
00:04:22,110 --> 00:04:24,530
If you don't have one you can
choose create an Apple ID.

91
00:04:24,530 --> 00:04:27,300
It's free.
You create an account and off you go.

92
00:04:27,300 --> 00:04:31,120
If you already have one though, you can
just punch that information in here and

93
00:04:31,120 --> 00:04:31,630
get logged in.

94
00:04:33,000 --> 00:04:35,150
I'm gonna go ahead and
get logged into that service.

95
00:04:35,150 --> 00:04:39,460
And as soon as I'm in then
I'll be able to customize it.

96
00:04:39,460 --> 00:04:42,260
Now when you first connect to iCloud,
if you haven't

97
00:04:42,260 --> 00:04:46,045
set it up before you might see an end user
license agreement, a few other things.

98
00:04:46,045 --> 00:04:49,005
It's actually asking me if I
wanna configure some of the basic

99
00:04:49,005 --> 00:04:50,477
services right here.

100
00:04:50,477 --> 00:04:52,325
All right, I'll go ahead and
just go with the default.

101
00:04:52,325 --> 00:04:56,425
And you see how it says use iCloud for
contacts, calendars, reminders, and

102
00:04:56,425 --> 00:04:59,205
Safari, and use Find My Mac.

103
00:04:59,205 --> 00:05:02,680
Well, those are a few basic
services that are a part of iCloud.

104
00:05:02,680 --> 00:05:03,990
Most of them are self-explanatory.

105
00:05:03,990 --> 00:05:04,860
Contacts.

106
00:05:04,860 --> 00:05:08,420
Well down here in Yosemite,
I've got a Contacts application, and

107
00:05:08,420 --> 00:05:11,630
inside of it will be all the people that
I communicate with, email addresses,

108
00:05:11,630 --> 00:05:13,400
phone numbers, and so on.

109
00:05:13,400 --> 00:05:16,960
By default that's stored in
your user profile on your Mac.

110
00:05:16,960 --> 00:05:19,320
And if you have two or
three Macs, you've got two or

111
00:05:19,320 --> 00:05:21,300
three separate sets of contacts.

112
00:05:21,300 --> 00:05:24,190
But if we use iCloud for
it, our contacts will

113
00:05:24,190 --> 00:05:27,700
synchronize across all the machines that
are logged in with our iCloud account.

114
00:05:27,700 --> 00:05:30,270
So now we just have one contact database.

115
00:05:30,270 --> 00:05:33,040
And if we don't have access to our
computer, we can always go to iCloud's

116
00:05:33,040 --> 00:05:37,090
website, www.icloud.com, log in,
and add access to those contacts.

117
00:05:38,370 --> 00:05:40,920
The same thing goes for
calendars and reminders, right?

118
00:05:40,920 --> 00:05:42,750
The calendar items that we set.

119
00:05:42,750 --> 00:05:45,398
And Safari, for our bookmarks,
so if I have a bunch

120
00:05:45,398 --> 00:05:49,342
of really cool bookmarks on my desktop,
they synchronize to my laptop, and

121
00:05:49,342 --> 00:05:52,503
even to our mobile devices,
our iPhones and iPads, right.

122
00:05:52,503 --> 00:05:55,130
So, it synchronizes across all of that,
which is pretty slick stuff.

123
00:05:56,700 --> 00:05:58,090
And then Find My Mac.

124
00:05:58,090 --> 00:06:00,260
This is one that's really useful.

125
00:06:00,260 --> 00:06:02,900
Have you ever lost your cell phone or
lost your iPad?

126
00:06:02,900 --> 00:06:05,070
Can't remember where your laptop is?

127
00:06:05,070 --> 00:06:06,120
It just happened to me the other day.

128
00:06:06,120 --> 00:06:09,850
The other day I was at home and
my son said can I use your iPad, Dad?

129
00:06:09,850 --> 00:06:11,850
And I said oh, sure, and
he asked where it was.

130
00:06:11,850 --> 00:06:13,630
I said well I don't remember.

131
00:06:13,630 --> 00:06:14,970
I don't remember where it is.

132
00:06:14,970 --> 00:06:16,980
It might be in the car,
it might be in my bedroom.

133
00:06:16,980 --> 00:06:21,205
And so I went on my laptop,
fired it up, connected into iCloud,

134
00:06:21,205 --> 00:06:23,220
and I did Find My Mac.

135
00:06:23,220 --> 00:06:25,290
And I went to look to
find out where it was.

136
00:06:25,290 --> 00:06:27,520
Actually I think I pulled it up on
my cellphone if I remember, right?

137
00:06:27,520 --> 00:06:29,650
So I was on my iPhone and
I went to Find My Mac.

138
00:06:29,650 --> 00:06:34,530
And I pulled my iPad up on there, and
it showed it right here at the office.

139
00:06:34,530 --> 00:06:37,472
And so I knew it was at the office and I
didn't have to worry about it being stolen

140
00:06:37,472 --> 00:06:40,253
and off in the middle of nowhere,
I can see it was right here at the office.

141
00:06:40,253 --> 00:06:42,290
And that's really cool stuff.

142
00:06:42,290 --> 00:06:45,461
It is somewhat limited in Yosemite though.

143
00:06:45,461 --> 00:06:48,265
And one of the basic functions
you have to have in order for

144
00:06:48,265 --> 00:06:50,440
this to work is a GPS location.

145
00:06:50,440 --> 00:06:52,450
If you don't have a GPS
location it's not gonna work.

146
00:06:52,450 --> 00:06:55,370
So if you have an older Mac with
no GPS service or if you're not

147
00:06:55,370 --> 00:06:59,020
connected to any wireless network,
it's not gonna work very well, is it?

148
00:06:59,020 --> 00:07:03,016
On an iPhone or iPad you've got GPS,
you've got location and wireless services,

149
00:07:03,016 --> 00:07:04,170
you know you have that.

150
00:07:04,170 --> 00:07:06,510
So really incredibly useful there.

151
00:07:06,510 --> 00:07:08,878
On a desktop you don't
normally have GPS service.

152
00:07:08,878 --> 00:07:12,336
You don't normally use wireless, and
so those it's harder for it to locate.

153
00:07:12,336 --> 00:07:14,628
On a laptop though if you have
a newer Mac, then it will.

154
00:07:14,628 --> 00:07:16,740
And you'll be able to
find them pretty easy.

155
00:07:16,740 --> 00:07:18,461
So I'm gonna go ahead and
turn those options on.

156
00:07:18,461 --> 00:07:21,400
Now be careful with this option here,
Find My Mac.

157
00:07:21,400 --> 00:07:24,850
If you have more than one
user account on the laptop,

158
00:07:24,850 --> 00:07:30,810
Find My Mac can only tie
a Mac to one iCloud account.

159
00:07:30,810 --> 00:07:34,560
So if I have five users
with five iCloud accounts,

160
00:07:34,560 --> 00:07:37,460
I can only Find My Mac to one of them,
all right?

161
00:07:37,460 --> 00:07:41,100
So you need to pick like an administrator
account, or some centralized account.

162
00:07:41,100 --> 00:07:44,700
And if one of those five users loses
the device they can't look it up.

163
00:07:44,700 --> 00:07:47,070
They have to come to the administrator and
say hey can you look it up and

164
00:07:47,070 --> 00:07:48,555
see where my device is and
they'll find it.

165
00:07:48,555 --> 00:07:49,679
Just be aware of that.

166
00:07:49,679 --> 00:07:50,850
If you don't share your laptop.

167
00:07:50,850 --> 00:07:51,910
I don't share my laptop.

168
00:07:51,910 --> 00:07:55,741
I'm the only that uses it so I just tie
it to my iCloud account and that's that.

169
00:07:55,741 --> 00:07:57,987
But if you do share it,
like a family device,

170
00:07:57,987 --> 00:08:00,248
you'll have to pick one
account to tie it to.

171
00:08:00,248 --> 00:08:02,895
All right, I'll go ahead and
hit Next on that.

172
00:08:02,895 --> 00:08:07,040
And it's gonna turn on iCloud for
my device and get it connected.

173
00:08:07,040 --> 00:08:09,170
Now when it gets setup,

174
00:08:10,200 --> 00:08:15,350
it's asked me to punch in my Apple ID
password to set up my iCloud Keychain.

175
00:08:15,350 --> 00:08:17,950
We have a keychain on our computer
normally that's storing our

176
00:08:17,950 --> 00:08:20,510
user credentials for our local access.

177
00:08:20,510 --> 00:08:22,710
iCloud has a keychain also.

178
00:08:22,710 --> 00:08:26,600
And we can synchronize our local
credentials with the iCloud credentials so

179
00:08:26,600 --> 00:08:29,120
that it will then synchronize
across all of our computers.

180
00:08:29,120 --> 00:08:31,390
You may or
may not want that functionality but

181
00:08:31,390 --> 00:08:33,620
if you're gonna use Find My Mac
you're gonna need it.

182
00:08:33,620 --> 00:08:36,780
So I need to punch in my password
here again so it'll have that.

183
00:08:38,020 --> 00:08:39,480
And store it in the keychain so

184
00:08:39,480 --> 00:08:42,120
that it'll be able to access
this service automatically.

185
00:08:42,120 --> 00:08:46,100
Basically when the computer turns on,
it needs to be able to reach out and

186
00:08:46,100 --> 00:08:49,980
report location information,
even before I log in.

187
00:08:49,980 --> 00:08:53,820
So my keychain might be locked
because I'm not logged in yet.

188
00:08:53,820 --> 00:08:55,990
It still needs to be able
to reach out to do it.

189
00:08:55,990 --> 00:08:59,550
If I don't do that,
if I don't give it the ability to do that,

190
00:08:59,550 --> 00:09:02,970
what's gonna happen is,
my computer's gonna turn on.

191
00:09:02,970 --> 00:09:05,770
And if I don't login,
it's not gonna report data.

192
00:09:05,770 --> 00:09:09,610
It's not gonna report whether
the system is at my office, or

193
00:09:09,610 --> 00:09:10,840
being sold on eBay right now.

194
00:09:10,840 --> 00:09:12,747
I won't know that because it
can't report back in, right.

195
00:09:14,360 --> 00:09:17,720
Now when you set this up, you do need
to set up a PIN number for iCloud.

196
00:09:17,720 --> 00:09:22,230
So I'll have to punch in some kind of
PIN number to use for that system so

197
00:09:22,230 --> 00:09:23,320
I will punch one in.

198
00:09:23,320 --> 00:09:25,908
By default it's a four-digit
numeric security code.

199
00:09:25,908 --> 00:09:27,940
If you wanna go more advanced
you can hit Advance and

200
00:09:27,940 --> 00:09:30,280
you can put in a bigger PIN number or
even letters.

201
00:09:30,280 --> 00:09:31,680
You can do all sorts
of crazy things there.

202
00:09:32,930 --> 00:09:34,945
And I just have to verify it and
make sure I got it right.

203
00:09:36,675 --> 00:09:38,215
All right, and then it's asking for

204
00:09:38,215 --> 00:09:41,095
a phone number that can
receive text messages.

205
00:09:41,095 --> 00:09:44,165
If I ever lose this device or
need to do verification for iCloud,

206
00:09:44,165 --> 00:09:46,115
it can send me a text message with a code.

207
00:09:46,115 --> 00:09:49,575
This is like a second factor, or
a dual factor authentication.

208
00:09:49,575 --> 00:09:52,720
If somebody tries to log in with
iCloud on another computer,

209
00:09:52,720 --> 00:09:54,888
they'll need my username and password.

210
00:09:54,888 --> 00:09:58,403
And the verification code that
gets sent to me via text, so

211
00:09:58,403 --> 00:10:01,367
we'd need both pieces of information,
right?

212
00:10:01,367 --> 00:10:03,820
I'll just put in my office number here.

213
00:10:03,820 --> 00:10:05,800
Let's see if I can punch that in.

214
00:10:05,800 --> 00:10:06,300
There we go.

215
00:10:07,740 --> 00:10:10,940
We'll get that on, and now it's enabled.

216
00:10:10,940 --> 00:10:14,920
Now iCloud is turned on, and I can see
Contacts, Calendars, Reminders and Safari,

217
00:10:14,920 --> 00:10:16,410
just like in that menu.

218
00:10:16,410 --> 00:10:17,900
Those were each of those options.

219
00:10:17,900 --> 00:10:20,140
And down at the bottom
I've got Find My Mac.

220
00:10:20,140 --> 00:10:22,730
The only one that wasn't on that
default screen was Keychain, but

221
00:10:22,730 --> 00:10:24,000
we saw those options, right?

222
00:10:24,000 --> 00:10:25,780
So Keychain synchronization is on.

223
00:10:25,780 --> 00:10:27,390
I could turn that off, but

224
00:10:27,390 --> 00:10:31,230
just be aware that your laptop won't
synchronize until after you log in.

And so as I start to navigate through

Apple Remote Desktop is kind of like

01:07:45,980 --> 01:07:50,934

01:08:01,760 --> 01:08:02,840

01:08:02,840 --> 01:08:06,850

01:08:06,850 --> 01:08:08,960

01:08:10,960 --> 01:08:12,740

01:08:12,740 --> 01:08:16,070

1361
01:08:16,070 --> 01:08:17,900
That Mac is now invisible.

1362
01:08:17,900 --> 01:08:22,300
When that Mac sends communications out,
the replies will be allowed to come back

1363
01:08:22,300 --> 01:08:25,650
in, but
otherwise it's not responding to these.

1364
01:08:25,650 --> 01:08:29,310
Now it's not completely invisible

1365
01:08:29,310 --> 01:08:31,100
So Bonjour discovery is still gonna work.

1366
01:08:31,100 --> 01:08:33,340
All the service discovery,

01:08:33,340 --> 01:08:35,220
People will find my shared folders and

01:08:35,220 --> 01:08:36,720
But that's stuff that I've allowed.

01:08:36,720 --> 01:08:40,350
If you wanna be truly invisible you've

1370
01:08:40,350 --> 01:08:41,450
Turn all that stuff off.

1371
01:08:41,450 --> 01:08:42,900
Turn off the iCloud functionality.

1372
01:08:42,900 --> 01:08:45,090
And now you are invisible.

1373
01:08:45,090 --> 01:08:48,080
Now when you send a request
out you'll get replies but

1374
01:08:48,080 --> 01:08:50,380
nobody will even see you
to send messages to you.

1375
01:08:50,380 --> 01:08:52,360
It's useful if you're somewhere

1376
01:08:52,360 --> 01:08:55,790
You don't want all that access

1377
01:08:58,110 --> 01:09:00,550
But that can also be part of the problem.

1378
01:09:00,550 --> 01:09:03,020
If you're not able to connect to

1379
01:09:03,020 --> 01:09:06,760

1380
01:09:06,760 --> 01:09:09,220

1381
01:09:09,220 --> 01:09:12,810

1382
01:09:12,810 --> 01:09:15,460
They might not be allowing
file sharing to pass through,

1383
01:09:15,460 --> 01:09:17,560
they might not be allowing

1384
01:09:17,560 --> 01:09:18,320
And that can be a problem.

1385
01:09:19,910 --> 01:09:22,900
There's also this automatically

1386
01:09:22,900 --> 01:09:23,670
incoming connections.

1387
01:09:24,690 --> 01:09:27,840
If we install software
that's digitally signed,

1388
01:09:27,840 --> 01:09:32,050
like from the App Store, then it will
automatically be allowed into the firewall

1389
01:09:32,050 --> 01:09:33,880
to be able to receive
those communications.

1390
01:09:34,890 --> 01:09:36,920
And again, I may or may not want that.

1391
01:09:36,920 --> 01:09:39,850
If it's from the App Store it's probably
safe, it's probably okay to allow it.

1392
01:09:39,850 --> 01:09:41,710
But I said probably more
than once in that sentence.

1393
01:09:41,710 --> 01:09:44,680
So if you don't like that you can
turn it off, and now you're saying,

1394
01:09:44,680 --> 01:09:46,310
I don't care if it's signed or not.

1395
01:09:46,310 --> 01:09:49,449
I wanna manually add it to the list
if I want it, otherwise, don't.

1396
01:09:51,936 --> 01:09:55,740
The other option is to block
all incoming connections.

1397
01:09:55,740 --> 01:10:00,340
That effectively shuts down any inbound
connections, including Bonjour,

1398
01:10:00,340 --> 01:10:02,110
including all the various things.

1399
01:10:02,110 --> 01:10:06,120
That are available on the system,
you now become basically shut down.

1400
01:10:06,120 --> 01:10:10,100
You can still send outbound
communications, but inbound communications

1401
01:10:10,100 --> 01:10:14,310
are not gonna be allowed, and
some protocols will no longer function.

1402
01:10:14,310 --> 01:10:17,860
Protocols that do port switching,
like FTP, where it starts on one port and

1403
01:10:17,860 --> 01:10:19,850
jumps to another, that's broken.

1404
01:10:19,850 --> 01:10:23,650
Most VPN tunnels will be broken,
but general web access, email,

1405
01:10:23,650 --> 01:10:27,120
that stuff will work still even though
we blocked incoming connections.

1406
01:10:27,120 --> 01:10:28,530
You send out your outbound messages,

1407
01:10:28,530 --> 01:10:31,730
they come back in on the same ports,
and it works.

1408
01:10:31,730 --> 01:10:34,220
So interesting type of setup there.

1409
01:10:34,220 --> 01:10:36,780
Not something that most
of us are gonna use, and

1410
01:10:36,780 --> 01:10:38,950
that can really break things
if we're not careful.

01:10:41,790 --> 01:10:43,990

01:10:43,990 --> 01:10:44,760

01:10:48,630 --> 01:10:50,948

01:11:01,790 --> 01:11:03,480

1424
01:11:12,080 --> 01:11:17,470

1425
01:11:17,470 --> 01:11:21,040
If we want to test one of the tools
I like to use is ping, and

1426
01:11:21,040 --> 01:11:25,050
normally I would use the network utility,
I can go into the network utility and

1427
01:11:25,050 --> 01:11:28,210
I can go to ping, and

1429
01:11:32,970 --> 01:11:35,910
But I start by pinging myself.

1430
01:11:37,180 --> 01:11:39,770
If you ping yourself, you have
what's called a loop back address.

1431
01:11:39,770 --> 01:11:46,315
The address is just your computer by
itself and if you ping it's 127.0.0.1.

1432
01:11:46,315 --> 01:11:50,085
This ping does not use your
network adaptors at all.

1433
01:11:50,085 --> 01:11:51,536
It just uses software on your computer.

1434
01:11:51,536 --> 01:11:57,161
So when you ping 127.0.0.1,
you're testing your TCPIP software.

1435
01:11:57,161 --> 01:12:03,255
If you get responses, Then you know your
software is working properly, right?

1436

That it's not like a corrupt OS, let me

01:12:34,860 --> 01:12:38,570

this is actually gonna hit the network

01:12:42,530 --> 01:12:47,680

01:14:16,750 --> 01:14:19,750
