01:18:55,288 --> 01:19:05,288
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Peripheral devices are accessories or devices that can be added on to a Mac that make it expandable like mice and keyboards, cameras, charging devices, printers, and external storage devices. Viewers will hear about peripheral devices and different ways to connect those devices through options like Bluetooth, FireWire, Thunderbolt, USB, and etc.
episodes.title: Peripheral Devices
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,297 --> 00:00:36,125
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:36,125 --> 00:00:38,720
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,720 --> 00:00:40,330
I'm your host Don Pezet,

5
00:00:40,330 --> 00:00:44,080
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

6
00:00:44,080 --> 00:00:47,910
We're starting to wind things down now
as we move into the final objective

7
00:00:47,910 --> 00:00:52,580
area inside of this exam as we take
a look at managing our system.

8
00:00:52,580 --> 00:00:57,870
In this episode, what we're going to is we
are gonna focus in on peripheral devices.

9
00:00:57,870 --> 00:01:00,900
When you buy a Mac,
Apple kind of has an idea

10
00:01:00,900 --> 00:01:05,330
of what is the most common set of hardware
that a regular user's going to need.

11
00:01:05,330 --> 00:01:09,560
And so when you buy that MacBook or
that iMac or that Mac Mini,

12
00:01:09,560 --> 00:01:12,860
it's already got the basic components
in there that you're going to need.

13
00:01:12,860 --> 00:01:16,230
It's got a hard drive for storage,
and it might be a magnetic drive or

14
00:01:16,230 --> 00:01:19,030
it might be solid state, but
it's got storage of some sort.

15
00:01:19,030 --> 00:01:19,910
It's got memory.

16
00:01:19,910 --> 00:01:21,030
It's got a video card.

17
00:01:21,030 --> 00:01:22,500
It's got network cards.

18
00:01:22,500 --> 00:01:26,420
It might have a physical
copper-based plug-in network card or

19
00:01:26,420 --> 00:01:28,700
it might have a wireless card or
it might have both.

20
00:01:28,700 --> 00:01:29,830
It might have Bluetooth.

21
00:01:29,830 --> 00:01:35,240
It might have various other things that
Apple assumes the general user will need.

22
00:01:36,380 --> 00:01:39,880
But the problem is,
not everybody is a general user.

23
00:01:39,880 --> 00:01:42,250
Different people have different needs, and

24
00:01:42,250 --> 00:01:46,960
so all of the Apple devices sold
today are designed to be expandable.

25
00:01:46,960 --> 00:01:48,040
Well, I say all of them.

26
00:01:48,040 --> 00:01:49,280
Maybe not the iPhones and iPads.

27
00:01:49,280 --> 00:01:51,110
Those are pretty well locked down.

28
00:01:51,110 --> 00:01:54,230
But as far as your MacBooks,
your Mac Pros and

29
00:01:54,230 --> 00:01:57,470
your Mac Minis,
they're designed to be expandable.

30
00:01:57,470 --> 00:02:01,180
Now in the old days when we bought
a computer, if it was expandable, right?

31
00:02:01,180 --> 00:02:06,340
If you remember the old G4 Macs and those
things, they were these big desktops and

32
00:02:06,340 --> 00:02:09,840
you could pop open the side and you could
add cards and add hard drives inside them,

33
00:02:09,840 --> 00:02:12,240
and you could do that without
voiding your warranty.

34
00:02:12,240 --> 00:02:16,720
But on these newer devices, like my laptop
here, it's not designed to be opened.

35
00:02:16,720 --> 00:02:19,220
I can't crack this thing open and
add hardware to it.

36
00:02:19,220 --> 00:02:22,720
Or if you buy one of those new Mac Pros
where it's shaped like a trash can

37
00:02:22,720 --> 00:02:23,670
you're not supposed to open those.

38
00:02:23,670 --> 00:02:27,250
There's no room to add
things inside of it.

39
00:02:27,250 --> 00:02:28,890
So how do we expand our Mac?

40
00:02:28,890 --> 00:02:32,580
How do we add more to it
to get it to do more stuff?

41
00:02:32,580 --> 00:02:37,040
We do it through some of the expansion
buses that are included on your device.

42
00:02:37,040 --> 00:02:40,840
The most common one of those is USB,
but we've got other ways, too.

43
00:02:40,840 --> 00:02:42,210
FireWire, Thunderbolt,

44
00:02:42,210 --> 00:02:47,460
Bluetooth, all these different ways of
attaching devices to your computer.

45
00:02:47,460 --> 00:02:50,130
Now when I say attaching devices,
what am I talking about here?

46
00:02:50,130 --> 00:02:52,500
Well, it can be a range of things.

47
00:02:52,500 --> 00:02:55,000
Right here,
just looking at my laptop on the show,

48
00:02:55,000 --> 00:02:57,390
I've got a couple of cables
sticking out of my laptop.

49
00:02:57,390 --> 00:03:02,080
I've got a Thunderbolt cable, over on
my left side, which is a network jack.

50
00:03:02,080 --> 00:03:04,890
So I've got a physical network
cable running into Thunderbolt.

51
00:03:04,890 --> 00:03:08,930
On the right side of my computer, I've
got a little USB dongle that's adding my

52
00:03:08,930 --> 00:03:13,375
trackball, because I'm not a big
fan of touchpads, so I've got this

53
00:03:13,375 --> 00:03:17,230
trackball that I use throughout the show,
and that's connected in via USB.

54
00:03:17,230 --> 00:03:21,330
I've got an HDMI cable in here,
which is how I'm sharing my screen.

55
00:03:21,330 --> 00:03:24,140
You guys are actually seeing
the HDMI output of my laptop when

56
00:03:24,140 --> 00:03:25,460
we share that screen out.

57
00:03:25,460 --> 00:03:29,480
So these are things that
I've added on to the system.

58
00:03:29,480 --> 00:03:30,700
They didn't come with it.

59
00:03:30,700 --> 00:03:31,840
It didn't come with a trackball.

60
00:03:31,840 --> 00:03:33,930
It didn't come with
an external adapter like this.

61
00:03:33,930 --> 00:03:37,420
I had to add those on to it to be
able to get that functionality.

62
00:03:37,420 --> 00:03:41,440
Those are peripherals, and
peripherals can be far,

63
00:03:41,440 --> 00:03:44,110
far more things than that,
right, based on your needs.

64
00:03:44,110 --> 00:03:47,570
Just as an example,
let's go to Apple's website here.

65
00:03:47,570 --> 00:03:50,230
So if I fire up Apple's website and

66
00:03:50,230 --> 00:03:55,500
go into the Apple Store,
you'll see where we can buy Macs,

67
00:03:55,500 --> 00:04:00,090
iPhones, iPads, and all the way on
the right here we've got Shop Accessories.

68
00:04:00,090 --> 00:04:03,530
These accessories are peripherals,
things we can add on.

69
00:04:03,530 --> 00:04:06,713
So here's the goPro cameras,
the AirPort wireless,

70
00:04:06,713 --> 00:04:10,460
then they've got bags and stuff,
that doesn't really count.

71
00:04:10,460 --> 00:04:15,020
But you'll see other things in here
like charging devices and fitness and

72
00:04:15,020 --> 00:04:17,070
sports stuff we can add on.

73
00:04:17,070 --> 00:04:21,270
Memory, some devices are still able to be
opened and you can add memory into them.

74
00:04:21,270 --> 00:04:25,030
For example, the Mac Minis that
were made up until this year,

75
00:04:25,030 --> 00:04:27,500
you could add more RAM into
them if you wanted to.

76
00:04:27,500 --> 00:04:29,890
The newer Mac Minis,
the memory is soldered in.

77
00:04:29,890 --> 00:04:31,090
You can't upgrade it anymore.

78
00:04:31,090 --> 00:04:32,950
So some of them have add-ons there.

79
00:04:32,950 --> 00:04:37,230
We've got Mice & Keyboards,
a lot of people use mice and keyboards.

80
00:04:37,230 --> 00:04:40,740
But then there's Music Creation,
so what's that all about?

81
00:04:40,740 --> 00:04:42,270
Well, I don't create music.

82
00:04:42,270 --> 00:04:43,770
It's not something I do.

83
00:04:43,770 --> 00:04:46,320
I have very, very little musical talent.

84
00:04:46,320 --> 00:04:47,480
Actually that's probably
a lie right there.

85
00:04:47,480 --> 00:04:49,720
I have absolutely no
musical talent whatsoever.

86
00:04:49,720 --> 00:04:51,290
So I have no interest in that.

87
00:04:51,290 --> 00:04:55,260
So what's under Music Creation is probably
not anything that I'm ever going to use.

88
00:04:55,260 --> 00:04:59,840
But there's other people out there,
that are DJs or producers or

89
00:04:59,840 --> 00:05:02,970
whatever, and
they need high-quality microphones.

90
00:05:02,970 --> 00:05:04,560
They need guitar input.

91
00:05:04,560 --> 00:05:07,170
They have a guitar they want to be able
to feed that right into their Mac so

92
00:05:07,170 --> 00:05:10,120
they can record with Garage Band and
do multi-track recording.

93
00:05:10,120 --> 00:05:11,440
They need that.

94
00:05:11,440 --> 00:05:13,000
Your average user doesn't.

95
00:05:13,000 --> 00:05:17,110
So Apple would be wasting money to put
that in every single laptop they sold

96
00:05:17,110 --> 00:05:19,390
when just a small fraction
of the people need it.

97
00:05:19,390 --> 00:05:23,540
So instead, they leave it up
to peripheral manufacturers.

98
00:05:23,540 --> 00:05:25,140
Notice this one says JAM.

99
00:05:25,140 --> 00:05:26,670
It's from a company called Apogee.

100
00:05:26,670 --> 00:05:29,350
This is not actually made by Apple.

101
00:05:29,350 --> 00:05:33,880
A company has made this to fill a need and
Apple supports that, in this scenario.

102
00:05:33,880 --> 00:05:36,200
They don't always support it,
but in this scenario they do.

103
00:05:36,200 --> 00:05:38,980
So if you need to plug
a guitar into your laptop or

104
00:05:38,980 --> 00:05:42,470
into your Mac Pro,
you can't do it right out of the box, but

105
00:05:42,470 --> 00:05:45,190
you can add a peripheral and
now you get that functionality.

106
00:05:45,190 --> 00:05:48,020
And you'll see there's all
sorts of specialized hardware,

107
00:05:48,020 --> 00:05:50,320
like here's a MIDI keyboard that runs.

108
00:05:52,040 --> 00:05:53,250
Some of this stuff, I actually,

109
00:05:53,250 --> 00:05:56,750
like I don't necessarily even know what
this thing is, some USB recording device.

110
00:05:56,750 --> 00:05:59,500
So a lot of this stuff is
really specialized and

111
00:05:59,500 --> 00:06:03,350
goes beyond what a normal person
might even understand what it is.

112
00:06:03,350 --> 00:06:04,950
But it's important to somebody.

113
00:06:04,950 --> 00:06:09,790
I have no idea what an IK Multimedia
iKlip Xpand Mini holder is.

114
00:06:10,840 --> 00:06:12,800
I don't know, but somebody needs that.

115
00:06:12,800 --> 00:06:15,310
It adds on to their laptop and
it adds that functionality.

116
00:06:15,310 --> 00:06:16,450
Those are peripherals.

117
00:06:17,640 --> 00:06:21,070
Really common ones, let's think of
one of the most common peripherals.

118
00:06:21,070 --> 00:06:23,590
Well, keyboard and mouse,
that's gotta be number one and number two.

119
00:06:23,590 --> 00:06:26,400
Keyboard and mouse are really,
really common.

120
00:06:26,400 --> 00:06:30,940
It used to be that webcams and
microphones were really common.

121
00:06:30,940 --> 00:06:33,320
But most computers these
days have them built in.

122
00:06:33,320 --> 00:06:36,310
It's like my laptop has a webcam and
a microphone built into it, so

123
00:06:36,310 --> 00:06:37,990
I don't really need to add that on.

124
00:06:37,990 --> 00:06:41,880
In the old days that was something
an average user didn't need, and

125
00:06:41,880 --> 00:06:45,790
so it was a separate device that you'd
buy and you'd add on to your system.

126
00:06:45,790 --> 00:06:49,649
But now thanks to things like FaceTime,
the average user does need a webcam and

127
00:06:49,649 --> 00:06:52,350
a microphone, so
Apple has included it in the device.

128
00:06:52,350 --> 00:06:54,030
That happens over time,
this stuff changes.

129
00:06:55,390 --> 00:06:57,940
Other really common ones, a printer.

130
00:06:57,940 --> 00:07:00,420
If you want to print, you might
have a printer on your network or

131
00:07:00,420 --> 00:07:02,570
you might have a printer
attached to your laptop or

132
00:07:02,570 --> 00:07:04,897
desktop somehow, via one of
the different connection mediums.

133
00:07:05,960 --> 00:07:09,620
Other devices we might connect,
network adapters, those are pretty common.

134
00:07:09,620 --> 00:07:11,550
I'm using them right here.

135
00:07:11,550 --> 00:07:12,220
What else?

136
00:07:12,220 --> 00:07:15,650
What else makes for
a good peripheral device you might add on?

137
00:07:15,650 --> 00:07:16,150
Storage.

138
00:07:17,230 --> 00:07:21,350
It's getting kind of sad the amount of
external hard drives that I have and

139
00:07:21,350 --> 00:07:22,990
USB keys that I have.

140
00:07:22,990 --> 00:07:24,690
I eat up a lot of storage.

141
00:07:24,690 --> 00:07:28,110
If you're gonna do Time Machine and you
wanna back up to an external hard drive,

142
00:07:28,110 --> 00:07:30,580
that external hard drive is
a peripheral that we attach.

143
00:07:30,580 --> 00:07:34,310
We're adding more storage to our
system without having to open it up,

144
00:07:34,310 --> 00:07:35,940
without having to void our warranty.

145
00:07:35,940 --> 00:07:38,260
It's really nice that
we're able to do that.

146
00:07:38,260 --> 00:07:40,990
Those are some of the things
that are peripheral devices.

147
00:07:40,990 --> 00:07:45,500
Now the problem with
peripheral devices is that

148
00:07:45,500 --> 00:07:49,730
when you add it onto your computer, it's
something that your Mac didn't expect.

149
00:07:50,770 --> 00:07:54,028
When Apple made your Mac at the factory,
when they put Mac OS on there,

150
00:07:54,028 --> 00:07:56,251
they knew what hardware
they were selling you.

151
00:07:56,251 --> 00:08:00,694
When they sold me this laptop, They knew
exactly what hardware was in there, and so

152
00:08:00,694 --> 00:08:04,990
Mac OS is designed to handle a 100% of
the hardware that's in this laptop.

153
00:08:04,990 --> 00:08:06,400
I didn't have to do anything special.

154
00:08:06,400 --> 00:08:08,730
It just worked right out of the box,
and that was that.

155
00:08:08,730 --> 00:08:12,230
But if I start adding peripheral devices,
like this trackball,

156
00:08:12,230 --> 00:08:16,390
when I added this trackball to my laptop,
Apple didn't know about that.

157
00:08:16,390 --> 00:08:18,500
My trackball's made by Logitech.

158
00:08:18,500 --> 00:08:21,000
And so
the Mac has to look at that and say,

159
00:08:21,000 --> 00:08:22,720
all right, do I know what that device is?

160
00:08:22,720 --> 00:08:24,020
Can I handle it?

161
00:08:24,020 --> 00:08:25,410
And it makes a guess.

162
00:08:25,410 --> 00:08:29,140
And it says well, it looks like a mouse,
I'm gonna treat it like a mouse.

163
00:08:29,140 --> 00:08:29,850
And that's what happened.

164
00:08:29,850 --> 00:08:33,700
When I first plugged in this trackball,
it treated it like a mouse, and it worked.

165
00:08:33,700 --> 00:08:36,630
My track ball was able to move the mouse
around on the screen, and the left and

166
00:08:36,630 --> 00:08:39,640
right mouse buttons would click,
and that worked great.

167
00:08:39,640 --> 00:08:42,600
But, my track ball has
some extra buttons on it.

168
00:08:42,600 --> 00:08:45,690
It's got a back and a forward
button on it to be able to, like,

169
00:08:45,690 --> 00:08:49,440
if you're browsing the web you can go a
web page, forward a web page if you want.

170
00:08:49,440 --> 00:08:52,750
It's got a scroll wheel on it that
can move the web page up and down.

171
00:08:52,750 --> 00:08:56,510
And when I first put the mouse in,
those actually didn't work.

172
00:08:56,510 --> 00:09:00,620
That was additional functionality
that the Mac didn't know about.

173
00:09:00,620 --> 00:09:03,990
It didn't know about those special
buttons that were on the track ball.

174
00:09:03,990 --> 00:09:07,980
What I had to do then
was to load a driver.

175
00:09:07,980 --> 00:09:10,550
Drivers are extra software that we add

176
00:09:10,550 --> 00:09:14,480
on to our Mac that allows them to
interact with specialized hardware.

177
00:09:14,480 --> 00:09:18,180
Now Apple is one of the best companies,
for

178
00:09:18,180 --> 00:09:20,700
making drivers not an issue for
us, all right.

179
00:09:20,700 --> 00:09:24,500
At Apple headquarters, they know what
are really common devices out there and

180
00:09:24,500 --> 00:09:28,990
they write native Apple drive Drivers
that are included with Mac OS, and so

181
00:09:28,990 --> 00:09:32,460
a lot of times if you go out and
you buy hardware that's really common, and

182
00:09:32,460 --> 00:09:36,610
you plug it in, your Mac will
recognize it and set it up and

183
00:09:36,610 --> 00:09:38,730
run and
you don't have to add a driver at all.

184
00:09:38,730 --> 00:09:40,960
It just knows it and works with it.

185
00:09:40,960 --> 00:09:45,180
But if you plug in your device and
it doesn't work, or parts of it work and

186
00:09:45,180 --> 00:09:50,750
parts of it don't, well, when that
happens, you may need to load a driver.

187
00:09:50,750 --> 00:09:51,310
All right.

188
00:09:51,310 --> 00:09:53,350
An example of this might be a printer.

189
00:09:53,350 --> 00:09:55,270
That you go to attach
a printer to your Mac.

190
00:09:55,270 --> 00:09:58,140
And the Mac sees it,
it shows up as a printer.

191
00:09:58,140 --> 00:10:00,400
But, some of the features are missing.

192
00:10:00,400 --> 00:10:03,670
We have an office copier here,
it's this massive printer.

193
00:10:03,670 --> 00:10:08,180
And it can do all sorts of crazy things
like it can print on large paper and

194
00:10:08,180 --> 00:10:12,180
fold it in half to booklets, it can
staple things, it can hole punch things,

195
00:10:12,180 --> 00:10:13,400
right, it's a really fancy printer.

196
00:10:14,500 --> 00:10:19,410
If I load the default Mac driver,
I can print out that big printer but

197
00:10:19,410 --> 00:10:21,780
I can't hole punch and I can't staple.

198
00:10:21,780 --> 00:10:26,010
It doesn't see that advanced functionality
until I load the driver, from the vendor.

199
00:10:27,220 --> 00:10:31,910
Now, when we add drivers to our software,
we attach them into Mac OS,

200
00:10:31,910 --> 00:10:35,030
that teaches the operating system
about that advanced functionality.

201
00:10:35,030 --> 00:10:37,410
How to properly talk to the hardware.

202
00:10:37,410 --> 00:10:40,800
It's not us talking to the hardware,
it's Mac OS talking to the hardware.

203
00:10:40,800 --> 00:10:44,630
We're teaching Mac OS how to
to talk to those devices.

204
00:10:44,630 --> 00:10:49,630
And we do that through the user drivers,
and drivers can come in one of three ways.

205
00:10:49,630 --> 00:10:52,490
There's actually three different
ways we get drivers on this system.

206
00:10:52,490 --> 00:10:56,060
The most common way is you
go to the vendor's website,

207
00:10:56,060 --> 00:10:59,450
you download a driver
package right from them.

208
00:10:59,450 --> 00:11:01,910
And it will be a PKG file, right?

209
00:11:01,910 --> 00:11:05,400
Normally when you download an application
from the web, it's an app, right?

210
00:11:05,400 --> 00:11:08,300
And we just drag it and drop it right
into our applications folder and

211
00:11:08,300 --> 00:11:10,360
now it's an application we can run, but

212
00:11:10,360 --> 00:11:14,240
a driver needs to be available to
the operating system underneath.

213
00:11:14,240 --> 00:11:16,210
It's not an app that we run on demand.

214
00:11:16,210 --> 00:11:18,890
It's something that's running
in the background on the system.

215
00:11:18,890 --> 00:11:21,220
And so
it'll come to use as a package file.

216
00:11:21,220 --> 00:11:23,190
And when you run that package file.

217
00:11:23,190 --> 00:11:26,470
it will copy the driver contents,
to the hard drive.

218
00:11:26,470 --> 00:11:30,230
It will copy them into your library so
that they're available, and

219
00:11:30,230 --> 00:11:34,670
you'll be able to access those
resources as you need to.

220
00:11:34,670 --> 00:11:38,410
Under the hood in Mac OS, we have
what's called the BSD operating system.

221
00:11:38,410 --> 00:11:39,950
BSD is based on Unix.

222
00:11:39,950 --> 00:11:42,660
It's a Unix-like operating system.

223
00:11:42,660 --> 00:11:47,051
And the heart of that Unix like operating

Ones that you don't see

943
00:47:49,500 --> 00:47:52,910
The first one the exam objectives
call out is Bluetooth.

944
00:47:52,910 --> 00:47:56,727
Bluetooth connectivity is wireless
connectivity that allows you to attach

945
00:47:56,727 --> 00:47:57,978
a device to your laptop or

946
00:47:57,978 --> 00:48:01,333
computer without having to open it up or
even run physical cables.

947
00:48:01,333 --> 00:48:03,216
Bluetooth is really popular for

948
00:48:03,216 --> 00:48:07,748
devices because it's based on our RF waves
that do really well when it comes to

949
00:48:07,748 --> 00:48:11,670
penetrating walls, so
it's a great technology for that.

950
00:48:11,670 --> 00:48:15,340
But its range is very, very short.

951
00:48:15,340 --> 00:48:18,830
When we talk about something
like a WiFi network for

952
00:48:18,830 --> 00:48:22,670
network access, you can get
usually up to about 300 feet away,

953
00:48:22,670 --> 00:48:26,870
about 100 meters away from a wireless
access point and still have a signal.

954
00:48:26,870 --> 00:48:30,920
With Bluetooth, you're lucky if
you can get ten meters away.

955
00:48:30,920 --> 00:48:33,250
The range for bluetooth is between one and

956
00:48:33,250 --> 00:48:37,560
ten meters, which maxes out somewhere
around 30 or 33 feet or so.

957
00:48:37,560 --> 00:48:40,840
That's about as far away as you can get
from a computer with a Bluetooth device.

958
00:48:40,840 --> 00:48:44,080
That makes it great for peripherals
that are gonna be right by the computer.

959
00:48:44,080 --> 00:48:47,050
It makes it bad for
things you're gonna roam around with.

960
00:48:47,050 --> 00:48:48,860
A Bluetooth is extremely flexible.

961
00:48:48,860 --> 00:48:50,940
They make Bluetooth microphones,
Bluetooth,

962
00:48:50,940 --> 00:48:53,980
speakers, Bluetooth keyboards and mice.

963
00:48:53,980 --> 00:48:56,610
They make all sorts of Bluetooth
devices that you can attach securely

964
00:48:56,610 --> 00:48:57,130
to your system.

965
00:48:58,630 --> 00:49:01,702
The thing you need to remember about
Bluetooth is that there's more than one

966
00:49:01,702 --> 00:49:02,332
version of it.

967
00:49:02,332 --> 00:49:06,400
Version 1.2 is the earliest one
that Apple really supported.

968
00:49:06,400 --> 00:49:08,810
I don't think they supported
anything before 1.2.

969
00:49:08,810 --> 00:49:13,690
And 1.2 is designed really just for
simple devices like keyboards,

970
00:49:13,690 --> 00:49:16,970
mice, and
those little cellular phone headsets.

971
00:49:16,970 --> 00:49:21,450
They had a maximum speed
of 721 kilobits per second,

972
00:49:21,450 --> 00:49:24,650
which is not terribly fast, right?

973
00:49:24,650 --> 00:49:26,920
721 kilobits is great for
a keyboard or a mouse.

974
00:49:26,920 --> 00:49:28,630
It's terrible for streaming video.

975
00:49:28,630 --> 00:49:30,850
You wouldn't wanna use it for
file transfers.

976
00:49:30,850 --> 00:49:33,220
But it at least got you by for
basic connectivity.

977
00:49:34,280 --> 00:49:37,030
The next major version was Bluetooth 2.1.

978
00:49:37,030 --> 00:49:40,600
It functioned basically like
Bluetooth 1.2, except it went faster.

979
00:49:40,600 --> 00:49:42,930
It had an upward speed of,
was it 3 megabit?

980
00:49:42,930 --> 00:49:45,990
Yeah, 3 megabit per second,
which is a lot more.

981
00:49:45,990 --> 00:49:48,700
Three megabits a lot more reasonable for
things like file transfer.

982
00:49:48,700 --> 00:49:51,930
So now you started to see cameras,
digital cameras and

983
00:49:51,930 --> 00:49:55,850
cell phones that could Bluetooth connect
to your computer to copy photos back and

984
00:49:55,850 --> 00:49:57,710
forth, copy videos back and forth.

985
00:49:57,710 --> 00:50:00,430
And it wasn't blazing fast, but
it wasn't slow either, right?

986
00:50:00,430 --> 00:50:01,570
It was kind of a good middle of the road.

987
00:50:02,990 --> 00:50:08,435
But on modern computers, what you're
going to see is Bluetooth 3.0 and 4.0.

988
00:50:08,435 --> 00:50:10,390
And often times you'll see both.

989
00:50:10,390 --> 00:50:13,131
So my laptop has 3.0 and 4.0.

990
00:50:13,131 --> 00:50:14,320
Now, why both?

991
00:50:14,320 --> 00:50:16,980
Well, each one addresses
something different.

992
00:50:16,980 --> 00:50:20,510
Bluetooth 3.0 was designed
to address speed.

993
00:50:20,510 --> 00:50:24,590
They wanted it to be as fast as possible,
and with Bluetooth 3.0,

994
00:50:24,590 --> 00:50:27,410
the maximum speed on that is 24 megabit.

995
00:50:27,410 --> 00:50:30,440
24 megabit is significantly
faster than the old

996
00:50:30,440 --> 00:50:34,570
three megabit that you saw on the old
Bluetooth 2.1, so it's a lot faster.

997
00:50:34,570 --> 00:50:38,430
When it comes to copying videos and audio
files and other things like that between

998
00:50:38,430 --> 00:50:42,600
a phone and a computer,
Bluetooth 3.0 does a great job for it.

999
00:50:42,600 --> 00:50:46,970
But it's energy hungry, so it's not so
good if you're worried about battery life.

1000
00:50:47,980 --> 00:50:50,750
It's good for simple, quick transfers,
but it's not good for

1001
00:50:50,750 --> 00:50:52,580
stuff you use all the time.

1002
00:50:52,580 --> 00:50:55,710
So, for example, on an iPad,
if you had a Bluetooth keyboard,

1003
00:50:55,710 --> 00:51:00,170
having a Bluetooth 3.0 keyboard connected
all the time would run your battery down.

1004
00:51:00,170 --> 00:51:01,700
I used to have one for my tablet, and

1005
00:51:01,700 --> 00:51:06,930
it would take usually about 10% to 12%
of my battery over the course of a day.

1006
00:51:06,930 --> 00:51:09,950
If I didn't use that tablet
at all during the whole day,

1007
00:51:09,950 --> 00:51:13,310
just having that keyboard attached, we're
getting to about 10% to 12% of my battery,

1008
00:51:13,310 --> 00:51:15,252
which is a pretty big chunk.

1009
00:51:15,252 --> 00:51:21,170
Bluetooth 4.0 or what it's normally
called is Bluetooth low energy, BLE.

1010
00:51:21,170 --> 00:51:24,980
Bluetooth low energy was designed
to address the energy problem.

1011
00:51:24,980 --> 00:51:29,780
To make it a lot less of a battery
drain and to make it connect really,

1012
00:51:29,780 --> 00:51:30,860
really rapidly.

1013
00:51:30,860 --> 00:51:33,720
One problem with Bluetooth 3.0 is
if you had a Bluetooth keyboard,

1014
00:51:33,720 --> 00:51:35,900
if it went to sleep you had to wake it up.

1015
00:51:35,900 --> 00:51:38,780
And it would take a good 20, 30 seconds
before the device would connect to

1016
00:51:38,780 --> 00:51:40,390
your computer and you could start typing.

1017
00:51:40,390 --> 00:51:42,700
So if you wanted a real quick type a note,

1018
00:51:42,700 --> 00:51:45,210
you weren't doing that on
a Bluetooth 3 keyboard.

1019
00:51:45,210 --> 00:51:48,740
But with Bluetooth 4 it
would connect very fast, and

1020
00:51:48,740 --> 00:51:50,790
then when it wasn't used
it would go to sleep and

1021
00:51:50,790 --> 00:51:56,040
it would consume very little energy, and
they achieve that by killing off speed.

1022
00:51:56,040 --> 00:52:00,920
Bluetooth 4.0 has a maximum speed
of 200 kilobytes, that means it's

1023
00:52:00,920 --> 00:52:06,021
actually slower then Bluetooth 1.0 or 1.2
it's slower then the oldest technology.

1024
00:52:06,021 --> 00:52:09,550
And that's because Bluetooth low energy
was designed for things like fitness

1025
00:52:09,550 --> 00:52:14,190
health bands, keyboards, mice,
stuff you don't use all the time,

1026
00:52:14,190 --> 00:52:17,330
stuff that when you need it, you need it
to work fast, and then when it's done,

1027
00:52:17,330 --> 00:52:19,540
you need it not to consume energy.

1028
00:52:19,540 --> 00:52:22,637
I have a Bluetooth keyboard I
use with my iPad and it's BLE,

1029
00:52:22,637 --> 00:52:27,430
Bluetooth low energy, and it makes no
noticeable difference on my battery life

1030
00:52:27,430 --> 00:52:29,260
whether the keyboard's on or off.

1031
00:52:29,260 --> 00:52:32,240
And the battery in that things,
when I charge it, it'll stay charged for

1032
00:52:32,240 --> 00:52:34,890
a whole month before I
have to recharge it.

1033
00:52:34,890 --> 00:52:36,800
BLE is not for speed.

1034
00:52:36,800 --> 00:52:38,040
It's for battery life.

1035
00:52:38,040 --> 00:52:42,245
And so that's why a lot of devices like
your MacBook Pros will come with both,

1036
00:52:42,245 --> 00:52:43,941
Bluetooth 3.0 and 4.0.

1037
00:52:43,941 --> 00:52:46,080
When you need speed, it'll use 3.0.

1038
00:52:46,080 --> 00:52:50,200
Like when you're connecting a video camera
and copying video files, it'll use 3.0.

1039
00:52:50,200 --> 00:52:52,490
Well when you're connecting
your fitness band,

1040
00:52:52,490 --> 00:52:53,560
it'll use 4.0, consuming less energy.

1041
00:52:54,790 --> 00:52:59,000
With all of the Bluetooth standards, you
have a maximum amount of devices that you

1042
00:52:59,000 --> 00:53:02,110
can attach, which is really kind
of based on your bandwidth, right.

1043
00:53:02,110 --> 00:53:05,220
If you get too many Bluetooth
devices attached you start to

1044
00:53:05,220 --> 00:53:08,010
run out of bandwidth and communications,
but otherwise, they're wireless.

1045
00:53:08,010 --> 00:53:10,340
They just connect up and that's about it.

1046
00:53:10,340 --> 00:53:13,280
We'll see on some of the wired methods for
connecting that we actually have

1047
00:53:13,280 --> 00:53:16,940
a solid number of devices,
a maximum number of devices we can attach.

1048
00:53:18,220 --> 00:53:19,140
All right.

1049
00:53:19,140 --> 00:53:24,038
Some of the other connectivity methods
they call on the exam, SCSI, S-C-S-I.

1050
00:53:24,038 --> 00:53:27,930
SCSI, it stands for
small computer system interface.

1051
00:53:27,930 --> 00:53:30,140
And it's a legacy connection.

1052
00:53:30,140 --> 00:53:33,540
We do still see it in some services but
as far as Macs,

1053
00:53:33,540 --> 00:53:37,080
I don't believe any Macs sold today
come with SCSI connections any more.

1054
00:53:37,080 --> 00:53:39,270
I could be wrong in that, but
I haven't seen one in a long time.

1055
00:53:39,270 --> 00:53:44,675
It used to be, back in the day,
that if you bought an iMac or

1056
00:53:44,675 --> 00:53:49,900
if you bought a MacPro that it would
have SCSI based hard drives in it.

1057
00:53:49,900 --> 00:53:52,700
And those SCSI based hard drives
were pretty fast at the time.

1058
00:53:52,700 --> 00:53:55,810
They'd have speeds that were
up to 320 megabits per second,

1059
00:53:55,810 --> 00:53:56,710
which is pretty quick,

1060
00:53:56,710 --> 00:54:00,850
and that was faster than some of the other
technologies that were out there.

1061
00:54:00,850 --> 00:54:03,150
The drives were more expensive though,
and so

1062
00:54:03,150 --> 00:54:05,100
that made them a little less attractive.

1063
00:54:05,100 --> 00:54:08,260
But one of the cool things about
SCSI was that you could have

1064
00:54:08,260 --> 00:54:12,480
up to 15 SCSI hard drives on
one channel on one connector.

1065
00:54:12,480 --> 00:54:17,260
They call it SCSI bus and it would
have IDs zero through 15, one of them

1066
00:54:17,260 --> 00:54:20,840
will be eaten up by the controller but
then the other 15 IDs would be available.

1067
00:54:20,840 --> 00:54:24,890
So there were 16 IDs total, you hear
people say you can have 16 devices.

1068
00:54:24,890 --> 00:54:26,920
But one of those devices would
get eaten up by the controller.

1069
00:54:26,920 --> 00:54:29,200
So you really only have
15 devices on there.

1070
00:54:29,200 --> 00:54:31,430
And you saw that on a lot of Macs.

1071
00:54:31,430 --> 00:54:35,590
I used to have an old Mac Quadra,
a long time, like 20 years ago.

1072
00:54:35,590 --> 00:54:39,039
And it had the big SCSI port on the back
where I could connect SCSI scanner or

1073
00:54:39,039 --> 00:54:41,790
SCSI hard drives and
it had SCSI hard drives on the inside.

1074
00:54:41,790 --> 00:54:43,720
It was all SCSI through the system.

1075
00:54:43,720 --> 00:54:44,990
But you really don't see that anymore.

1076
00:54:46,230 --> 00:54:48,850
Another one you don't see anymore is ATA,
right?

1077
00:54:48,850 --> 00:54:53,240
ATA drives, you'll hear them called
parallel drives or IDE drives.

1078
00:54:53,240 --> 00:54:57,010
This is another standard that
we saw on some Macs especially

1079
00:54:57,010 --> 00:55:00,530
on the earlier MacBooks,
they would have the ATA drives.

1080
00:55:00,530 --> 00:55:03,700
It stands for
Advanced Technology Attachment.

1081
00:55:03,700 --> 00:55:06,180
It was designed for older hard drives.

1082
00:55:06,180 --> 00:55:10,820
It had a maximum speed of 133 megabits,
which was about

1083
00:55:10,820 --> 00:55:14,740
a third of the maximum speed of SCSI, so
you'll see where SCSI is a lot faster.

1084
00:55:14,740 --> 00:55:17,500
But ATA drives were a lot less expensive,
and so

1085
00:55:17,500 --> 00:55:21,980
they were easier to implement especially
in compact devices, like laptops.

1086
00:55:21,980 --> 00:55:26,880
With ATA, you do have a maximum device
count of two devices per channel.

1087
00:55:26,880 --> 00:55:29,200
With SCSI it was 15, right?

1088
00:55:29,200 --> 00:55:31,640
With ATA it's only two.

1089
00:55:31,640 --> 00:55:35,840
So if you had a hard drive and a CD drive
that was it, it was maxed out right?

1090
00:55:35,840 --> 00:55:37,780
If you had two channels you
could have four devices.

1091
00:55:37,780 --> 00:55:40,390
If you had three or
four channels you could have more devices.

1092
00:55:40,390 --> 00:55:42,940
But you were limited to two per channel.

1093
00:55:42,940 --> 00:55:46,421
This is another legacy connector,
and to my knowledge,

1094
00:55:46,421 --> 00:55:48,750
it's not used in any Macs sold today.

1095
00:55:48,750 --> 00:55:49,328
SCSI and

1096
00:55:49,328 --> 00:55:56,020
ATA were both replaced by a different type
of connector called Serial ATA, or SATA.

1097
00:55:56,020 --> 00:55:59,888
Serial ATA kind of fixes some of
the issues that we had with the older

1098
00:55:59,888 --> 00:56:02,100
standards by increasing the speeds,

1099
00:56:02,100 --> 00:56:05,917
making ATA much more in line with
the speeds that we saw with SCSI.

1100
00:56:05,917 --> 00:56:09,208
With SCSI I said the maximum
speed was 320 megabit.

1101
00:56:09,208 --> 00:56:12,587
With serial ATA, it is 600 megabit.

1102
00:56:12,587 --> 00:56:13,168
Right?

1103
00:56:13,168 --> 00:56:20,650
Regular ATA was 133 megabit,
SCSI was 320, serial ATA 600 megabit.

1104
00:56:20,650 --> 00:56:23,910
So serial ATA is faster than both SCSI and
regular ATA, so

1105
00:56:23,910 --> 00:56:26,200
that kind of pushed them to the wayside.

1106
00:56:26,200 --> 00:56:32,220
There is one negative, with serial ATA,
you can only have one device per channel.

1107
00:56:32,220 --> 00:56:37,000
So if I wanna have a hard drive and a CD
drive, I've gotta have two SATA channels.

1108
00:56:37,000 --> 00:56:39,830
So when you buy a desktop,
it'll oftentimes have four or

1109
00:56:39,830 --> 00:56:41,180
six channels in it.

1110
00:56:41,180 --> 00:56:44,710
But when you have a laptop, it'll just
have the basic channels needed for

1111
00:56:44,710 --> 00:56:46,730
the devices that are inside of it,
and that's it.

1112
00:56:46,730 --> 00:56:48,600
So, a little bit harder to expand.

1113
00:56:48,600 --> 00:56:52,490
But it's a lot less expensive,
it's a lot faster, and it works great.

1114
00:56:52,490 --> 00:56:57,520
So a laptop like mine, I don't have an
optical drive, I just have my SSD drive.

1115
00:56:57,520 --> 00:56:58,940
It's connected via SATA.

1116
00:56:58,940 --> 00:57:01,190
If you buy a Mac Pro,
it's going to come with those SATA drives.

1117
00:57:01,190 --> 00:57:03,830
If you buy an iMac,
it's gonna have a SATA drive inside of it.

1118
00:57:03,830 --> 00:57:06,720
Whether it's solid state or whether
it's magnetic, that doesn't matter.

1119
00:57:06,720 --> 00:57:08,090
It'll be a SATA connect.

1120
00:57:08,090 --> 00:57:11,710
And if you have an optical drive, like
a super drive it'll usually be connected

1121
00:57:11,710 --> 00:57:14,730
VSA also inside of the device, right.

1122
00:57:14,730 --> 00:57:19,200
So, those are the internal buses
that we'll see on our System.

1123
00:57:19,200 --> 00:57:22,580
Now with those, it requires opening
up your device to get at them.

1124
00:57:22,580 --> 00:57:25,660
If I wanna change the hard drive
in my laptop or in that Mac Pro,

1125
00:57:25,660 --> 00:57:29,760
I'm gonna have to open up that case to
get in there and start to work with it.

1126
00:57:29,760 --> 00:57:31,950
So we don't normally wanna do that.

1127
00:57:31,950 --> 00:57:35,980
The rest of the buses that Apple calls
out in the exam are all external ones or

1128
00:57:35,980 --> 00:57:39,730
expansion buses that we can add more stuff
onto the system without having to crack

1129
00:57:39,730 --> 00:57:43,880
open that case and that's usually
a little more in line with what we want.

1130
00:57:43,880 --> 00:57:47,160

and then into printers and scanners.

1797
01:30:59,400 --> 01:31:02,680
Shows the printer, and check off
share this printer on the network.

1798
01:31:03,920 --> 01:31:05,160
The other way to share it,

1799
01:31:05,160 --> 01:31:09,810
like if I uncheck that,
is you go to your system preferences.

1800
01:31:09,810 --> 01:31:13,610
And instead of going to printers and
scanners, you go down to sharing.

1801
01:31:14,900 --> 01:31:17,750
Inside of sharing,
you can turn on printer sharing.

1802
01:31:18,830 --> 01:31:20,080
You can pick the printer.

1803
01:31:21,220 --> 01:31:23,660
And the only difference between here and

1804
01:31:23,660 --> 01:31:29,320
the other place is once you turn it on,
you can customize the print permissions.

1805
01:31:29,320 --> 01:31:33,770
Maybe I don't want everyone to print,
maybe I want to limit that now.

1806
01:31:33,770 --> 01:31:37,880
So I can add it in and maybe,
I just want me to be able to print.

1807
01:31:37,880 --> 01:31:40,630
And so I can take everyone and
set it to no access.

1808
01:31:40,630 --> 01:31:42,690
And me, I get full access.

1809
01:31:42,690 --> 01:31:45,480
So now, if I'm on somebody else's
computer here in the office,

1810
01:31:45,480 --> 01:31:49,370
I can connect to this printer, and
I can print but other people can't.

1811
01:31:49,370 --> 01:31:51,560
So if you want to
customize the permissions,

1812
01:31:51,560 --> 01:31:53,910
you need to go to the sharing preference.

1813
01:31:53,910 --> 01:31:56,600
But if you just want to share it out and
let everybody print, you can do that

1814
01:31:56,600 --> 01:31:59,975
right from the printers and scanners
preference, you can set it right in there.

1815
01:31:59,975 --> 01:32:02,110
Right, and in fact,
if I went the other way,

1816
01:32:02,110 --> 01:32:05,130
notice how they have links,
like here's this link, open printers and

1817
01:32:05,130 --> 01:32:08,070
scanners preference,
we saw the same thing under the other one.

1818
01:32:08,070 --> 01:32:11,550
If I go to the printer and
scanner preferences, and

1819
01:32:11,550 --> 01:32:13,830
I choose the printer, it's got
a link to the sharing preferences.

1820
01:32:13,830 --> 01:32:15,790
The two tools link together.

1821
01:32:15,790 --> 01:32:17,910
Because they know you might
need to go back and forth.

1822
01:32:17,910 --> 01:32:21,390
I turn on the sharing here, then I
jump over to sharing preferences, and

1823
01:32:21,390 --> 01:32:22,660
I set the permissions.

1824
01:32:22,660 --> 01:32:24,760
And then I jump back to printers and
scanners, and

1825
01:32:24,760 --> 01:32:26,420
I configure the printer some more, right?

1826
01:32:26,420 --> 01:32:28,930
So they link to each other for
that exact purpose.

1827
01:32:28,930 --> 01:32:30,480
But that's how we share those out.

1828
01:32:30,480 --> 01:32:33,210
Once it's shared, people on
the network can just browse, they see

1829
01:32:33,210 --> 01:32:36,160
the printer, and they can print to it, and
they don't have to mess with all the stuff

1830
01:32:36,160 --> 01:32:38,960
that we just did as far as loading
the driver and getting that all set up.

1831
01:32:38,960 --> 01:32:42,750
They'll learn all that from My Mac, My Mac
will tell them what the printer is and

1832
01:32:42,750 --> 01:32:46,710
what format it uses and they just need to
talk to me and not the printer itself.

1833
01:32:46,710 --> 01:32:50,320
So if I say, hey you gotta give
me files in postscript format,

1834
01:32:50,320 --> 01:32:52,970
they just need that
generic postscript driver.

1835
01:32:52,970 --> 01:32:55,880
Or if I needed an airprint,
they can send it to me in airprint.

1836
01:32:55,880 --> 01:32:58,280
And then I can turn it into PCL or

1837
01:32:58,280 --> 01:33:02,090
whatever to send it along to that printer
and get it to print out on the other end.

1838
01:33:02,090 --> 01:33:03,700
So it makes things a lot more simple.

1839
01:33:05,450 --> 01:33:07,430
All right, but
that's basically it for printers.

1840
01:33:07,430 --> 01:33:11,540
Now I had to manually add this one in
because it was on a different network.

1841
01:33:11,540 --> 01:33:13,870
Tim's, it automatically found
that one on the network, right?

1842
01:33:13,870 --> 01:33:15,230
So it just located it.

1843
01:33:15,230 --> 01:33:17,530
And I don't have Tim's driver loaded, so

1844
01:33:17,530 --> 01:33:19,960
I might need to go and add a driver for
his too if I wanna get.

1845
01:33:19,960 --> 01:33:23,120
I don't see, I don't even get
an Options button on this one.

1846
01:33:23,120 --> 01:33:24,880
So I would need to load the driver for
his too.

1847
01:33:26,340 --> 01:33:29,610
If we directly plug the cable in,
we wouldn't have to use the plus button,

1848
01:33:29,610 --> 01:33:31,980
it would automatically spot it,
see it, and add it in.

1849
01:33:31,980 --> 01:33:34,010
So we'd have one less step there
with the direct attach printer.

1850
01:33:35,782 --> 01:33:37,505
All right, but
that's about It for printers,

1851
01:33:37,505 --> 01:33:40,345
not the craziest thing in the world,
pretty straightforward.

1852
01:33:40,345 --> 01:33:46,285
The exam, remember, the underlying system
is CUPS, the Common Unix Print System.

1853
01:33:46,285 --> 01:33:47,235
It's pretty neat.

1854
01:33:47,235 --> 01:33:50,590
It's one of the better things that Apple's
done for the open source community.

1855
01:33:50,590 --> 01:33:54,400
There's one other thing I wanna mention,
I mention that when we print to a printer,

1856
01:33:54,400 --> 01:33:58,200
it takes those documents has to put them
in a format the printer will understand,

1857
01:33:58,200 --> 01:34:00,940
and it does that on your hard drive, okay?

1858
01:34:00,940 --> 01:34:03,960
Well it does that in
a folder that's protected.

1859
01:34:03,960 --> 01:34:07,360
So, I wanna point that out to you guys
cuz it's not a common one you encounter.

1860
01:34:07,360 --> 01:34:11,390
And this can turn up on the exam,
it's not terribly likely, but it can.

1861
01:34:11,390 --> 01:34:14,850
The printer, when it generates
those temporary documents,

1862
01:34:14,850 --> 01:34:20,816
it puts them in a folder which is /var,

1863
01:34:20,816 --> 01:34:25,810
var, that's a hidden folder anyway,
we don't normally see that one.

1864
01:34:25,810 --> 01:34:31,860
/var/spool/cups.

1865
01:34:31,860 --> 01:34:34,560
That's the folder where your
temporary print jobs are going.

1866
01:34:34,560 --> 01:34:37,770
And if you ever try and browse to it,
you get permission denied.

1867
01:34:37,770 --> 01:34:40,120
Right, it's a secured folder.

1868
01:34:40,120 --> 01:34:45,070
They want to make sure that each user
can't see each other's print jobs.

1869
01:34:45,070 --> 01:34:47,340
If I had a secret document, and
I don't want anybody else to see it,

1870
01:34:47,340 --> 01:34:50,380
and I print it, and
a copy of it gets stuck in the spooler.

1871
01:34:50,380 --> 01:34:53,860
Like, the printer's offline,
if somebody else could access the spooler,

1872
01:34:53,860 --> 01:34:55,350
they could see what I was printing.

1873
01:34:55,350 --> 01:35:00,200
So it's secured, it's isolated, and
you're not able to get to it, right?

1874
01:35:00,200 --> 01:35:01,400
If you want to see
what's inside it though,

1875
01:35:01,400 --> 01:35:04,300
you can jump over to like, an admin shell.

1876
01:35:06,050 --> 01:35:07,370
I'm just gonna do that real quick.

1877
01:35:07,370 --> 01:35:09,370
You're not supposed to do this,
Apple doesn't quite like it.

1878
01:35:09,370 --> 01:35:13,990
But if we want to see what's in there,
we can browse to it here, and

1879
01:35:13,990 --> 01:35:15,190
now we can browse inside.

1880
01:35:15,190 --> 01:35:19,210
And what you'll see are folders for each
of the printers that have been created.

1881
01:35:19,210 --> 01:35:21,950
Now, these folders don't mean anything
to us because we're not supposed to

1882
01:35:21,950 --> 01:35:22,500
see them, right?

1883
01:35:22,500 --> 01:35:24,350
The system is keeping track of that.

1884
01:35:24,350 --> 01:35:28,570
And there's a cache, see that cache
right there, where print jobs and

1885
01:35:28,570 --> 01:35:30,060
other things can get stored.

1886
01:35:30,060 --> 01:35:32,760
Here's that image that it
was using of Tim's printer.

1887
01:35:32,760 --> 01:35:34,490
There's some officer printer data.

1888
01:35:34,490 --> 01:35:36,290
There's things that get
cached in there that again,

1889
01:35:36,290 --> 01:35:38,780
you might not want other
people to have access to.

1890
01:35:38,780 --> 01:35:45,155
And if I take a look at one
of these other folders, or

1891
01:35:45,155 --> 01:35:47,945
actually that's just a raw file, isn't it?

1892
01:35:47,945 --> 01:35:48,855
That one is.

1893
01:35:48,855 --> 01:35:51,915
I've got my cache, I've got my temp,
and I guess I've never printed so

1894
01:35:51,915 --> 01:35:53,695
some of the folders haven't been created.

1895
01:35:53,695 --> 01:35:59,095
But you can browse in here and see some of
the different things that have been made.

1896
01:35:59,095 --> 01:36:01,350
I don't really have all that
much to see in this one, do I?

1897
01:36:01,350 --> 01:36:04,380
But this is where those
temporary jobs get cached and

1898
01:36:04,380 --> 01:36:06,720
stored, until they make it to the printer.

1899
01:36:06,720 --> 01:36:08,890
If the printer's offline,
they'll sit there.

1900
01:36:08,890 --> 01:36:10,060
And that's where the risk occurs.

1901
01:36:10,060 --> 01:36:13,890
That's why Apple secures this location and
doesn't let you get to it.

1902
01:36:13,890 --> 01:36:18,310
But it's just /var/spool/cups.

1903
01:36:18,310 --> 01:36:19,210
You should never have to go there.

1904
01:36:21,450 --> 01:36:23,830
All right, well,
that's about all I've got on printers,

1905
01:36:23,830 --> 01:36:26,960
and really about all I've got on
peripheral devices as a whole.

1906
01:36:26,960 --> 01:36:30,340
So this is a pretty good spot for
us to wrap this show up.

1907
01:36:30,340 --> 01:36:33,320
Let me remind you guys,
if you have questions on any

1908
01:36:33,320 --> 01:36:38,010
of the different things that we've talked
about in this show, feel free to ask.

1909
01:36:38,010 --> 01:36:38,840
Live during the show,

1910
01:36:38,840 --> 01:36:43,140
you can go to itpro.tv/live, you'll see
the chat room right beneath the video,

1911
01:36:43,140 --> 01:36:47,080
you can post your questions there and

1912
01:36:47,080 --> 01:36:49,660
If you have any questions after the show,
use our Q and A forums.

1913
01:36:49,660 --> 01:36:52,150
At the top of every page
on the ITProTV website,

1914
01:36:52,150 --> 01:36:56,410
you'll see a link that says Q and
A, click on it,

1915
01:36:56,410 --> 01:37:01,710
it'll take you to the forums and
you can post your questions there.

1916
01:37:01,710 --> 01:37:02,533
We monitor and answer after the show.

1917
01:37:02,533 --> 01:37:03,380
Take advantage of that resource.

1918
01:37:03,380 --> 01:37:04,298
It is there for you.

1919
01:37:04,298 --> 01:37:05,040
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed this episode.

1920
01:37:05,040 --> 01:37:08,420
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet,

episodes.description: When a system is not performing right, one should utilize the proper tools and troubleshooting techniques to assess the problem at hand. Viewers will hear about the different options to boot up a Mac and the phases of a system boot in order to implement troubleshooting diagnostics and tactics on a system.
episodes.title: System Troubleshooting
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,292 --> 00:00:22,458
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,458 --> 00:00:32,458
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,542 --> 00:00:36,625
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

5
00:00:36,625 --> 00:00:39,250
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:39,250 --> 00:00:40,718
I'm your host Don Pezet,

7
00:00:40,718 --> 00:00:45,000
back again with another episode of
Apple Certified Support Professional.

8
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:47,371
In fact,
we're not just back with another episode,

9
00:00:47,371 --> 00:00:51,190
we're back with the final episode of this
series as we wind down the objectives.

10
00:00:51,190 --> 00:00:52,730
We're on the final one and

11
00:00:52,730 --> 00:00:56,620
in this episode we're going to take
a look at some stuff that is really cool.

12
00:00:56,620 --> 00:01:01,110
The whole title of this series is
the Apple Certified Support Professional.

13
00:01:01,110 --> 00:01:03,180
And that means that you're going
to be dealing with systems that

14
00:01:03,180 --> 00:01:05,760
aren't necessarily working
the way they're supposed to.

15
00:01:05,760 --> 00:01:09,360
We've seen a ton of things throughout
the series that showed how to configure

16
00:01:09,360 --> 00:01:13,010
options, and
change the way the Mac OS behaves.

17
00:01:13,010 --> 00:01:14,080
In this episode,

18
00:01:14,080 --> 00:01:18,480
we're going to take a look at what to
do when Mac OS isn't even working.

19
00:01:18,480 --> 00:01:21,090
When you can't boot, or
you can't login, when you're just

20
00:01:21,090 --> 00:01:24,930
stuck trying to get into the system at
all, better yet go and configure settings.

21
00:01:24,930 --> 00:01:28,225
So we're going to see some neat stuff,
and these are the tools that

22
00:01:28,225 --> 00:01:32,110
kinda become our mental toolkit,
for when we work on computers.

23
00:01:32,110 --> 00:01:34,980
Now, Apple has put a lot of

24
00:01:34,980 --> 00:01:38,640
really neat Troubleshooting Utilities
into the Operating System and

25
00:01:38,640 --> 00:01:42,300
the hardware itself, most of which
is hidden away from the users.

26
00:01:42,300 --> 00:01:46,003
We've seen lot of things like the
Network Utility, and System Information,

27
00:01:46,003 --> 00:01:50,490
Disk Utility, Recovery Mode, all that
stuff we've covered in other episodes.

28
00:01:50,490 --> 00:01:53,460
It's all there, it's already to use,
if you know about it.

29
00:01:53,460 --> 00:01:57,230
If you don't know about it, it's hard to
stumble across those utilities, right?

30
00:01:57,230 --> 00:02:00,690
You don't necessarily see them,
they're kind of out of our purview.

31
00:02:00,690 --> 00:02:05,810
But a lot of that stuff, you can only
access assuming your Mac will boot up.

32
00:02:05,810 --> 00:02:07,990
But what if your Mac won't even boot up?

33
00:02:07,990 --> 00:02:10,100
What if it won't even get that far?

34
00:02:10,100 --> 00:02:12,600
Well, then you've gotta take
some extra steps, and try, and

35
00:02:12,600 --> 00:02:14,200
see what you can do to correct it.

36
00:02:14,200 --> 00:02:18,880
Well, to understand how to
troubleshoot boot problems,

37
00:02:18,880 --> 00:02:22,000
we need to understand what
happens at boot time anyway.

38
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:24,350
When you press the power
button on your Mac,

39
00:02:24,350 --> 00:02:27,810
there's actually four stages that
we go through as it boots up.

40
00:02:27,810 --> 00:02:31,010
It does a couple of different
things during that process, and

41
00:02:31,010 --> 00:02:32,240
I want to show that to you.

42
00:02:32,240 --> 00:02:36,160
I want to walk you through the process,
and so we're gonna be using another Mac.

43
00:02:36,160 --> 00:02:39,440
Normally, I'd use my laptop for this,
but because we're gonna be doing some

44
00:02:39,440 --> 00:02:41,910
troubleshooting, I'm gonna
use a separate Mac today.

45
00:02:41,910 --> 00:02:44,930
So I've got a Mac mini that's
off camera here, and this is it,

46
00:02:44,930 --> 00:02:46,210
we're looking at it right here.

47
00:02:46,210 --> 00:02:47,480
And it's running Yosemite.

48
00:02:47,480 --> 00:02:51,338
It's a perfectly healthy machine,
it's up, and it's running and it's happy.

49
00:02:51,338 --> 00:02:53,500
But I wanna walk through
the boot process and show you,

50
00:02:53,500 --> 00:02:56,610
what's going on at each stage.

51
00:02:56,610 --> 00:02:59,100
So let me just give this
guy a quick restart.

52
00:02:59,100 --> 00:03:03,100
So we'll go ahead and restart that one,
and while it reboots, there we go, we're

53
00:03:03,100 --> 00:03:07,690
just gonna let it reboot, it's gonna go to
a black screen and it's gonna power off.

54
00:03:07,690 --> 00:03:11,150
Then it's gonna power back
on cuz I told it to restart.

55
00:03:11,150 --> 00:03:14,330
And when the power's on,
you'll see a black screen for a moment.

56
00:03:14,330 --> 00:03:19,260
And that black screen is it going
through its basic firmware process.

57
00:03:19,260 --> 00:03:22,880
Then it goes to a grey screen,
with a grey Apple on it.

58
00:03:22,880 --> 00:03:25,041
And that's when it's
starting to do it's booter,

59
00:03:25,041 --> 00:03:28,540
when it's trying to find out where
it's going to boot from, all right.

60
00:03:28,540 --> 00:03:30,200
Then you get this screen right here,

61
00:03:30,200 --> 00:03:34,410
which is a gray Apple with
a status bar at the bottom.

62
00:03:34,410 --> 00:03:37,330
And this is the Kernel kicking in for
the Operating System,

63
00:03:37,330 --> 00:03:39,460
starting to do its activities.

64
00:03:39,460 --> 00:03:43,490
And then once that's done, it's gonna
transition us to a login window,

65
00:03:43,490 --> 00:03:44,660
all right?

66
00:03:44,660 --> 00:03:48,070
Those are the four steps that
happens when a Mac boots up.

67
00:03:48,070 --> 00:03:51,210
The firmware,
which is when we have the black screen.

68
00:03:51,210 --> 00:03:55,130
Then we get the booter, which is when
we have the gray screen with an Apple.

69
00:03:55,130 --> 00:04:00,130
Then we have the kernel, which is the gray
screen with an Apple, and the loading bar.

70
00:04:00,130 --> 00:04:02,670
And then we have the login
window right here.

71
00:04:02,670 --> 00:04:04,820
Those four steps.

72
00:04:04,820 --> 00:04:10,550
If your Mac is failing to boot, it's
gonna fail in one of those four phases.

73
00:04:10,550 --> 00:04:13,367
If you can get to the login window
like this, typically things are fine.

74
00:04:13,367 --> 00:04:17,710
Typically things are working out okay.

75
00:04:17,710 --> 00:04:21,590
And if you can log in as a user, so
like if I try to log in as ITProTV here.

76
00:04:21,590 --> 00:04:25,660
Let's see if I can remember that password.

77
00:04:25,660 --> 00:04:27,780
Maybe I do.
There we go, all right.

78
00:04:27,780 --> 00:04:32,550
If you can get to that spot,
things are pretty fine, right?

79
00:04:32,550 --> 00:04:36,020
If you can get to that spot and
you can't log in as a user.

80
00:04:36,020 --> 00:04:37,420
If you've forgotten the password.

81
00:04:37,420 --> 00:04:42,520
Or if you go to log in and
the Mac crashes and it shuts down.

82
00:04:42,520 --> 00:04:44,870
Well those are typically
software problems.

83
00:04:44,870 --> 00:04:47,630
Those are problems with that user account,
right?

84
00:04:47,630 --> 00:04:50,670
The user account that you'd just
log in as, oh that's our chat room,

85
00:04:50,670 --> 00:04:51,890
let me get that out of the way.

86
00:04:51,890 --> 00:04:52,570
There we go.

87
00:04:52,570 --> 00:04:54,800
So those are usually just problems
with the user account, and

88
00:04:54,800 --> 00:04:57,440
those can be solved by logging
in as a different user.

89
00:04:57,440 --> 00:05:01,020
It's pretty straightforward and I'll talk
a little bit more about that later on.

90
00:05:01,020 --> 00:05:05,170
But if you can't even get to
the login window, what do you do?

91
00:05:05,170 --> 00:05:08,630
Let's talk about each of those
four phases and what's happening.

92
00:05:08,630 --> 00:05:12,256
The very first phase when I booted,
was that I got a black screen, right?

93
00:05:12,256 --> 00:05:14,860
And that black screen was the firmware.

94
00:05:14,860 --> 00:05:16,410
Now, what is the firmware?

95
00:05:16,410 --> 00:05:20,190
Well, on the mother board for that Mac,
in this case it was the Mac Mini, but

96
00:05:20,190 --> 00:05:23,810
it would be the same for my laptop, or
MacBook Pro, or any thing like that.

97
00:05:23,810 --> 00:05:27,390
On that mother board, you have what
a lot of people call a Bios Chip, but

98
00:05:27,390 --> 00:05:31,360
Apple refers to as their firmware because
they have a custom firmware that written.

99
00:05:31,360 --> 00:05:34,970
And that firmware, is what's responsible
for powering on the hardware.

100
00:05:34,970 --> 00:05:38,410
When you push that power button,
the firmware's what wakes up all of your

101
00:05:38,410 --> 00:05:41,540
hardware, and says, hey, the hardware
needs electricity, so it can spin up.

102
00:05:41,540 --> 00:05:44,180
The CPU needs electricity so
it can power on.

103
00:05:44,180 --> 00:05:47,220
The memory needs electricity, and the CPU
needs to be allowed to talk to it, right.

104
00:05:47,220 --> 00:05:49,440
That's what your firmware is doing.

105
00:05:49,440 --> 00:05:53,790
While it's doing that,
it does what's called a post check.

106
00:05:53,790 --> 00:05:55,935
Or a power on self test.

107
00:05:55,935 --> 00:05:59,200
And the power on self test,
is we just start testing

108
00:05:59,200 --> 00:06:01,970
all the different hardware pieces,
to make sure they're functioning.

109
00:06:01,970 --> 00:06:04,830
The system says, hey,
I need to power on a video card.

110
00:06:04,830 --> 00:06:07,320
Well, if the video card won't power on,
we got a problem.

111
00:06:07,320 --> 00:06:10,370
So, that's a pretty good indicator
that we've got some failure there.

112
00:06:10,370 --> 00:06:13,580
If it can't power on the video card,
if it can't find the video card.

113
00:06:13,580 --> 00:06:15,440
But if it can't find the video card.

114
00:06:15,440 --> 00:06:17,010
And we get some error.

115
00:06:17,010 --> 00:06:18,034
What can the Mac tell us?

116
00:06:18,034 --> 00:06:18,810
It can't tell us much.

117
00:06:18,810 --> 00:06:22,190
It can't tell us much at all,
because it couldn't find a video card.

118
00:06:22,190 --> 00:06:24,550
It's not like it can
display an error message.

119
00:06:24,550 --> 00:06:29,970
So, at a firmware stage, it can be very
difficult to troubleshoot an error, right?

120
00:06:29,970 --> 00:06:31,140
What'll normally happen,

121
00:06:31,140 --> 00:06:37,080
when you have an error at that stage,
it's almost always a hardware problem.

122
00:06:37,080 --> 00:06:38,970
So we can't even get in to our software.

123
00:06:38,970 --> 00:06:40,660
We can't even boot from recovery.

124
00:06:40,660 --> 00:06:42,540
You can't even boot from removable media.

125
00:06:42,540 --> 00:06:44,220
You've got a hardware problem.

126
00:06:44,220 --> 00:06:45,540
Your video card failed.

127
00:06:45,540 --> 00:06:46,895
Your memory's failing.

128
00:06:46,895 --> 00:06:49,130
Your CPU has failed, something like that.

129
00:06:49,130 --> 00:06:51,030
And so what the mac will do,

130
00:06:51,030 --> 00:06:54,160
is it'll default to a different
way of reporting the error.

131
00:06:54,160 --> 00:06:58,650
If you have a hardware error like that,
you'll get one of two, or

132
00:06:58,650 --> 00:07:00,630
possibly both, types of messaging.

133
00:07:00,630 --> 00:07:02,650
The first form of messaging is the sound.

134
00:07:02,650 --> 00:07:03,780
An audible beep.

135
00:07:03,780 --> 00:07:06,352
And Apple calls them Beep Codes, so

136
00:07:06,352 --> 00:07:10,395
when you power on the Mac,
you just start to hear [SOUND].

137
00:07:10,395 --> 00:07:11,820
Or something like that.

138
00:07:11,820 --> 00:07:14,570
It will be a pattern,
long beeps and short beeps.

139
00:07:14,570 --> 00:07:19,496
You might hear beep, beep just like
that or you might hear beep-beep,

140
00:07:19,496 --> 00:07:23,920
beep-beep, different combinations there
and each combination means something.

141
00:07:23,920 --> 00:07:26,260
You can actually pull it up on the Apple
service manual, if you want, and

142
00:07:26,260 --> 00:07:28,500
you can actually find out what
each of those Beep Codes mean.

143
00:07:29,870 --> 00:07:31,566
But at this level, at the ACSP level,

144
00:07:31,566 --> 00:07:33,898
it doesn't really matter
what the Beep Code means,

145
00:07:33,898 --> 00:07:37,870
because regardless of the result, it
means your system needs hardware service.

146
00:07:37,870 --> 00:07:40,300
If you're getting Beep Code like that,

147
00:07:40,300 --> 00:07:43,350
you're more than likely gonna need to
take it down to Apple for repair, or

148
00:07:43,350 --> 00:07:47,680
do a warrantee exchange, whatever it
is you have for covering that unit.

149
00:07:47,680 --> 00:07:49,290
It's gonna have to have repairs.

150
00:07:49,290 --> 00:07:51,250
There are some times
when you can avoid that.

151
00:07:51,250 --> 00:07:54,440
For example,
like this Mac Mini in particular.

152
00:07:54,440 --> 00:07:56,750
This Mac Mini is last year's version.

153
00:07:56,750 --> 00:07:59,292
And so
it still has removable memory in it.

154
00:07:59,292 --> 00:08:01,290
If some of the memory became loose.

155
00:08:01,290 --> 00:08:04,375
Maybe I was moving the unit around and
a little memory chip became loose.

156
00:08:04,375 --> 00:08:06,333
Well, that could cause
a beep code when it boots.

157
00:08:06,333 --> 00:08:08,292
It can't find RAM, can't boot up.

158
00:08:08,292 --> 00:08:10,934
So, I might be able to just
undo the bottom cover and

159
00:08:10,934 --> 00:08:12,680
tighten those memory sticks.

160
00:08:12,680 --> 00:08:13,672
Take them out and put them back out.

161
00:08:13,672 --> 00:08:16,610
They call reseating the memory, and
that might fix the problem right there and

162
00:08:16,610 --> 00:08:18,145
I didn't have to I have
to do a warranty call.

163
00:08:18,145 --> 00:08:19,605
I have to do maintenance on it.

164
00:08:19,605 --> 00:08:21,955
Just pop the chip out and pop it back in.

165
00:08:21,955 --> 00:08:26,385
Or, it could be that a hard drive cable
came loose, it's unlikely in a Mac Mini,

166
00:08:26,385 --> 00:08:30,565
but it's possible in a Mac Pro or one of
the bigger Macs, you could have that.

167
00:08:30,565 --> 00:08:33,085
So you've checked the normal things.

168
00:08:33,085 --> 00:08:34,935
You've checked to make sure
your cables are seated,

169
00:08:34,935 --> 00:08:38,075
your cards are inserted properly,
you checked all those things.

170
00:08:38,075 --> 00:08:40,815
Another thing to try is to
unhook all of your peripherals.

171
00:08:41,880 --> 00:08:46,200
If you've got a FireWire camera hooked up,
and a USB hard drive, and

172
00:08:46,200 --> 00:08:48,520
a ThunderBolt monitor,
unhook all that stuff.

173
00:08:48,520 --> 00:08:51,630
Unhook everything except for the basics.

174
00:08:51,630 --> 00:08:54,190
Keyboard, mouse, monitor.

175
00:08:54,190 --> 00:08:55,630
And try and power it on then.

176
00:08:55,630 --> 00:08:57,730
It could be a peripheral
that's causing the problem.

177
00:08:57,730 --> 00:09:00,090
And that's a quick and
easy way to test it.

178
00:09:00,090 --> 00:09:03,580
But if you do that and you're still
getting a beep code then that means you do

179
00:09:03,580 --> 00:09:07,050
have some kind of hardware issue
inside of the unit itself, and

180
00:09:07,050 --> 00:09:08,510
you may not be able to fix that.

181
00:09:08,510 --> 00:09:10,030
You'll probably have to go in for
warranty.

182
00:09:11,260 --> 00:09:13,550
Sometimes you don't get a beep code.

183
00:09:13,550 --> 00:09:15,760
Sometimes the problem
is with the sound card.

184
00:09:15,760 --> 00:09:17,590
It's not able to generate those beeps and

185
00:09:17,590 --> 00:09:21,910
in those scenarios instead of a beep code,
you'll get a visual code.

186
00:09:21,910 --> 00:09:24,920
The power button on the Mac will flash,
all right?

187
00:09:24,920 --> 00:09:27,730
Normally, when you hit the power,
the power button lights up and

188
00:09:27,730 --> 00:09:30,040
just stays lit up the whole rest
of the time the Mac has booted.

189
00:09:30,040 --> 00:09:34,200
And if it goes to sleep, right, it does
that dim kind of fade in, fade out thing.

190
00:09:34,200 --> 00:09:35,900
But if you power on the Mac, and

191
00:09:35,900 --> 00:09:39,840
it can't generate an audio beep code,
it'll flash the power light instead.

192
00:09:39,840 --> 00:09:42,790
So, you'll have short flashes and
long flashes and

193
00:09:42,790 --> 00:09:46,130
those are indicating the same
types of codes as the audio beeps.

194
00:09:46,130 --> 00:09:48,700
And you can use those visual codes
to be able to decipher what's

195
00:09:48,700 --> 00:09:49,830
wrong with the Mac.

196
00:09:49,830 --> 00:09:52,720
You can go to Apple's website and
pull the service manual for your Mac and

197
00:09:52,720 --> 00:09:54,620
it'll tell you what those codes mean.

198
00:09:54,620 --> 00:09:58,070
But it's the same thing as the audio
codes, it doesn't really matter because

199
00:09:58,070 --> 00:10:01,640
whatever's wrong is usually going
to require hardware service.

200
00:10:01,640 --> 00:10:04,970
Reseat your cables, reseat your cards,
see if that fixes it.

201
00:10:04,970 --> 00:10:11,130
If it doesn't, you've got
a maintenance call in your future.

202
00:10:11,130 --> 00:10:14,985
That process, the firmware booting up,
when it loads,

203
00:10:14,985 --> 00:10:16,985
what it's loading is what
is called the Bootrom.

204
00:10:16,985 --> 00:10:19,115
So you'll hear people
talk about the Bootrom.

205
00:10:19,115 --> 00:10:23,025
And the Bootrom is that really,
really tiny operating system that

206
00:10:23,025 --> 00:10:26,915
just does basic things like powers on the
hardware, gets the system up and running.

207
00:10:26,915 --> 00:10:28,845
And every Mac has its own Bootrom.

208
00:10:28,845 --> 00:10:32,095
And the Bootrom does actually

209
00:10:32,095 --> 00:10:36,090
have some neat utilities built into it
that allow us to check our systems.

210
00:10:36,090 --> 00:10:37,260
One of the neatest ones,

211
00:10:37,260 --> 00:10:42,020
one that a lot of people don't know
about is the Apple hardware diagnostics.

212
00:10:42,020 --> 00:10:46,910
It is a hardware diagnostic built into
pretty much every Mac that you can access.

213
00:10:46,910 --> 00:10:48,000
But it's access to a hidden menu.

214
00:10:48,000 --> 00:10:50,080
And we're gonna see some of
these throughout the day.

00:10:50,080 --> 00:10:53,590
Is that we got a number of shortcut
combinations that we can do while our Mac

00:10:53,590 --> 00:10:55,299
boots that changes what it does.

So if I'm not even getting past

I never see an Apple logo up on my screen,
I've got a problem and

00:11:05,640 --> 00:11:08,110

00:11:08,110 --> 00:11:11,510
Now, if it's a video card problem, you're
not gonna be able to get to the hardware

00:11:11,510 --> 00:11:14,560
diagnostics, but if it's something else,

00:11:14,560 --> 00:11:17,250
You'll be able to get to it and

00:11:18,350 --> 00:11:20,170
If you wanna see the hardware diagnostics,

00:13:53,160 --> 00:13:54,830
On my MacBook Pro if I had booted,

00:14:03,570 --> 00:14:07,250
So you let it run, and

00:14:07,250 --> 00:14:10,030

00:14:10,030 --> 00:14:13,240

And now you can take down

00:14:16,970 --> 00:14:19,160
So neat little diagnostic there.

00:14:19,160 --> 00:14:22,400
And this is all done
Inside of the bootrom.

00:14:22,400 --> 00:14:25,180
So this would work even if I

00:14:25,180 --> 00:14:29,230

00:14:29,230 --> 00:14:31,530
It's a great way to do
a hardware diagnostic and

00:14:31,530 --> 00:14:33,800

00:14:33,800 --> 00:14:35,960
When I think I have a firmware problem,

00:14:35,960 --> 00:14:40,470

00:14:40,470 --> 00:14:45,280
If I get the gray apple up on the screen,

00:14:45,280 --> 00:14:48,670
That means it's already coming up and

By that point,

00:14:49,510 --> 00:14:53,040
the only hardware failure you might have

00:14:53,040 --> 00:14:54,670
If you have a hard drive failure,

00:14:54,670 --> 00:14:57,870
a lot of times you'll still get
that gray apple on the screen, And

00:14:57,870 --> 00:15:01,320
then it just doesn't get to where you
get the loading bar at the bottom right?

304
00:15:01,320 --> 00:15:03,400
So you get some different input there.

305
00:15:03,400 --> 00:15:06,780
This is why it's important to
understand the different stages of boot

306
00:15:06,780 --> 00:15:09,440
because you have different
problems at each stage.

307
00:15:09,440 --> 00:15:12,020
At this stage it's almost always hardware.

00:15:12,020 --> 00:15:16,140
Right, now Notice the first test
it's run here, testing memory.

309
00:15:16,140 --> 00:15:19,170
Memory problems are more
common than you'd think.

310
00:15:19,170 --> 00:15:21,410
A lot of people have memory problems and

311
00:15:21,410 --> 00:15:27,060
don't realize it, because memory problems
oftentimes look like hard drive problems.

312
00:15:27,060 --> 00:15:29,840
You save a file to your hard drive,
and then you go to open it and

313
00:15:29,840 --> 00:15:33,040
the file's corrupt, and you go, oh,
great, my hard drive must be failing,

314
00:15:33,040 --> 00:15:34,480
my file got corrupted.

315
00:15:34,480 --> 00:15:36,368
Well, what happens is,
any time you save a file,

316
00:15:36,368 --> 00:15:41,240
the file was stored in RAM and then it
writes it from RAM down to the hard drive.

317
00:15:41,240 --> 00:15:44,770
And when you open a file,
it opens the file from the hard drive and

318
