1222
01:00:43,690 --> 01:00:48,880
The last thing that we need to mention for
this troubleshooting episode is sleep.

1223
01:00:48,880 --> 01:00:51,850
Not our personal sleep,
although that is a nice thing to have, but

1224
01:00:51,850 --> 01:00:54,240
the sleep modes inside of Mac OS.

1225
01:00:55,630 --> 01:00:58,690
When you run a Mac, by default,
the way that it's shipped out of the box,

1226
01:00:58,690 --> 01:01:01,870
it's set to go to sleep periodically,
and what do I mean by sleep?

1227
01:01:01,870 --> 01:01:05,620
Well, if the computer sits idle for
long enough,

1228
01:01:05,620 --> 01:01:10,590
it will not power off completely,
but it will power down a good bit.

1229
01:01:10,590 --> 01:01:13,870
It'll take a lot of stuff like
the hard rives and stop spinning them.

1230
01:01:13,870 --> 01:01:17,150
The CPU, it will drop it to
a lower power level, slow it down.

1231
01:01:17,150 --> 01:01:20,000
It does all these things to conserve
energy while the computer is not

1232
01:01:20,000 --> 01:01:20,550
being used.

1233
01:01:21,580 --> 01:01:24,090
And for
the most part that's not a big deal.

1234
01:01:24,090 --> 01:01:27,860
But there are somethings we can tweak
about that sleep operation to change

1235
01:01:27,860 --> 01:01:31,430
the way that is works, and I want to show
you a couple of those that might creep up.

1236
01:01:31,430 --> 01:01:33,446
And I'll just stay in safe boot mode here,

1237
01:01:33,446 --> 01:01:36,950
I don't need anything that's
out of the ordinary for this.

1238
01:01:36,950 --> 01:01:40,590
But oh,
actually what are my power options.

1239
01:01:40,590 --> 01:01:42,350
But we'll see if my options
are all showing up right.

1240
01:01:43,660 --> 01:01:47,800
So if I go into my System Preferences,
you can go into Energy Saver, and

1241
01:01:47,800 --> 01:01:50,410
that's where you're gonna
see your sleep options.

1242
01:01:50,410 --> 01:01:53,590
And you'll see like, my turn display
off is set to never when I'm on a power

1243
01:01:53,590 --> 01:01:55,140
adapter, which they absolutely hate.

1244
01:01:55,140 --> 01:01:58,920
But, on yours, it will normally be set to
something like 20 minutes or 30 minutes

1245
01:01:58,920 --> 01:02:02,750
and if you haven't used the computer in
that time, it will turn the display off.

1246
01:02:02,750 --> 01:02:05,883
And then you'll see where you have
some other options here like prevent

1247
01:02:05,883 --> 01:02:09,550
the computer from sleeping
automatically when the display is off.

1248
01:02:09,550 --> 01:02:13,420
By default, if the display goes off,
the system goes to sleep.

1249
01:02:13,420 --> 01:02:16,880
Now, if you are trying to run
some programs in the background,

1250
01:02:16,880 --> 01:02:20,510
they should keep the system awake, but
if they weren't programmed correctly then

1251
01:02:20,510 --> 01:02:24,490
they might go to sleep also, and that
causes the system to have some problems.

1252
01:02:24,490 --> 01:02:27,920
When you're not able to run these
things while the system is asleep.

1253
01:02:27,920 --> 01:02:30,060
You can tell it to stay awake or

1254
01:02:30,060 --> 01:02:33,480
you can update your software to
make sure that it's supported.

1255
01:02:33,480 --> 01:02:35,100
But you've got a few other
options that are in here,

1256
01:02:35,100 --> 01:02:37,730
like put hard disc to sleep when possible.

1257
01:02:37,730 --> 01:02:39,740
Some people like that some people don't.

1258
01:02:39,740 --> 01:02:43,050
If you put your hard discs to sleep and
they're magnetic discs, the ones that

1259
01:02:43,050 --> 01:02:47,340
spin, the first time you go to access them
again it's got to spin them back up, and

1260
01:02:47,340 --> 01:02:50,980
that takes time so it makes your system
a little slow to come out of sleep mode.

1261
01:02:50,980 --> 01:02:52,140
Some people don't like that.

1262
01:02:52,140 --> 01:02:54,890
So you can turn that option off and
the hard drives will stay awake.

1263
01:02:56,250 --> 01:02:58,450
You've got wake for network access.

1264
01:02:58,450 --> 01:03:02,320
What if you've got back to my Mac turned
on, and your computer goes to sleep?

1265
01:03:02,320 --> 01:03:05,310
Well if your computer's asleep, you
can't remote into it to see your screen.

1266
01:03:05,310 --> 01:03:07,070
You can't use back to my Mac.

1267
01:03:07,070 --> 01:03:11,020
But, if you turn that on,
now when you fire up back to my Mac,

1268
01:03:11,020 --> 01:03:12,470
your computer'll wake up automatically.

1269
01:03:13,780 --> 01:03:15,670
Similar to that is power nap.

1270
01:03:15,670 --> 01:03:19,420
Power nap says while we're asleep,
from time to time the computer can wake up

1271
01:03:19,420 --> 01:03:23,310
to run time machine backups, check for
new email and all those other resources.

1272
01:03:23,310 --> 01:03:26,660
So those are things that kind of change
the way that that sleep mode works,

1273
01:03:26,660 --> 01:03:27,760
kind of waking that system up.

1274
01:03:27,760 --> 01:03:30,430
And then always remember that
you've got different options for

1275
01:03:30,430 --> 01:03:32,680
battery versus power adapter.

1276
01:03:32,680 --> 01:03:35,440
When you're on a wall socket versus
when you're running on battery,

1277
01:03:35,440 --> 01:03:39,600
then you might wanna be more restrictive
when you're on battery than when you're

1278
01:03:39,600 --> 01:03:40,660
on a wall adapter.

1279
01:03:40,660 --> 01:03:43,530
So little variations there.

1280
01:03:43,530 --> 01:03:47,220
Notice that when you're on battery,
wake for network access isn't an option.

1281
01:03:47,220 --> 01:03:51,734
That's because normally when you're on
battery, you're on wireless networks, and

1282
01:03:51,734 --> 01:03:55,882
when you go to sleep, the wireless adapter
is one of the things that consumes a lot

1283
01:03:55,882 --> 01:04:00,167
of power, so it goes to sleep too and it's
not able to wake on the network activity.

1284
01:04:00,167 --> 01:04:02,495
So those are some of the basics settings
we need to be aware of outside of

1285
01:04:02,495 --> 01:04:03,293
the power management.

1286
01:04:03,293 --> 01:04:06,451
Now there's one other thing that
can cause the problems, and

1287
01:04:06,451 --> 01:04:10,292
this really started back with Mavericks,
but it's the same in Yosemite.

1288
01:04:10,292 --> 01:04:14,500
There's something inside
of Yosemite called App Nap.

1289
01:04:14,500 --> 01:04:17,928
And what App Nap does is it says
that there's a program running in

1290
01:04:17,928 --> 01:04:21,989
the background and it's been idle for
awhile and we haven't been using it,

1291
01:04:21,989 --> 01:04:24,167
it can actually sleep the application.

1292
01:04:24,167 --> 01:04:26,236
And it takes the memory for
that application and

1293
01:04:26,236 --> 01:04:29,545
it kind of writes it to the hard drive and
it puts that application to sleep and

1294
01:04:29,545 --> 01:04:30,542
it stops responding.

1295
01:04:30,542 --> 01:04:32,793
Well, I work with virtual machines a lot,
and

1296
01:04:32,793 --> 01:04:36,548
I would have this problem where virtual
machines would start to go to sleep and

1297
01:04:36,548 --> 01:04:39,583
I would try and remote into them,
and I couldn't get to them.

1298
01:04:39,583 --> 01:04:43,449
If you have background software
that you want to run all the time,

1299
01:04:43,449 --> 01:04:47,560
that you don't want to go to sleep,
you'll want to turn off App Nap.

1300
01:04:47,560 --> 01:04:48,860
If I browse on my hard drive and

1301
01:04:48,860 --> 01:04:54,360
go into applications, let's see,
what would be a good application for me.

1302
01:04:54,360 --> 01:05:00,150
Maybe something like,
I know what I wanna do and I don't see it.

1303
01:05:00,150 --> 01:05:02,220
So we'll say something like Google Chrome,
right?

1304
01:05:02,220 --> 01:05:04,890
Maybe I have Chrome running and
it's checking my email and

1305
01:05:04,890 --> 01:05:08,630
doing on-screen notifications, so I always
wanna get those on-screen notifications.

1306
01:05:08,630 --> 01:05:11,988
Well, if it goes to sleep,
I wont get those on-screen notifications.

1307
01:05:11,988 --> 01:05:16,280
So I can choose Chrome and I can pull up
it's information, you can just right click

1308
01:05:16,280 --> 01:05:22,325
and do get information or Ctrl+Click or
whatever it is you wanna do to get there.

1309
01:05:22,325 --> 01:05:23,940
Cmd+I is what I did.

1310
01:05:23,940 --> 01:05:27,860
And inside you'll see that option
right here, Prevent App Nap.

1311
01:05:27,860 --> 01:05:31,020
So if you have a program that is
intended to be running all the time.

1312
01:05:31,020 --> 01:05:33,070
And for some reason, every now and
then, you can't get to it or

1313
01:05:33,070 --> 01:05:34,280
it's not responding.

1314
01:05:34,280 --> 01:05:35,810
It might be because it's
gone into App Nap mode.

1315
01:05:35,810 --> 01:05:38,370
And you can turn that off for
it, and now when you run it,

1316
01:05:38,370 --> 01:05:41,030
it'll just stay awake all the time and
it'll always be available.

1317
01:05:41,030 --> 01:05:44,320
It's a problem that I've bumped into
more than my fair share of times.

1318
01:05:46,085 --> 01:05:50,375
The other thing about sleep mode is when
you go into sleep mode your Mac will take

1319
01:05:50,375 --> 01:05:53,505
what's in memory and
write it to the hard drive.

1320
01:05:53,505 --> 01:05:56,925
And it's doing that, actually hang on,
it only does that if you have a battery.

1321
01:05:56,925 --> 01:05:58,565
If you don't have a battery
it doesn't worry about it.

1322
01:05:58,565 --> 01:06:01,445
But if you have a battery when
your system goes to sleep,

1323
01:06:01,445 --> 01:06:03,845
it'll write whats in
RAM to the hard drive.

1324
01:06:03,845 --> 01:06:07,680
And the reason it's doing that is if your
battery runs out, what's gonna happen to

1325
01:06:07,680 --> 01:06:11,030
your system, it's gonna power off, and
then it wants you to loose your data.

1326
01:06:11,030 --> 01:06:13,400
So then, what happens is if
you power your laptop on,

1327
01:06:13,400 --> 01:06:16,450
it will see that memory
written into the hard drive,

1328
01:06:16,450 --> 01:06:20,140
it will reload it into RAM, and
you'll resume right where you left off.

1329
01:06:20,140 --> 01:06:24,020
That's called hibernate, and
hibernation is a default thing,

1330
01:06:24,020 --> 01:06:26,160
it's turned on it's part of sleep mode.

1331
01:06:26,160 --> 01:06:29,240
If you're on a battery,
it's supports hibernate.

1332
01:06:29,240 --> 01:06:30,870
If you're on a desktop it doesn't.

1333
01:06:30,870 --> 01:06:34,880
It goes on that low power mode, and you're
on a wall socket so you've always got some

1334
01:06:34,880 --> 01:06:38,330
power, unless you have a power outage,
in which case it just goes off, right.

1335
01:06:38,330 --> 01:06:40,460
You don't need hibernate on a desktop, but

1336
01:06:40,460 --> 01:06:44,470
on a laptop you do because a laptop
it doesn't have continuous power.

1337
01:06:44,470 --> 01:06:47,570
If that power runs out hibernate
will make sure your data's safe.

1338
01:06:49,372 --> 01:06:51,940
All right, so
those are a few things to think about.

1339
01:06:51,940 --> 01:06:54,420
Let's see, what else is there?

1340
01:06:54,420 --> 01:06:56,130
I think that's really about it.

1341
01:06:56,130 --> 01:06:59,370
I don't think I have
anything else on that one.

1342
01:06:59,370 --> 01:07:04,590
It is possible that your computer
goes to sleep, your laptop or

1343
01:07:04,590 --> 01:07:07,760
whatever runs out of battery power and
it goes into hibernate mode.

1344
01:07:07,760 --> 01:07:12,840
And something about that memory was
written to the system and it's bad.

1345
01:07:12,840 --> 01:07:14,280
And it won't boot up.

1346
01:07:14,280 --> 01:07:16,150
And it can't boot, right?

1347
01:07:16,150 --> 01:07:18,390
The way to flush that is safe boot.

1348
01:07:18,390 --> 01:07:20,100
Just hold Shift while you're booting.

1349
01:07:20,100 --> 01:07:23,869
If you hold Shift while you're booting,
it throws out your extension cache and

1350
01:07:23,869 --> 01:07:28,190
it throws out whatever sleep mode, or
whatever hibernate might have cached also.

1351
01:07:28,190 --> 01:07:31,040
And it gives you a fresh,
clean, boot, all right?

1352
01:07:31,040 --> 01:07:33,130
It'll take a lot longer to boot,
and it is Safe Boot.

1353
01:07:33,130 --> 01:07:35,280
Once you're done you gotta reboot again,
so

1354
01:07:35,280 --> 01:07:36,970
that's the way you kind
of force that along.

1355
01:07:36,970 --> 01:07:38,490
Safe Boot's a pretty handy tool to use.
